Because Capitano isn't the best thing that apple had creat and im on a 2015 apple PC

row.Title: Run Forest, Run!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Mail, N/A, Performance, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: After updating on a late 2013 MBP I am seriously considering downgrading to Yosemite.
El Capitan seems to be buggy and unstable where I had very few issues with Yosemite.
Yosemite quicker with less battery drain.
Mail has become unstable, fails to get new mail, constantly freezes and can only be killed from the unix prompt.
Mavericks to Yosemite was full of pleasant surprises.
Yosemite to El Capitan is a big disappointment.
Feels like upgrading from Windows XP to Windows Vista.
At least email still worked properly on Vista.
If you are considering upgrading check out the support forums first.
I am not the only one seeing these issues.

PROS:* added Find My Friends to Notification CentreCONS* breaks USB devices like serial ports and scanners* breaks USB on VirtualBox VM* Mail * sleep wake issues with unexpected reboots after sleeping for >1 hour* Mail app completely locks up and am unable to refresh emails for 15+ minutes* Email appears then disappears* sleep issues causing excessive battery drain - put device fully charged to sleep at night, next morning battery completely dead and needs power to boot* Bugs - Keyboard text shortcuts keep disappearing, only reappears after reboot* Safari - after update many working websites stop working* Safari hand off from ios not working as well as Yosemite* need to reboot often to fix bugs
i don't know why many people have problems with this update-it runs great for me!
You have to write the review a few days after the update, to make sure that the system finished the indexing files, so that you would get optimal peformance.
It seems to run slightly faster than Mavericks, which i updated from.
Day-to-day use is very smooth, and i'm happy with updating.
However, the split-screen feature could be better, because it's slightly harder to enable IMO than windows.
If you have doubt, make a backup through time machine, and try it out for a few days-your initial experience might change after more usage, as the system optimizes.
I have MacBook Air mid 2011, 4GB RAM, 256GB SSD
After updating to Yosemite my Mac felt noticably more sluggish than with Mavericks (boot up time was much longer, apps took longer to open, wifi connectivity issues).
I decided to do a clean install of El Capitain once the new update was released and couldnt be happier.
I saved all my files to an external hard drive, erased my macintosh hard drive and proceeded with a clean install of OS X El Capitain from a bootable USB that I made with instructions I found online.
My mac is running like it did the day I bought it even tho it is now 3 years old.
If anyone experienced slow downs after installing OS X Yosemite, I would definitely recommend backing up all your important files and doing a clean install of El Capitain.
Screenlock appears on my 2011 17 inch Macbook Pro without being enabled in settings.
Turning it on and off does not resolve the problem.
Forget the gimmicks and give us a rock solid OSX like Snow Leopard, Apple.
Thats what drew us to you in the first place.
So far so good, updated my 5 year old macbook to this most recent OS with absolutely no problems.
Save yourself a lot of grief and don't upgrade.
I've had Mac's for years and this is the first time I've had to re-install the OS.
My system keeps shutting down , 4th time now over past 2 weeks since upgrading.
Come-on Apple, I would expect this from Microsoft NOT you.....very disappointed.
Early 2011 Macbook Pro - Everything has slowed down since the update.
Even while writing this review, my computer has stalled.
The features are not earth shattering either.
Wait until the update is stable before downloading.
I downloaded this update and now I'm having major issues with my Mac.
The first major issue was with my mail.
None of my accounts would connect.
After several hours of playing with settings and deleting and re-adding accounts they finally started to work.
I cannot access the Disk Utility without the system freezing.
I can't do a Restart without the system jamming.
Wish I had NEVER installed this.

row.Sentences: 10.11.1 has really solidified my user experience with the new El Capitan.
Those who take time to learn the various OS capabilities in this system will be very pleased.
Emphasis: take the time to learn how to use El Capitan!

row.Title: would be nice if I could install it

row.Sentences: My MacPro is compatible yet I can't install the darn thing

row.Title: Don't know what all the negative reviews are about

row.Sentences: Went off like a charm, little slow to download and it gave me a bit of trouble installing but other than that it seems to have sped up the time it takes apps to open.
i have 15" 250 go in flash after the update became very slow.
Sorry Apple I gone put back Yosemite.
some of the apps don't function properly, or as well as with yosemite.
System is much slower & has crashed a few times since downloading El Capitan; photos is no longer user friendly and the dating system on photos is really, really annoying.
Thinking of dumping El Capitan and going back to yosemite.
I love the new features in this new OS or should I say this Yosemite update.
The only problem is the bugs and its also unstable.
It crashes everytime when I try to open a PDF which is just sad.
I also noticed some weird graphics hanging around the screen that clicker somtimes which is very annoying and unnacceptable.

row.Title: Mid 2011 imac. working great so far.

row.Sentences: It is confusing others are having issues while many of us do not.
I have been pleased with this update.
Had to restore because of my own mistake- interrupting the new itunes update.
Upon completion of the restore, and downloading all required updates, so far so good.
Zero issues to report, no spinning beachballs, no issues with the cloud, or photos.
Remember everyone you do still have iPhoto and all its old contents should be intact.
AND- you can choose not to transfer to the photos app if stability or your library are critical to you and the reviews cause you concern.
Backing up to time machine and the cloud on a few fronts is certainly worth the effort.
I would also recommend those who experience issues do regular maintenance such as time machine backups (a must if you treasure your data).
Kaspersky for mac and clean my mac 2 are also huge in good housekeeping; you still have to do that yes, even on a mac.
Though more secure than windows, it is not perfect.
In any case It is also fair to say that new OS versions will always tend to be optimized for newer macs first and then get the required adjustments as they become discovered and addressed.
Keep in mind too, that older systems (4 years plus) are always going to need optimization so hold off if your concerned with reviews that may apply to you.
There is no reason to rush, especially if your system is working just fine the way it is.
With millions of machines and configurations, it is no wonder that some things will work perfectly in set up a vs. not perfectly in set up b.
It would be virtually impossible to address every cause and effect problem prior to release.
The real world feedback is the only way to be proactive for hardware and software adjusments.
With new Os changes will also mean some apps need to be optimized under certain conditions as well.
If you find one app doesn't work as before, fear not, devs know this via consumer feedback, and will address issues as well.
Being part of the community and sharing experiences is key to systems working well together.
All in all, for us here, only a few minor bugs have come to light so far, but nothing worth mentioning..... so far.
In general usage terms, it IS much more fluid than Yosemite in many areas.
Very pleased with the attention to details.
By the way shaking the mouse to get the large arrow effect is intentional I believe.

It is so if you happen to lose sight of the pointer (think backgrounds with lots of text or a wallpaper that hides the pointer, or if your not 1-2 ft. away from the mac.... shaking the mouse left to right makes the arrow enlarge so you can quickly see its location again.
Not sure if this can be adjusted in preferences.

row.Title: Decent update from OSX Yosemite
row.Topic: Compatibility, Feature, Installation, N/A, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: I've updated 3 machines now: a Mac Mini 2011 and 2 x 2013 15inch rMBPs without any issues.
No stability concerns, no random crashes the entire process was rather painless (for a change).

The new "rootless" is a little annoying when you want (or need to) force override the EDID monitor profiles, but nothing that a quick reboot into recovery mode can't resolve and otherwise rootless has not impacted on anything I have to do day-to-day.
In fact as far as upgrades go this is the first time I have NOT had issues with an OSX update.
Even my Homebrew installatations were transitioned just fine and only minor quibbles with permissions that were easily fixed.
Previously every OSX update ended up requiring a clean install and installation from USB key because I always had errors and random problems - but not this time.
The only actual niggle I have is not even an Apple issue: Microsoft have not (can't be bothered to??)
updated IntelliType / IntelliPoint so the mouse/keyboard drivers will not load.

I use a Natural 4000 keyboard to help reduce wrist strain, and currently I cannot use all the key mappings - but media play/pause and volume actually work OK. Other than that, my only other comment is with iTunes and the latest update, 12.3.1, that re-enabled Apple Music after I explicitly disabled it; and it slapped the screen up front and centre when I re-opened iTunes *grrr* That was annoying since I have absolutely no interest in the service.

I was just wondering, of all the people out there that have problems with your Mac, how many of you do any maintenance to keep your computer running smoothly?All computers need maintenance at one time or another.
I will agree that after installing the update my computer did hang a bit more than usual when opening an app.
I run an app called El Capitan Cache Cleaner that I have used for quite a while, and after a reboot the computer runs great.
For all of you out there that want free, it costs money to buy it, (9.99 if I remember correctly).
They update to the new versions all the time, and some times you will have to repay a reduced price after some version updates.
I have no affiliation to the company, and I'm just telling you what works for me.
I am no computer wiz, ( I consider my self middle of the road experience wise), and it is very easy to use.
For the more advanced people there are things in there I don't undestand that you probably will.
For the novice user, very, very simple to run.
I can't remember where I found this app, and I've used it for at least 2 yrs.
I've used it since before Yosemite, (cant remember all the other os updates), and update to the newer version when needed.
I love free just like anyone else, but when you find an app that is actually worth it, why not support the developer for helping you out?
Just my opinion.
Regardless, I love this app.
Probably wont solve any app issues your having, but I'm willing to bet it will solve hanging issues some of you are having.

I really hate posting anything to the internet because it's full of lets just say unhappy people that dont realize that peoples opinions are there own, so let me sum up my post for you unhappy people.
I'm not affiliated with the developers, this works for me might not for you, and if you don't like to pay for apps, this app is not for you.
For any of you ,especially novices who have no clue how to maintain your computer, this may work for you.
For the record I have a 15 inc, 2.2 ghz MacBook Pro.
It's about 4 years old and runs great.
Be warned - the upgrade is utterly horrible- your computer will crash - Office 2016 does not work well with this version - It crashes at every turn - Just a horrible experience all around.
Come on Apple - you can do so much better!

row.Title: Wish I could go back, or not!

row.Sentences: It's always been like that, when updating my software from my mac, a deep cold in my guts, a leap of faith on thousands of programmers that we all rely on and have to trust.
Since my first one, I can't even remember if it was Snow Leopard or not.

Anyway, the first couple weeks I would always complain about all that had changed and wish I could go back, not very different this time, but given a few more time understanding what is happening in the system I can change and adapt all my way of working from the old to the new.
This new OS is essentially the same, always improving not only the way the system works but how we work and use our iOS, never leaving us stagnated in our old way.
Is it comfortable staying old?
Therefore, this is more like a thank you note.
Thanks very much to all you who devoted time improving my system and my life.
Keep strong and updating!!

row.Title: Flawless Performance Boost
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Seamless upgrade.2.
Immediate performance increase for my Macbook Pro Retina, Mid 2014 Edition.3.
The ability to now utilize a "snap" feature on OS, is an extremely beneficial and productive feature that has been borrowed from Windows.
Considering that 99% of my work revolves around Windows computers and networks, it is a blessing to finally see it come to Mac.4.
Had previously had a few programs that would get the rainbow spinwheel after one of the minor Yosemite patches.
In fact, the only reason I know there is a new type of pinwheel is from viewing it online.
And yes, the old one is a better rainbow spinner.
But hey, if I don't see it....5.
Machine now boots as fast as when first puchased, and logs in immediately just as it intially did.
Again, it was after one of the minor Yosemite patches that it slowed down.6.

The 1 Star ratings and people saying it slowed down their machines, I am very much suspecting have something to do with people installing the latest OS onto machines that aren't up to par with the latest and greatest.
Much like I always listed to people griping about how slow a Windows machine was, when it was trying to run Windows 7 on 1GB of RAM and an old 5400rpm hard drive, and a Celeron processor.
It's not the OS people, it's the hardware you're expecting to run it.7.
Buying a Mac is like buying a Windows PC, if you buy the lowest, entry level Mac, it won't matter if you're a 2015 model.
It's still the ENTRY level hardware.
If you want to have the latest OS X, and bells and whistles as they arrive, you need to invest in hardware that is capable of handling it.
In closing, I've been running OS X El Capitan for weeks, and it's been nothing but flawless, quite literally no glitches, no issues, notta.
Also, I noticed someone complaining that when moving the mouse or trackpad extremely fast, the cursor gets very large.
I don't believe this is a glitch, it's in fact to help people to see where it is, if and when they are wiggling the cursor quickly to try and locate it on higher reolutions and large screens.
some bugs in safari and parental control
I have this installed on my 2009 Macbook Pro with a SSD and I have found no issues so far, some of these reviewers may need a hardware upgrade.
This is the worst update ever!
I've lost all of my apps and data, including years of irreplaceable CD's copied to my Mac music library.
My trust in Apple has been destroyed.

It paused on me too, tried to restart from applications menu and App Store, it locks up computer so I shut down, reboot and it will ask me to sign in to icloud to down load and repeatedly locks up on pause again.
Using 1 year old MBPR with everything.
Hate it, 2 days now.
Even ran Eset to see if virus but nothing there either.
Completely hung up on Pause for week now
don't see why there are so many negative reviews, works great!
Constant wheel spin.
What happened, revert to Yosemite.

Since updating, computer can no longer handle graphics intensive programs without having them hang and die on me constantly (and this in spite of the fact that I'm using a high end mac that more than meets the system requirements of said apps).
Terrible update, feels more like I've downloaded a virus.
Everything moves like molasses compared to Yosemite, and I'm not at all pleased with the performance (or lack thereof) that I've been seeing since updating to El Captain.
I was hoping that the last system software patch released just a day or two before this post would address these issues, but no dice; same problems still persist.
Don't upgrade until Apple gets it RIGHT.
I've bought my first Mac a month before of this realese.
I'm totaly disapointed with this new system.
My Mac is sometimes closing the windows suddenly and for some jobs is working slowly as well.
How can I to return to Yosemite?

row.Title: Great update for my mid-2014 macbook pro

row.Sentences: Everything works perfectly for me and it's much more reactive!
Logic Pro X works flawlessly with all my Waves plugins.
Apogee is really quick on releasing updates too.
I'm glad that this year Apple decided to do a "Snow Leopard" style upgrade this year, and buckle down on performance and stability, while still adding some really cool features.
There have been some issues with it but it's mostly with third party apps that haven't been updated for El Capitain.
If you don't have any mission critical apps that arn't haven't been updated for El Capitain, I highly recomend this update.

row.Title: too many bugs even after update!

row.Sentences: Finder gets stuck on regular bases.
There are quite a few applications not respoding as they should.
It is a great major update if only they can fix the bugs and performance isssues.
It was a premature release.
It will be rock solid when they realease 10.11.6.. or something.
I have just updated to OS El Capitan, only to discover that I can no longer access my Windows 7 partition in bootcamp.
On the Mac desktop, I can see that the disk space that I have allotted to Mac remains at what I set it after setting up Bootcamp.
The rest of the drive is shown as an icon labelled "remote disk", but gives no further information about partition size or content.
In addition, I have noticed on a couple occasions that, when browsing the internet, the curser ceases to function properly.
Ther have also been occasions when the system froze during normal appication use, and then rebooted on its own.
This is what yosemite should have been; you can call this Snow Leopard IIApple needs to stop pumping out tons of features every year at the expense of system speed and stability.
We need more updates like El Cap.
Here's hoping that they do the same for iOS....which is a buggy mess as of late.
To all the !d!ots giving 1 star reviews, blame yourself for getting a slow computer with traditional hard drive.
Time to stop being a cheap@ss and upgrade to a SSD.

row.Title: The worst Apple experience I've ever had.

row.Sentences: An operating system bent on making users of Office products as frustrated as possible.
Non-communicative response from comany in terms of fixing the compatibility issues with office as a priority.
A poor product, a poor roll-out, and poor communication - three things I don't expect from Apple.
I did the mistake to run the upgrade for our two Mac (Air & Pro).
This is the worst upgrade that I have made and even the lastest update did not help.
The computers are slow, unresponsive except in safe mode.
I used my time capsule to go back to Yosemite with mixed results.... so I'm debating if I will do it with the second computer.

row.Title: I wish I had never downloaded

row.Sentences: Being a devoted Apple user, I trusted that this update would be as seamless as the others.
Kudos to Apple support for the 6 days (yes, six days) of support they gave me to help me try to overhaul both my iMac and my MacBook as everything went haywire following installation.
The iMac is still problematic.
I don't dare turn it off since doing so usually results in having to reinstall a back-up from Time machine before reinstalling the operating system.
I'm waiting for the update that will, hopefully, solve some of these issues.
No wonder it hasn't been offered for almost instant installation.
Someone knows there are issues with the version but no one is talking.
crashed my laptop.
only do this if you have backed up you comp like i didn't...

row.Title: Hotmail still not working..even with new update

row.Sentences: Hotmail server still not woking in the mail app.
Even with the new update..
If there were no stars I'd be giving it.
It's been downloading for the past hour and nothing.... absolutely nothing.

row.Title: Mail index corupt - stuck in loop trying to import messages

row.Sentences: I upgraded last week and nothing but issues, especially with Mail and Microsoft PowerPoint / Word (Office) crashes.
Applied the patch.
Laptop is fine.
Desktop is having issues loading Mail and says it needs 89 hours to import messages.
Seems like Apple pushes Software out more quickly but with less quality.
My macbook Air refuses to shutdown or restart after upgrade.
MacBook Pro, late 2011 - so it's a bit older, dual core i5, but with upgraded memory.
This works fantastic for me.
I love the flat look, I like the speed, and everything seems stable for me.
The only issue I had was actually downloading it.
Overloaded servers or my connection caused the download to fail several times, and restart, once at 97%.
This update has reminded me what it was like when I was a PC owner constantly trying to figure out how to make something work.
This is an update Bill Gates would be proud of!
I need my printer back!!
No print drivers work!
Just upgraded to 10.11.1.
Option to display login window as "Name and password" rather than "List of Users" still does not work.
Please fix ASAP!

row.Title: Sighshould have avoided updating like the reviews said.

row.Sentences: Sigh....should have avoided updating like the reviews said, despite the promises of a more efficient and snappier OS.
Did the latest update OS X El Capitan 10.11.1 update and the Digital Camera RAW Compatibility Update 6.17, now iTunes App is complete frozen.
I can't play or manage my music, can't manage iOS Apps(do updates), can't even quit the App without "Force Quit".
Also overall, my MacBook Air Mid-2011(CTO'd with highest SSD, Processor and RAM) is now even slower than after the "Maverick" update.
I really should have avoided this update, I'm really regretting it now.
I upgraded the OS as I was pretty excited about all those new features.
However, EI Capitan is very disappointing.
One thing I have to clarify, My MacBook Pro 13' was bought last year which is the old version without "force touch'.
My brother currently has the "force touch' one.
I compared El Captian on both macbook, new OS works perfectly fine on the new macbook with forch touch while many features are gone on the old macbook.
I can easliy used the built-in translation function by using three-finger gesture and temporily open a sub window using the same gesture by pointing to a link.
However, all these have been removed from the El Capitan update on my old macbook.
Bad update, it doest take care of the old macbook users.
I am soooo regreted that I chose to update to this version!
Everything runs way slower than before; battery can only supoort me for 4 or 5 hours without runing any app; plus my Outlook is totally down with this update!

row.Title: No problems on iMac (27-inch, Mid 2011) TRY IT

row.Sentences: So far no major problems.
When you open an app for the first time it may be a bit slower but when you use next time - same app different files (office, finder, mail, safari, etc)- it does not delay.
Overall the performance seems to be higher than the Yosemite - will have to see in the long run.
Reccomend to try it!
Dont like it - switch back to Yosemite.
PS: it does take a long time to download and install but for over 6Gb size it is fine.
Ok I personnaly use a retina mid-2013 macbook pro retina with 8 gb ram.
No problems in the last month and a half of usage on the bug side....
I did not yet check if the crashing from usb is still an issue under this OS, thing which happened to me under Yosemite.
The most bothering thing with El Capitan for me is the fact that not all apps apply to split-screen so I go on to attempt to have split-view with two apps only to notice it's not possible....
So I resorted to using Flexiglass once again for a while.
I am surprised how divided the ratings are on the operating system.
I guess it all goes down to how recent your machine is.
With my machine, Yosemite just made my computer better and El Capitan also with some refinements.
How can I complain when compared to other backup solutions on the windows side that were burdensome or otherwise inelegant?
I have never had a failure of my mac as of yet, I don't depend ont time machine but it works!

Here are some of the details I love with the actual OS : - When in full-screen in Safari I can drag to the left side my mouse to access my bookmarks bar.- Animations and bookmarking in the favorites has been much more fluid and visually appealing, on top of having a much nicer layout for folders.- Auto-play of mini-viewed videos on mouse-over in Photos (neat!

)- The cursor jiggle trick is neat also.... sometimes I'm surprised that such functions took so long to become mainstream.- I was thrilled for one week that I could now finally hide the menu bar.... only to revert back from auto-hiding....

Fact is, it became bothersome when the menu bar popped back into view while browing the web and I generally do large strides in cursor movements then get more precise in my action as I go towards the top of the screen.... As such, the menu bar almost always appeared unless I was being careful.... and I don't want to be careful doing this.... so auto-hide off.
(But it is quite elegant when auto-hide is on, so thanks Apple for making it possible.
)- Pinned tabs in safari?
(AKA, death of the bookmarks bar for me)- Added flexibility to the share button in Safari renders obsolete the use of many different plugins.
(Less plugins is better)All in all I could go on with all the features, wether they be useful or just a nifty touch that makes using my computer evermoreso pleasurable.
I can only say that I'm filled with gratitude that his OS has delivered in its promises while not breaking anything for me.
When Yosemite was released, I lost a lot of fluidity in transitions between desktops with the four finger gestur swipe.

That was fixed a little later on with dot upgrades but I see no hickups as of yet except for one special-use case for me : - While I like the way Safari handles bookmarks, if I were to apply my favorite setup (of one line per section and folder for all the rest per category) there is excessive choppiness to the scrolling.
But as folders are becoming much more enjoyable, exception of the fact that when you put something in a folder you are far less likely to use it....
I now use folders....
But mainly, the simple fact of having bookmarks stored I actually far more often end up using them through spotlight or the search bar.

row.Title: cancelled the update after reading more negatives than positives

row.Sentences: I'll wait for Apple's statement in response to the negative reviews.
Hopefully, issues that arised with OS X El Capitan be resolved immediately before I go ahead with the update.
Just switched from Mavericks to El Capitan on my Mid-2012 MacBook Air.
The aesthetic change doesn't bother me, but I have noticed decreased performance in several areas since installing the new OS.

My start up time has doubles from 10 seconds to about 20, I've noticed choppiness in the display on start up as well as when opening apps like safari, several programs now take longer to start up, a few graphically non-intensive games that I run have experienced dips in performance and choppiness, and I have noticed delays in response time from the cursor when starting up apps or connecting other devices.
I keep my hard drive streamlined and am nowhere near my 120 gb limit.
Definitely regretting the switch and wishing I could go back to Maverick so that my computer would perform the way it used to.
TL;DR: Unless you need to upgrade your OS for a specific reasons, Don't do it.
I've noticed a general decrease in performance (Maverick-El Capitan).
Current version is OSx 10.11.1.
Just to be on the safe side, I did a Time Machine backup to an external drive before upgrading.
I was thrilled not to have needed that backup!
Upgrade from Yosemite was glassy smooth and uneventful.
Love many of the new features and my 15" MBP Retina, late 2013 is working faster and more efficiently than ever!
For those having problems, it might be helpful to write which version of hardware you're using into your reviews.
Others with the same Mac hardware version might be experiencing the same problem.
This was a very good update except for the fact that apple was not very good at pointing out some of the new features.

For example: when you move your cursor around really fast, alot of people are saying that it's a bug because they don't know it's supposed to happen (Also most of the people that say that are dumbasses and dont what "disable' means).
I have not yet to encounter a real bug.
Good job apple.
Since that update to El Capitan, I can't open my mail anymore with my login/password.
My online iCloud works but not my Desktop app.
Very bad experience!
Please remove all racist emojis from Mac OS and iOS!
All emojis must be gender and race neutral.
Isn't that obvious?Please, work on something useful.
There are still many problems in 10.11 to fix.
It took more than 2 hours for the update to complete.
Even after the update, my macbook pro (late 2012) significantly SLOWED DOWN instead of speeding up as promised.
I had to reboot twice to get it stable.
My RAM was still being used at 100% running just chrome.
I've had to use a ram booster to clear my ram and it's now a bit more bearable
So far so good except that Time Machine cannot backup since the upgrade.
It tells me about being unable to write or create a folder....
Disk utility tells me that the disk is OK but something's wrong for sure.
Don't know what's going on.
Plz fix this !
Update: Really bad upgrade from apple....
I miss Maverick.... but since my time machine have errors since el capitan, can't go back for now...

row.Title: Dumped it, back to Yosemite for now

row.Sentences: Tried this update on my 2011 13in MBP.
It seemed ok until it started to sync with iCloud.
16 hours later, still no movement on the update bar.
So I did the time warp and undid the whole mess.
Sorry Apple but this kind of dissapointment was unheard of in days past.
Not only is everything slower (wish I read these reviews before I updated) - and that spinning wheel is so much more frequent....but THE WORST is I can no longer open my Apple Mail.
It gets hung up on the "Validating mailboxes" screen and everything then runs painfully slow.
And why is my hard drive always grinding away - what's it working at?
I miss OSX Lion.
Apple, you're losing this fanboy.
I begin by, my older macbook of 8 years old was running on Snow leopard because it was the most stable, rocksolid one.
After updating my personal MacBook Pro 2011 with OS X 10.11 it went great & it is the most stable, rock solid, polished one that I have experienced yet.
Thank you Apple, this is a great update, I love working on this.
I just returned 2 years ago with performences.
*OS X 10.11.1 Awesome Update

row.Title: The absolute worst!!!!!!!
row.Topic: Feature, N/A, Performance, Safari, Speed, Update

row.Sentences: Dont bother with this update.
My computer is soooooo slowwwwwwwwwwwwww after this it is driving me crazy.
Disk utility doesnt allow for permission repairs when I need to make them still.
but the worst is the speed.... if you can handle waiting a minute or 2 for a page to load then be my guest.... if it bothers you.... then don't upgrade to this ridiculous OS.
who cares if it is a free update.... if it makes your computer slower than cold molasses then what is the point.
Please tell me where the improvement is?
Safari has bugs galore so I dont even use it anymore and Chrome wont even launch.
Firefox is the only thing I can use as a browser and it is less than acceptabtable.... but at least it works i guess.
I have been on a mac for 20+ years and it seems they are going in the wrong direction.... Apple.... are you hiring people from microsoft because Steve would find this update appauling.
Make it better or dont make it at all.
I have had to waste the time and effort to wipe my hard drive clean and start from scratch reinstalling everything as I was on the road working on a business trip and didnt have my backup with me.
I am surprised by all the reports on glitches and cannot help but think that maybe the hardware or user upgrade process may be at fault.
I have upgraded my Mac Mini (late 2009) as well as Mac Book Pro (2009) and IPhone 6 - seamlessly !!!
In fact, all three are integrated beautifully and my (albeit a bit old) computers are operating faster and better than ever.
I am no Mac expert but I found the upgrade pretty simple and as usual Apple's operating system is awesome and does everything it promised.
I switched from PC to Mac about 15 years ago and I can promise you I WILL NEVER GO BACK TO PC EVER !!!
Long live Apple - I am a sucker for excellent products.
It took a long time to download/install (approx.
5 hours) but it works perfectly.
My apps open quicker now!
I am very satisfied with this new OS X update.
It's 10 times better than yosemite!
My 15" Retina Macbook Pro was rendered virtually useless within an hour of updating.
Apps would run slow, hang or fail to launch.
I gave up and rolled back to Yosemite using my Time Capsule backup but it cost me a full day and I lost one of my Parallels virtual machines in the process!
I love my Macbook Pro but not this update!
El Cap definitely focuses on refinements.
Runs faster, smoother and less crash prone over Yosemite.
I'm on a retina MBP.
I find the some of the low reviews baffling.
I guess gripers are always more prone to posting reviews.

A quick and painless update on my; (13" mid'12 MacBook pro: 2.9Ghz i7, 240GB Kingston 3K SSD, 16GB Crucial 1600Mhz Ram)Have tested over the last few hours and find it to be very responsive with no visible bugs.
Good Job!
Locks up constantly, has graphical glitches.
Hold off on this upgrade.
Very long install.
Asks for iCloud password again, takes a while to sync.
I did an extra re-boot after install and working well.
Apps open quicker.
Finally Trash has option: Delete Immediately to delete a selected item permanently.
It initially looked like a great update, but my Macbook Air has been crashing mutilple times daily since the update.
I'm constantly having to reboot, and application such as Microsoft Office don't work properly (which I absolutely need to work).
It's a big disssapointment.
Wait for the patch!
It looks great and shiny as an other apple product would, however there are so many problems it makes you wonder if this newest OS was ever even tested.
It cause a number of apps to freeze and crash upon opening, such as outlook.
For other apps, it just jam packs it with previously inexistant bugs, which has been especially prevalent with the adobe suite.
Even after reinstaling a number of apps and cleaning up their data, there is still no fix.
On the whole, this OS is great if all you do with your computer is change your background.

row.Title: iPhoto designed not to work with El Capitan

row.Sentences: Why release a product that does not work with iPhoto?
Maybe Apple could have warned users!
Here is an example Apple can use next time:"iPhoto does not work with El Capitan.
Do you want to continue with the installation of El Capitan?
"Why do inexperienced users have to figure out how to fix Apple's short comings?
I use computers as a tool not as a hobby!
Has Apple lost its way without Steve Jobs?

row.Title: I had to revert to Yosemite

row.Sentences: I did a clean install.
The OS looks like it has nice new features but my macbook pro (mid 2012) became so slow it was unusable.
I reverted to Yosemite for now and will wait for 2-3 updates to make sure most bugs are eliminated before trying El Capitan again.
Photos.app remains weak due to inability to "Edit with External Editor" and lackluster API.
NIK will not develop Photos Extensions; Pixelmater only has "distort" extensions and RawHide can not develop for Photos.app with this API.
Basic Preferences like crop aspect ratio are missing.
App is reduced to a mobile app on a Mac.....a real step backwards from iPhoto's External Editor and Aperture.

row.Title: this software literally made my computer useless..

row.Sentences: I have an early 2011 macbook pro.. its super fast.. well.. until I loaded El Crapitan on it..
I see the spining wheel all the time now almost non stop..
I have tried both updating or clean install.

I have replaced a new solid state drive.. etc.... nothing works.. on all my computers.... (of the same year and I have 9) it continues to give these issues for some time now even after indexing for spotlight has been completed.. HORRIBLE OS that and my printer.. which has worked in the last version STOPPED WORKING DUE TO NO DRIVER SUPPORT.. yet.. when I installed the one from the USB that came with the printer.. wow it worked.. this software is horrible and does not really bring anything new..
Ever since downloading it I have had nothing but problems when it comes to printing from preview.
After upgrading from Yosemite (which I had no issues with on my MacBook Air!)

El Capitan seems to glitch on me while I am streaming video feed, the audio and video is off and while it may not be too big of a deal, sometimes it is and whole conversations are missed....i hope that there is a fix for this soon I am now using my iMac instead of my laptop for work which is running Yosemite with no audio or video feed glitches.
If you love all those features that Apple introduced in this new OS, go for it.
However, if you value the flow and the quality of OS, consider waiting.

row.Title: its ok but most tablet drivers aren't supported anymore

row.Sentences: this update is really bad for me because i NEED to draw for my schoolwork.
my tablet is as good as garbage right now since my tablet isn't working, and who knows when wacom will release an update.
do not download if you are a digital artist like i am

experiencing more random crashes mostly around Office products....sometimes leading to severe hangs ....as I cannot remove the battery for hard-hard-resets, playing with power button eventually gets me out.
great desktop experience, better performance
I hate this update.
Where the did my right side page thing go ??
I used to scroll with 3 fingers and get it but its gone.
Also the new iPhoto is terrible its so ugly i want the old one back.
I hate updates and I would have never gotten it if i didnt extremely need to to download something for school.
Doesn't down load at all my message is and error occurred but apparently its down loaded.
Ran virus scan guess what appeared you guessed it OS X so I deleted it.
I don't understand it I have had my Mac Book pro for three years pretty updated version right?
I have never had a problem till now, not only that iPhoto won't update tells me that it can't be found come back later so I did still won't up date.
I have always looked at the reviews and thought well it was mixed and well since I didn't have trouble on the last few updates I went ahead wished i didn't do it.
I don't know what else isn't working yet.
Sure praying that You people at Apple get the next up grade out fast.

Well I think I figured out what the problem was it has to do with the El Capitan update instead of the usual way it loads this time I had to go into the dash board while I was looking for something else I noticed the update just had to be uploaded into my Mac.

So I click on the icon and it began down loading the update so far its fast now however I still can't get an update for the IPhoto no biggie there I don't mind it at this point but it would be nice if it would up date on other hand I shpuld go see if it loads the same way.
This new operating system is relatively easy to install and does work almost as well as advertised.
However, ever since El Capitan has been on my iMac, my Mail app keeps crashing, upwards of 4 or 5 times in a row.
Could Apple please be kind enough to issue a patch for that problem, since it is rather annoying, not to mention counterproductive for the self-employed person that I am?
Thanks in advance.
Secure empty trash needs to come back!
I had a coincidental hard drive crash (where the SMART status failed to warn me) and thought that El Capitan had failed.
But after a new hadr drive, El Capitan imported the last Time Machine backup perfectly.
While I do NOT like the candyland look of these last two O/S at least in dark mode it's tolerable (in the over bright mode, I end up with migraines).
Pretty solid - if ugly - release.
I feel like Summer has returned with the ever-present beach ball that seems to come standard with El Capitan.
Safari is much slower to load.
Spotlight has improved, but since I don't use Notes, Mail, Photos or Mission Control, there's not much here for me, other than a slower iMac.
Quite amazing.
Beautiful update that I have running on my mid-2007 iMac and my MBA early-2014 with no/no issues save only for FaceTime on my iMac mid-20017 which just closes just as t is aout to connect.
I hope it is fix with an up date, but other than that no issues and smooth as silk.
I always thought I had a quick, fast responding computer.
8gb memory with lots of HD space left.
Then can El Crapitain.

I guess it's Mac's way of telling me that it's time to move on and that I'm forced into possibly upgrading or being left with a slow poor responsive computer (unless they do some major tweeking of El Capitain).
For anybody with an iMac 2009 model, wait till they fix this software first.
Safari no longer works, everything is slow, I absolutely hate this upgrade.
And it is so difficult and onerous to revert back to Yosemite.
I have to borrow my sister's computer to do work online now!!
This update has been a nightmare for me.
Extremely buggy with no workaround or fixes.
MacBook Pro is useless to me without the ability to use preview which is just one of the many issues.

row.Title: crushes several times a day! very frustrated with the customer service

row.Sentences: After upgrading they system starts to shut down my computer unexpectadly.
I don't know how much data did I lose, but now I am working with USB key, because the next available support is in 5 days.
2500CAD, - waste

row.Title: bring back the page icons on mission control

row.Sentences: Mission control (F3) no longer groups the similar pages together and the page icons telling you what page is no longer there so you have to click on several pages until you open the one you want, ruined the whole experience for me :(

I got an old mid-2010 macbookpro and since i was on yosomite it was so slow.. even just tapping the volum button took 3 seconds before it shows the volume display -_- i wasn't really sure about passing onto El capitan for this reason.. and finally it was probably the best thing i could have done!
Everything is so smooth and fast.. i love it.... especially the split screen!

row.Title: A few bugs, but nice update overall

row.Sentences: Sadly, the new flat design is the direction it seems everyone is headed.
Still not a fan, but El Capitan has refined the UI (mostly due to the font changes) enough that I can live with it.
I only hope they will refine it further, and bring back a bit more depth and contrast.
Things like "Search' inputs, don't look like inputs so much as they look like buttons.
I think it's a mistake to mix these two paradigms up for the sake of changing to a flatter UI.
Some of the icons also have much less creativity, and depth of "detail' but I'm slowly becoming more accustomed to the colour and icon changes - though not all are for the better.
Things do look better on retina displays.

On the technical side of things, it's a nice improvement but I'm noticing graphical glitches with the new "Metal' graphics sub-system, and there are several pieces of software that need updates for better compatibility.
As far as the included apps, the biggest bug I've found within every-day usage is the Notes app.
Once you minimize it, it cannot be un-minimized without going to "show all windows", and finding the window preview then clicking to bring to front.
Other technical "bugs" or "gotchas" is the fact that double-click to minimize, or double click to zoom doesn't work across all applications.
Been this way since Mavericks, and was never like this previously - always consistent behaviour.
Overall nice update; just needs further refinement, and really wish Apple had standalone 27" 5K displays as the old Thunderbolt displays are growing old.
This OS does look noticeably better (as of course with everything in general) on a Retina display.
So far everything I use has worked fine.
Except the Mail app.
If it doesn't stop responding immediately (which is about half the time), it hangs while downloading new mail (another 20% of the time).
So around 35% of the time it works properly on the first try.
Unfortunately, I have even more trouble getting Outlook to not crash and hang and disconnect from random accounts, so I'm stuck with this unreliable, but pretty mail application.
Existing Boot Camp partition is not accessible.
An update is required.
Everything looks good so far but my Airdrop is no longer working...
I have a new Macbook Air and an iPhone 6.
Is anyone else having this problem?

row.Title: many errors on app store downloads

row.Sentences: many errors on app store downloads.
split screen is nice but why so many error messages???????????????????????????
I absosultely love Apple but I am very disapointed with this version.
Scrolling through windows is now a pain.
If you go into a holder then swipe back to the previous folder it automatally goes to the top.
So annoying when you are looking for something and now loose your place!
External hardrives are now only read only!
I found a patch to fix this; however, now I have huge files that I can not see or have disapeared.
Also the photos app almost seems independent.
If I want to email one of my photos it does not give an option to select one from "photos."
I wish I hadnt updated!

row.Title: Problems deleting cache from Trash Can

row.Sentences: Once in a while I delete accumulated cache from my library.
I now can't delete the cache from the Trash Can, consistently claims its "in use".
Never had this problem before the upgrade.

row.Title: Improves performancejust takes forever to download lol

row.Sentences: As soon as the download is finished I'll tell you how awesome the update was, and how it is totally worth the.... well it's telling me 24hrs to wait with a 32G ram, 3T drive and i7 processor brand new iMac 2015???....
hmmm, now i know its 6 gigs but wow 24hrs???
is that a long time?....
cu tomorrow pffft :-( ***UPDATE*** So actual DL time was more like 6hrs all in, and it seems to work fine :) in fact my iMac seems faster.... so I'm upgrading from 3 to 4 stars!
I think the bugs have more to do with microsoft programs so toss out your antiquated DOS PC and get an iMac, problem solved!!!
BTW.... the new update is awesome.... totally worth it lol, sorry i doubted you Apple :P
Downloaded and updated from Yosemite, this was a mistake.
There are too many driver issues right now.
Printer stopper printing (worked yesterday), USB keyboard stopped inputting correctly.
Calculator randomly erased my numbers.
Mail was a disaster.
Wait until a future update is released that addresses these major issues.

row.Title: DO NOT UPGRADE IF YOU RUN ADOBE CC!!!!!!

row.Sentences: Well here's a complete boondoggle from the folks at Adobe and Apple.
Turns out that the Adobe CC apps don't play nice with 10.11....ooooops, sorry about that says Adobe.
Apparently no one thought to do any Q/A work to see if this major release from Apple would cause any grief.....again, "ooooops!"
says Adobe.
Bottom line- if you are running Adobe CC and actually want your apps to work, DO NOT UPGRADE.
It would seem that the issue is resolved in 10.11.1 (BETA)...

row.Title: New interface looks great, but slower than Mavericks
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Outlook, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: I upgraded from Mavericks to El Capitan - skipped Yosemite because of all the negative reviews.
I am pleased to report everything went smoothly with the download and install process.
I had some initial problems with Outlook 2011 email locking up, but this seems to have cleared itself after I dowloaded the latest updates from Microsoft.
I'm dissapointed with iPhoto no longer being available - it is greyed out, so I can't open it anymore.
Some of my apps were a little slower, particulalty when launching for the first time after the upgrade, but they seem ok now, or I have just got used to it.
Overall, I am pleased with the update and the new look.
Macbook Air 13 (6,2) with Intel Core i5 1.4GHz (early 2014), 8GB RAM
Yosimite was a step in the right direction with closer links to iOS, El Capitan builds on that and also brings significant perfomance enhancements.
My late 2012 Macbook Pro is performing smoother and more reliably since the update.
Now if Apple could only fix iOS9 performance the say way it would be computing nirvana.

row.Title: macbook pro retina 15 update to Os x el capitan ver.10.11

row.Sentences: anyone here Os x EL capitan????

experiencing like a dead pixel on the left side a straight solid vertical line from top to bottom ,since the new el capitan update my Photoshop cs6 glitches too ,picture doest show when i try to (+) zoom it.

row.Title: do not download if everything is well with Yosemite

row.Sentences: I tried to download El Captain but the download was interrupted and when I tried to resume it, it got stuck on "waiting".
I had to delete it from the launchpad in order to clear it from that status.
I have read it is a common problem many encountered when downloading it.
I am just thankful nothing crashed.
I won't be upgrading any time soon.

row.Title: Crashed my harddrive, had to format and lose everything

row.Sentences: The update is great and looks very smooth.
However, I wish that in order to get the update I wouldn't have had to format my entire harddrive since the OS X wouldn't install.
Thanks for making inferior products with future obsolescence in mind.
A great little update that enchances the overall feel and function of Macs OS X.
so laggy on my macbook pro 13in, and no update till now to fix or even to improve it!
The most irritating update I've ever made.
Wish I hadn't.
So many extra fixes I had to make with other applications.
Internet and overall speed of my MacBook is about 25% slower.
I upgraded from Maverick which I liked.
The shock I got when I discovered iPhoto was no more.
What a stupid idea was that?
Oh but I can use third party extensions in Photos which I also need to download and pay for.
Very disappointed in Apple's direction.
You are not able to do serious work after the death of Steve Jobs!!!!
OS X Yosemite and OS X El Capitan are your worst versions.... we don't need visual enhancement but we want you fix the errors...
Mail update continuous error loop.
Could not get rid of dialogue box2.
Can't sign into my icloud account anymore (there are lots of threads of others having this issue)3.

Whenever I reboot, I have to set up icloud, keychain, accept terms etc.... each and every timeThese are all errors found within the first 10 minutes of using the new OS, can't wait to see what else pops up.
Hopefully an update coming real soon.

row.Title: Not compatible with Quark XPress 10!
row.Topic: Compatibility, El_Capitan, N/A, Outlook, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: If you are work with graphic designing programs, don't upgrade to El Capitan!
This operating system does not support Quark XPress 10 or higher.
I had to downgrade to Quark 9.5 to complete an urgent project.
For the first 2 weeks, I could not run Microsoft Outlook 2011 either.
Only today there was an update available that seem to fix MS 2011 crashing issues.
In regards to Adobe, I have only worked with Illustrator and Photoshop, they seem to be working fine.
Remember that you can't downgrade El Capitan, unless you have a time machine backup or reinstall your downgrade version from scratch.

row.Title: longer then expected, but otherwise smooth

row.Sentences: the update took longer then expected to install but, otherwise simple and flawless update.
El Capitan installed fine on my Late 2012 iMac (3.4GHz Intel Core i7).
However, I notice that it runs a little slower than OS X Yosemite did, which is disappointing.
Finder windows switch a little slower, I can actually see the graphics progress with a slight latency rather than the instant flip from one Finder window to the next as before.
Would be nice if Apple could find out what's causing this and make it as fast as its predecessor.
The 'shaking mouse pointer' in El Capitan is a nice addition to OS X, however.
You shake it with your mouse and you can suddenly see where it is because it becomes bigger.

Problems saving photos: Next, for the longest time, I've noticed that Preview (the feature in OS X that allows the viewing of photos and images in Finder windows), has a bug in it that Apple has consistently ignored and never fixed for years now.
I click on a photo in the web browser (whether Safari or Firefox) to save it and Preview always activates, of course.

The save options are confusing and if you dare to change the filename of the image and forget to add the extension (.jpg, .png, .pdf, etc), you end up saving an image without any extension at all and it can't be viewed properly on your Mac later.
Really frustrating.

(Contrast this to Windows where everything is automatic and easy, you simply save whatever file or image it is without bother with the extension and Windows automatically adds the right extension for you so that there are never any problems later.)
How many years has this problem gone on?
Too many years to count.

Themes, colors, backgrounds, screensavers and sounds in OS X: I grew up on Windows 98 and then XP before I switched to the Mac and I got used to the wonderful choice in the way to add different sound effects to all the different functions in the Windows OS.

The ones that come in OS X are pathetic and distracting, I'm forced to turn the entire sound SFX feature off instead of being allowed the choice of adding quiet yet cool-sounding ones from a nice palette as Windows always had.

Another feature in Windows that I miss are the great variety of screensavers that I could choose (my favorite was the aquarium), in OS X there are only a few and most of them are not worth looking at.
Only the photo slideshow screensaver and the plasma-arc are any good.
I want more and better.
Finally, I want to change the colors and backgrounds of the headers and backgrounds of the Finder windows so that I don't have to look at grey upon grey all the time.
Way too boring and kind of depressing, really.
(*And I want the choice of turning my iMac's screen into a night-view option so that it's easier on the eyes, just like I can on my iPad using the iBooks app.
There should be a range of different screen fonts/background colors for this so I can turn Finder windows on the Mac into something less harsh on the eyes at night or in a darker room.
And the apps like Microsoft Word and Pages should match this as well if possible.)
There should be a lot more choice in this as well as the choice in color of the fonts in them too, as long as it's readable in whatever colors you choose.

I don't know how long OS X has remained without these kinds of obvious features that Windows users have long enjoyed but it's about time OS X at least matched this ability a little, or more preferably, made options for this even *better* than what Windows has always offered.

That way Apple can make OS X look even *cooler* and flashier than anything you'd ever see in Windows, right?Finally, in a minor suggestion, give OS X's Calendar App the same option for software developers and users to insert photos/artwork there the same as big paper calendars have, with the option to use the photos/artwork in the screensaver too.
The calendar can then be turned into a screensaver itself, a different photo or artwork for each day of the week with all your calendar notes overtop.
Album artwork is already included in the iTunes music store for each album for sale, why not offer high-resolution, full-screen calendar art with the Calendar app, it just makes sense, doesn't it?
(I've got more suggestions, a lot more, but it's a start.)
No support for WD My Cloud will not open in finder.
This is the best OS X yet, it is the Snow Leopard of Yosemite.
Keep up the good work Apple!
My recent update to El Capitan went smoothly and in general I am delighted with the overall upgrade.
Ever since I updated I immediately had a Jave dialogue box jumping onto my screen every 3 hours or so.
It says "To use the Java command line you need to install a JDK" and then a prompt to visit the Java web site.
So to get rid of this I followed the link and installed the updated Java.
Everything works fine however the update did not get rid of this nuisance dialogue box and nothing I do in the Java settings can get rid of this.
Please address this in a future El Capitan update.
Removes my back up drive (using Time Machine and external drive) whem IMac awoken frim sleep.
Sends this message "Disk not Ejected Properly"Eject "La Cie" before disconnecting or turning it Off"I have done nothing to the back up drive
My Mail program won't stay open for more than 10 seconds before crashing.
Not to mention now forced to use the useless photos app (I miss IPhoto).
I upgraded to see if it would make my computer faster and it's just as slow as ever.
I just installed on my MacBook Pro Late 2011.it's running great so far.

row.Title: Perfected under the hood.
row.Topic: Compatibility, Feature, Mail, N/A, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: We all know some of the features are a long time coming, and certain other operating systems have been utilizing these features for ages.
But the real accomplishment here is the performance.
The system optimization is incredible, everything is snappy and responsive.
Graphics are rendered faster, and more efficiently, and the little things you wished would be addressed in Yosemite finally are.
Compatibility issues are cropping up occassionally, but updates are to be expected.
I initally thought the growing cursor thing was the dumbest idea I've ever seen on a Mac....until my friend pointed out his 2 27" displays....yeah, ok, it's a good idea then.
Type face looks more polished, and the list of new features isn't that long, but it's essentially a perfected Yosemite, which is just great.
Here are some issues I've encountered and solved:Mail - my signatures were in there, but they wouldn't appear in a new message.
I copied the original signature, removed all of them from the list, and then added a new signature and pasted.
Logic/Garageband 3rd party plug-ins - some of them don't work, in part or at all, but they all work in their stand-alone players.
Not really a solution, but I'm sure updates are coming.
So far, these are the only major ones.
Personally, if you're having problems with your apps....well that's the risk you take when you upgrade to a brand new OS, so if you weren't prepared for it, it's your own fault.

row.Title: Upgrade crashes - can only restore from TimeMachine

row.Sentences: Tried to upgrade on both a Mac Mini and an iMac running 10.9.5.
Both upgrades crashed out to installer log and a dialog saying OSX could not upgrade, leaving the machines in an endless cyle of rebooting and failing.
Finally had to restore from TimeMachine.
Tried downloading and upgrading 4 times, on two different networks - no dice.
On the phone with support for an hour - they could not figure it out.
IF YOU TRY TO UPGRADE - MAKE SURE YOU HAVE A DECENT TIMEMACHINE BACKUP.
I'll wait until the first update to try again.
This version is a hot mess.
Makes me wonder what has happened to Apples QA...
installed but disappointed.
All my music drivers doesnt work anymore!

row.Title: crashes all the time macbook pro 15inch mid2015

row.Sentences: Since the update to El Camino, my mid2015 macbook crashes all the time.
Frequently when i open the lid, everything seems to bug and I end up having to force quit my macbook witch I really don't like to do.
Programs and Apps are in general allot longer to open, biggest difference was with Diablo3, witch prior to the update started up in a matter of seconds, and now takes remarkably longer.
All in all this is the first time I don't like a OS update, especially after having bought a new macbook pro 15inch.
I hope that Apple comes out with a OS update to fix certain of these problems.

row.Title: Brought my 2009 MacBook Pro back to life

row.Sentences: Yosemite had rendered my MacBook pro fully upgraded settings to basically useless.
Upond updating to El Capitan, it seems I am back to optimal preformance.
Thank you apple for ressurecting my wonderful MacBook.
The new OS seems to have serious issues with the new Office suite.
Word can't save to .pdf and Excel crashes frequently and although it claims to have saved latest input, it has not.

row.Title: OS X El Capitan: Be careful Canadians, iPhoto application upgrade not available in Canada

row.Sentences: Be VERY careful Canadians!!
OS X El Capitan requires Photo 9.6.1 upgrade to allow access to iPhoto photographs.
Apparently 9.6.1, released March 19, 2015, is "not available in Canada at this time" How long must Canadians wait???
?After upgrading to OS X El Capitan I am unable to access, or even view, ANY of my 2,000+ photos!
The response to my repeated attempts to download the required iPhoto 9.6.1 upgrade is always "This item is not currently available in the Canadian Store."
I can not find any way to resolve this and have no idea when the required 9.6.1 upgrade, released March 19, 2015, will be available in Canada.
The revised Safari Bookmarking system is, in my opinion, ten steps backward.
I sincerely wish I had NEVER upgraded my beloved iMac to El Capitan
the desktop picture is white.
but when i zoom out of desktop i can see my desktop picture.
can anybody help me fix it.
I decided to to try EI Capitan.
It does run a little faster and load quicker, but there are some serious problems with the programming.
After install I backed up my internal SSD and then I tried to install EI Capitan on my PCI raid card and it crashed and totally messed up my raid card.
So I tried to restore my system from a previous back-up only to find my back-up was totally messed up and had to be reformated.
Fortunately I had cloned my drive onto a removable disc just incase of problems.
after about 10 hours of messing around, I finally got all my discs reformatted and my system restored.
It seems that apple has put in programming into El Capitan that like it if your computer is highly modified.
I have a late 2012 Mac Pro that El Capitan registered as an intel computer because of the modifications.
Modes such as 2 terabite aftermarket PCI raid card with 2 samsung SSD cards, a GTX 980 sc CPU and 3.46 CPUs just for starters.
So if your Mac is modified it would be better to wait until all the bugs are fixed and until apple realizes that alot of people modify there Macs.

row.Title: Working great with late 2011 Macbook Pro 13"

row.Sentences: I was a little concerned about how this would work with my older laptop, but after reading reviews on improved speed with even older models, I decided to give it a try.
A little slow at first, but once I opened most apps once, the speed is great!
Feels like I got a new laptop and I'm loving the new features with Messages and split screen!

row.Title: 2012 MBA Battery Life decreased by almost half

row.Sentences: This OSX drains battery (7-8 hours to 3-4 hours).
Some people doesn't have this problem.
I'm going back to Yosemite
Unfortunately ,I downloaded El Capitan for upgrade from Yosemite.
After doing so ,I couldn't restart my computer and the hard drive stopped spinning.
I restored from time machine back again to Yosemite .and tried to re install El Capitan ,but same problem.
Now I had to restart from command-r sequence and went back to LION !!!!!
Don't upgrade if things are working well
After the Yosemite disaster, how could I be stupid enough to upgrade again?

It is pretty hard to find anything good about this upgrade.- Every time you do anything, the spinny beachball replaces the mouse for 30-45 seconds.- photos freezes almost every time you open it- mail crashes if it runs for more than 2 hours at a time- most apps go to "not responsponding' when you quit them so you have for force quit constantly- you have to reboot every 1-2 hours or the os freezes and can't recover- when I tried to sync my previosly functioning Iphone 6s, it hangs while it tries to sync photos, but the photos are synced to the iphone- every time the computer sleeps, when it wakes it can't see the thunderbolt display, and you have to disconnect and reconnect- when you connect the thunderbolt display, application windows move off the screen and the only way of getting to them is to repeatedly connect and disconnect until they re-appear on a screen- battery life has gone from 4-5 hours to 1-2 hours- 25% of the time, when the computer sleeps, it wakes up the spinny beach ball and freezes - you have to hold down the power button to get it to reboot- not sure if this is a MS problem or just another Apple screw up - MS office doesn't work.
in 2011, Outlook is incompatable with the os, and word and excel can only open once out of 10 times you try to open them.

Office 2016 runs great and supports the new split screen function, but you can't quit the apps - they freeze and you have to reboot to get the computer to run again (force quitting just quits the apps, but the computer doesn't work).
Excel can only run for 10-15 minutes at a time before it freezes and the only fix is a reboot.

The only positive things I can see so far:- reboot is faster than with Yosemite - and that is a good thing because I do that more than I do anything else on the computer.- the spit screen function is great.
Finder received some modifications, it is apparent, because its glitchy, and has a hard time recognizing connected servers, or connecting to them at all.
Pretty new colors dont mean much when you lose on productivity.
With the latest few iterations of mac osx it is clear that Apple has forgotten about their die hard, power users, and system / network admins running their software.
Sure they have all these new features that make continuity between mac and, well, your iphone as ill never use one, better.

and very minor visual changes they actually try to call a "Feature" for the most part all of the new "Features" with the exception of split view and Metal (which wont be supported fully by devs for a WHILE) are really just stripping down our old pre existing features, giving them a paint job and calling it new and better, because.... theres less?
lets take mission control.
I fail to see how making me mouse over my virtual desktops to see a preview is an upgrade.
I now have to do more work to get the same info, what about when i just need to grab a quick glance at a script's progress?

Now things get real(-y unusable) For a minor amount of added security, that only protects the most basic of users who click yes to everything and blindly allow maleware to be directly given access to root, power users like myself can no longer get access to OUR OWN SYSTEM FILES.
Meaning I can't even modify the required custom software to gain access to MY server or remote terminals as i NEED direct access to /system /usr/bin which I no longer have.
This is now the third iteration in a row.
That's three years straight i've been excited to run an update.

and have reverted (painfully thanks to older problems with manditory online access during os install) back to OS X 10.8 to have a stable system, with enough legacy support, and enough current support (also slipping now.....) to call it a viable Desktop operating system.
Guys.... Windows 10, isnt actually too bad.
Get back on your game Apple.....
But pretty disapointed in the fact that splitview is ONLY for apple programs....
Everything is running faster after a second boot up.
However, most of the features in "Disc Utility" is non functional and trash can no longer has "Secure Delete Feature"
Prior to downloading this update, I read some of the comments.
I found that it downloaded, installed with no real problems.
The few times it slowed down caused me to worry, as some of the negative feedback I read caused my concern.
However, just letting Apple do what it needs to do, and it works great.
I am running an iMac Late 2009.
Works just fine.
Since installing it kernal panics my mac pro.
I have also done a clean install with no data restoration,still crashes.
USB audio support for changing the volume is gone even though this has been an issue since early in the beta.
Greatly improved battery life!
Only issue so far is that Trusteer Rapport is not yet supported.
Installed this with no issues, up until I started using more than one application at a time.... resulting in the comupter crashing every time.
Thank god I had an OSX Yosemite backup file, and reinstalled that.
Not one crash since the reinstall of Yosemite.
El Capitain is simply great.
This is Yosemite with all the stuff they had to fix so it's awesomeGood move by Apple.
Works well on my macbook and on my Imac
The wifi connection randomly freezes.
And the preview ocassionally crushes.
Please fix these problems.
I am away from home and my MacBook freezes.
Sometimes I can reboot and run for a short time, other times it flashes a folder with a question mark.
A few hard restarts and it will run for awhile.
I cannot download a fresh instal.
Stuck with a failed install waiting for an update.
BTW, why do I have to swipe from Dashboard instead of just clicking on the layout behind?
Very good, I don't generally write reviews.
All lagginess of Yosemite is gone.
However Apple's 30 min of instalation as it appears on screen is really 1.5 hrs.
You need patience with some Chocolates and coffee.
Good Luck.
I have an older MacBook Pro (4,1) on which Yosemite runs very well; enough so that I favour it over the slightly faster OS it originally came with.
Downloaded El Capitain to a seperate volume and have been playing with it.
It appears to work as well as Yosemite except for laggardly mouse scrolling (some apps) ) which forgets its settings each time I log out.
Disk Utility is next to impossible to use as the pie-chart style of partitioning is awkward compared to the rectangular layout of its predecessor.
Still don't care for the inspid grey sidebar graphics which cannot be changed on El Capitain as they can on other OS's back to Lion.
It's back down to the Yosemite valley for me.
Not sure what new features there were in this new OS, but after I installed it, I've been experiencing new problems that hadn't occurred before with Yosemite.

There's a lot of lagging, such as my notification bar getting stuck halfway until closing, I've had times when I couldn't just slide my pop-up notifications to the side with 2 fingers, other problems when I've tried to click something with just a touch to the touchpad but it wouldn't respond so I'd have to click elsewhere then try again, and the continuity of the notes between my macbook and my iPhone is not where it use to be, to the point where I am worried about losing work that I typed up on my phone because it won't transfer to my pro and the edit will be overridden by a previous version instead.
All mainly small things, and the main problem in general is lagging, but it has really affected the ease of my everyday usage and regularly used functions.
Hopefully an update will smoothen things out.
I just downloaded the new software update and so far so good.
I was a little hesitant to download this update because of all the bad review the last software (yosimite) update had; thus, I had mixed feelings about this software update.
SO far so good.

row.Title: Works great on a 2007 MacBook Pro

row.Sentences: Even on an old system, it runs very smoothly.
The split screen function alone makes it an outstanding update.
Text looks smoother too.
The new drawing engine looks great on my 17" screen.
All in all, a brilliant update years ahead of anything Microsoft has to offer.
Please fix split screen for Microsoft Word because its window completely freezes.

row.Title: Rock Solid Update
row.Topic: Backup, Download, Feature, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update

row.Sentences: I've been using apple products for many years now, and I have to say this was a very smooth update.
It downloaded and installed without any issue.
I haven't had any problems with compatiblities, crashes etc.
A much better release in terms of ease, compared to Yosemite.
While it does add a few new features(I love having two apps open in full screen on the same screen), it feels more like fixes for Yosemite, to be honest, making it run extremely well.
I did notice there is a slight delay now before my desktop icons appear, compared to before, though, but that's about it.
If you are considering updating, do yourself a favour and BACKUP FIRST!
While my experience was smooth, yours may not be - sometimes there are software compatibilities issues and it's better to be safe with that backup!
It may also be a good idea to do a verify disk with disk utilities first (on your startup drive, to make sure there's no file system errors on your hard drive.
One other issue I've noticed is if you pause the download, it won't unpause correctly sometimes.
If you have this problem, go into Launch Pad, hold your mouse on the icon until it starts to wiggle (iOS style), and X it out.
You can then start your download again.
OS X El Capitan is an okay update.
I didn't really see much difference compared to Yosemite.
Safari is a bit slower and whenever I try to save files the saving window pop up freezes.
Please fix this issue!
I prefer using Safari over other browsers.
Now, I can't edit for my blog because every time I save a photo, the pop up freezes.
When software is downloaded (6+ Gigs) you lose I PHOTO and I MOVIE pics,movies and all.
There are no updates for the canadian market as of yet.. Super frustrating!
I forgot to time machine my Photos and Movies, thats my Bad ;(

row.Title: DO NOT UPDATE IF YOU USE OUTLOOK

row.Sentences: The operating system itself is great, BUT, if you use Microsoft Outlook, do not update.
It will not work with El Capitan....
I didn't think to look into this before updating and now it is completely unusable.
A Google search will confirm this.
Apparently, Microsoft is working closely with Apple to create a fix, but have not yet released a solution.
As a long time Mac user (10+ years), I have to say that I'm very pleased with the overall functionality of El Capitan.
I have an early 2009 MacBook, which is one of the oldest MacBooks to still be eligible to upgrade to El Capitan.
It originally came with Leopard, which I then upgraded to Snow Leopard, with which I was very pleased.
Later on, I upgraded to Maverick, seeing as it was free.
I was not at all impressed with the performance of my MacBook once I had upgraded to Maverick but it wasn't bad enough for me to downgrade back to Snow Leopard.
I decided to give El Capitan a try seeing as the reviews on performance on older machines were good and so far I'm very pleased.
It's still the same OSX that we all love with a refreshed look, a few new features and overall improved performance.
Kudos to you Apple ;)
The overall visual flow is improved.
However, since I have installed El Capitan, I have been having problem with mail.
More specifically, when I single click on a mail, the rest of the e-mail should normally pop up on the right side space.
I have to go to the web version of the e-mail provider to view the rest of the message.
It's a small issue, but it is quite annoy.
If Microsoft had a secret wish, El Capitan would be it.
This upgrade is so reminiscent of the clutter that Microsoft had millions endure with their Windows operating systems it's almost deja'vu.
If you've had any problems with Yosemite, download and install El Capitan, it's sure to be an enlightening experience.
Your Outlook will stop to work!
Wait until they fix this version.

row.Title: lots of problems list all mail from pop/server Yahoo/Rogers

row.Sentences: I know a lot of positive comments have been made BUT I have to say it has been one ( mess here.
I did the upgrade and had it hang/stall several times.
it cleared all my mail accounts and calendars.
it has taken hours to get most thing reset and i dont know what I have lost totally.
I have been at the apple store 2 day to get it resolved.
I lost most my Yahoo mail.
I have spent hours on this clean up.
TOTAL MESS!!!!!!
I downloaded it multiple times, even with a restart.
All i get is a message "error has occurred'.
I have a 1 year old iMac running Yosemite.
I'm thrilled to finally have the split window option (wish it was sooner though).
When I open just a single image in preview, where the image would be located it's all green.
This does not always happen on every image however.2.
After typing my password in after opening the lid from sleep, it takes about 10 seconds to get back in, whereas previously it was instant.
If those are the only issues I encounter now, I'll be happy however.
The performance increase is significant, like an entirely new MBP!
After update, it seems i lost about 2-3 hours battery time not sure if it only happen to me or someone else also experience this issue.
Dear Apple, etc:As some PEOPLE have experienced-including me-"upgrading" to El Capitan seems to have made Safari very slow and glitchy.
Going back to Yosemite now.
I'll try again LATER.--Dave
El Capitan works great !
Very fast and smooth.
I'm very pleased with this OSX.
This is a big download.... took about an hour.
Safari is super slow now and I have pop-up ads?
?Hope things improve soon......
The upgrade was seamless, no issues at all on early 2009 iMac and 2012 Macbook Pro.
It did take a few hours so be prepared to spend some time.
It initially says 35 minutes, I have a 5ombps internet connection, total time to finish was more like 2 hours to download and install.
Much better than Microsoft Windows though!
One issue: Everytime I need to login to itunes or the app store I have to login twice.
It is like I entered the password incorrectly and I know that to be false!
I am using a password manager.
I copy and paste, access denied, I paste the same clipboard again and access granted and itunes opens.
Anybody else having this issue?So far this is the only issue I have.
The speed is greatly improved on my early 2009 iMac.
Also on my macbook pro.
Everything seems to be working much better than Yosemite and it was good!
I thought it was supposed to speed things up including the bootup time.
It did't, it slowed down and some to most apps stopped working properly.
