Why oh why are Apple unable to do software updates?I delayed my update to this OS version in the vain hope that the all the teething problems would have been sorted, but no.
Apple's own software fails to work properly, i.e.
It keeps forgetting its passwords, this problem happened on a previous OS X version, so no learning there then.
thanks apple.
downloaded from the app store.
BUT HOW DO YOU ACTUALLY INSTALL ITNO ** IT ** IS ** NOT ** OBVIOUS
High memory usage therefore slows everything down
The decission to upgrade to El Capitan came as I wanted to update my entire apple product collect to make them sync easier and so forth.
I run a business with this machine and christ on a bike is it slow!
When I first got it, it was fine, its was perfect!
Then some how seemed to slow down, my iMac now has more beach ball action than Bay Watch.
Then things really started to turn sour.
Photoshop started to lag, it would move with me, shapes would move 1 - 3 seconds after I moved them.
I use apps via my web store to print labels using download and auto open in preview.
Now preview won't even open and tells me to force quit when I right click the app icon.
I was foced to then open pdf files in safari.
So download open in finder and open with safari and print.
This has now become a problem when I click show in finder.... well its ends there.
Finder pops up, then it doesnt show the file ive just downloaded and it freezes, becomes completely unresponsive.
I cant use finder.
So now I can even do the work I am intending to do.

Apps such as pages and numbers have been popping up all week telling me an update needs to be done even though no updates are abailable for them and the most recient one was done along with the El Capitan download.
My iMac is only 10-11 months old and its slower than my 6 year old Macbook Pro.
Apple need to sort a successful dot version to resolve this and quickly too.
Lots of issues for everyone it seems.
Always been an apple fan.... but this has put me off, at leasr I have an iPad pro to see me through
I thought Yosemite was bad!
My MacBook is only a few years old and I've already had to put as much RAM in as possible!
Think I'll stick with Mavericks.
Since downloading OS X El Capitan, I can no longer use Picasa (application I have used for years now), and I only have the option to use IPhotos to import my pictures.
This is disappointing, and it seems to be an issue for many users.
Otherwhise the software upgrade is OK, but I don't really notice the difference with the earlier version.
I installed El Capitan onto my Macbook Air (2012 Version) and I have noticed no improvement in user experience.
It has slowed my system down and takes much longer to boot up from either sleep or complete power down.
I won't be installing this onto my other computers yet.

row.Title: No Major Issues Yet - Design Looks Plastic-like & Cheap!

row.Sentences: I very reluclently upgraded my 2012 MacBook Air to OS X El Capitan depsite all the negative reviews, simply because I have just purchased Adobe Creative Cloud and to install Photoshop CC 2015 I HAD to updrage.
Well, I've not experienced any major issues so far, and I've been able to install Photoshop and other software with no issues!
I've noticed a minor bug accessing one of my regular streaming websites where videos will not load what-so-ever, but I'm hopeful that this will be resolved with the next software update.
(HINT HINT APPLE)The new look is very plastic-like and looks cheap, which is a shame but not a deal breaker.

Other minor negative feedback is I have to hold the power button to bring up the shut down options rather than just pressing it which is a minor annoyance, and the lock screen looked far better before.

I took the time to read a lot of reviews before taking the plunge, and even thought the outcome was adequate in my case, my advice to those considering upgrading to El Capitan is..... Only do it if you REALLY have to!!!
Best to wait until all the bugs I fixed and the negative reviews are fewer than the possitive.
Best of luck.
After reading the negative reviews I went for it, downloaded and installed.
All went to plan no problems, however I am a professioanl photographer and use the tether function on Adobe Lightroom CC.
Imagine my shock when working at a prestigious charity event with 600 people in attendance, to find my camera wont tether anymore.
It appears that El Capitan has knocked out all Nikon and Leica cameras.
Please tell me this will be fixed and ASAP.
Very unhappy customer Apple :-(((
What is waiting Apple to correct the bugs everybody talk about since the release of El Capitan ?

USB connected devices are not recognised anymore (USB time machine, external hard drives for pictures, etc....), Mail has bugs where some address do not record proper SMTP server (need to be input every time you open mail), etc.... Quite disappointing from Apple.
Now let s see how quickly they will solve this.
This has been by far, my least enjoyable upgrade of OS X.
My apps run slowly, Mail takes forever to quit (making logging out a waiting game) and general start-up times are noticeably lengthy.
My Adobe software has all manner of issues running on El Capitan and I see Apple and Adobe pointing fingers at eachother, with no solutions in sight.
I've used a Mac since 10.2 and this has been the only time I am seriously looking at downgrading.
I love my mac but I am really starting to dislike it.
It used to work well, boot up quickly, never hang but after this last upgrade I feel like re building it with an older version of the OS.

It is not one thing but a collection of many small things that do not work, it feels laggy, it has screen redraw issues, I cannot export VPN settings, TDM does not work as well, system setting error messages that make no sense.
So my Chrismas present ask is that you fix all the issues and do not worry about a release with a funny name next year.

row.Title: Super stable and functional on a 2010 Mac Pro

row.Sentences: Nothing wrong with this upgrade at all.
It works very well and so does all my software.
I am so annoyed with el Capitan, it was a reluctant upgrade for me and a regrettable one.
ProTools not working MBox not working.
This update made my MacBook run so slowly it's practically unusable.
I would recommend staying far away from El Capitan if you enjoy being productive.
Really disappointed, Apple.
I converted from Windows to Mac in April 2015 with the iMac and was blown away.
It had Maverick installed with the update for Yosemite, so I did that straight away - absolutely amazing, no issues, everything connected and worked straight away - ace piece of kit!

Followed the progress of El Capitan and wasn't overly impressed with it, but decided to go for the upgrade anyways - not good, making my machine slower instead of faster was the biggest issue, and I didn't see any value for me in the other bells & whistles.
So, I've gone back to Yosemite and the blistering speed has returned - happy days!
I have really felt most uncomfortable with this release.
I had less trouble with Microsoft XP Pro.
The slowness, the beachball, the advice I got (even from Apple Support) which failed to resolve the problem, the failure of Superdrive to record or eject,.
The shear complexity of it all.
This is not a system for those of pensionable age who do not want to spend hours trying to resolve the unsolvable.
I am beginning to ask if there is indeed life outside my home office.
I have promised myself another 5 days.
If I cannot get the damn thing to work by then it is down to the charity shop with it, and I shall return to the arms of Dell and Microsoft.
I avoided Yosemite because of all the adverse reviews regarding wireless connectivity.
So it was with trepidation that I decided to go for El Capitan, presuaded by the iCloud drive which had made all my numbers and pages documents unavailable in my IOS devices.
Dowload was 3.5 hours over a standard copper wire broadband connection and installation was a further hour.
I ensured that everything had been shut down, wireless turned off and the download received by an ethernet connection direct from the router.
Everything works, no mail problems, no wireless problems, no connectivoty problems and speed is faster.
The sense of refief is palpable, thank you Apple.

row.Title: A point(less) upgrade. No problems, but no significant progress.

row.Sentences: I can't really describe it as a major update, it's not in practical terms.
My workflow is identical, and I forget I've upgraded.
It's not noticeably faster or slower, has no obvious benefits other than stopping the notifications to upgrade!!
I have no issues with it, but then I didn't with Yosemite in terms of crashes and the like, just the childlike design.
If this is Apple's idea of a major upgrade, we've not got far to go before the company starts to implode on the Mac side of things.
We've lost the professional look (that went with Yosemite when we moved to Fisher Price colour schemes etc) and now we've lost the progress.
Photos is not progress, it's simply making things more and more like iOS and burying any seriously useful features where editing is concerned.
Mavericks was the last time we really had solid professional progress on the Mac, and I think it will be the last time by the looks of it.
I'm adding to my review that I still feel the same after some weeks.
It's not more or less stable than Yosemite, it's hardly any different.
Staggering waste of developer time.

I was forced to upgrade from 10.9 to play a game and I desperately regret my decision even the format of websites have changed, Everything is more clunky, totally riddled with bugs, booking a flight which i did with ease in a few minutes the other night before i upgraded has turned into an absolute debacle.
Just really terrible, doesn't even look better, if anything it looks a bit cheaper, shinier and more plastic, as if it were designed for(by) a child.
it broke my wife's macbook and broke our mac mini.
even after a reinstall, the very next update breaks it again.
when i say break i mean it doesn't boot and shows a broken display.
Apple advise to always keep your software up to date.
Downloaded El Capitan, restarted my Mac, result no access to Bootcamp to run Windows OS.
Three years of work stored on that part of the partition, machines that can only run on Windows software, cannot get access to any of it.
Apple is aware of this problem and 5 weeks later still no fix!!!
Business ready to go bust.
Can only imagine how many million customers are in the same situation as myself, just hope your business isn't sufferring.
Discusted that such a major problem is not being dealt with promptly and can only simpathise with anyone in the same position as myself.
This is the second time an update has caused major problems for me.
Updated my iPhone 5s to latest OS a couple of years ago, the result of that was a sim failure.
Sim failure is no big problem but Apple made it a big problem.
Took it instore where a cough cough "genius" said my phone was damaged beyond repair as a result of the update and there was nothing they could do to fix it.
Was told to pay 136 and they would replace the handset!

Let me get this right, your software update caused a perfectly fine working phone to be rendered damaged beyond repair and I need to pay the company that caused thie problem 136 to fix this, are you serious Apple!!

I said the Apple support online told me it sounds just like a simple sim card failure and to ask the "genius" to take my sim card out and try it in another iPhone to which the "genius" replied, where am I supposed to find an iPhone to test your sim card, seriuosly "genius" we're in an Apple store and you're asking me where you're suppoed to get an iPhone from!
Complained to Apple and they made another appointment to see yet another"genius".

It was a nice young girl that dealt with me and I explained the situation and she simply took out my sim card put it in her own iPhone and confirmed it was just a simple sim card failure, put her sim card in mine and my phone worked fine!!!
So the next time you have to visit a "genius" question everything they tell you as there must be so many people getting screwed over.

Another little point this was my third replacement iPhone as the first 2 had faults which they replaced the handset because of which says a lot for the quality of their handsets, probably why you only get a 1 year warranty with Apple even although they claim to make the best phones in the world, Samsung don't claim this but they give you a 2 year warranty on their phones, good to see some companies are looking after their customers.
Ever wonder why Apple became the most profitable company in the world??!

Spotlight search is painfully slow now; everytime I try to search for something I have to wait for the 2nd internal hard disk to come to life and even then the results are certainly not what I would expect.
iOS search is much fasterSecondly, CAN YOU PLEASE CAPITALISE the letter i when I am typing-yet another thing ios can do just fine.

row.Title: took a deep breath and did it!!!! it worked

row.Sentences: fist of all i wasn't that sure because of all the bad reviews but then i noticed all the old macs had bad reviews however i just bought mine a year ago so it was fairly unused so i just hit the update button and finally it worked i will definately recommend this.
I tend to upgrade as soon as they are available.

In a nutshell there are no major issues BUT several bizarre niggles, the biggest of which is that finder now hides the most recent file off the top of the column when in column view, sorted but date modified - how I work.
This means that when trying to find a file I always have to scroll downwards to reveal that most recent file.
Another weird one: when an app opens a finder window to open a file or save a file, it now opens a window which is not in the same view that you chose normally.
I live in column mode, it open in detail view.
I upgraded my 2012 Macbook Pro to El Capitan this last week.
At first it seemed to be working better, however, after a few days it became very glitchy, as if the code of the OS had been scrambled.
It's now lagging so much in almost every task, from trying to restart, to opening basic apps like Safari.
From what was a very clean OS running well on Yosemite, this is now really lagging.
Going to have to do a full clean reinstall and wipe everything.
Apple, please sort it out.
If the OS's are supposed to slot nicely on top of each other, then please make it happen beacuse in theory that idea is fantastic, but in practice it just doesn't work effectively.
If I knew what I know today about OS X El Capitan I would have stayed with Yosemite.
In my house there are 4 Apple computers.
Two are running El Capitan, one Yosemite and another running Lion (older machine).
The ones running the older OS have no bugs or hickups whatsoever.
The other two dont even feel like the machines they used to be when on Yosemite (and they are both high spec Mac Pros).
Since upgrading to El Capitan I have nothing but trouble, Mail keeps quitting, iCloud drive not working well when trying to retrieve documents or files whilst working on Keynote, etc.
I have been with Apple since 2006 and so far this is the only OS that I have complains about.
Maybe the expectations are too high due to quality and consistency of the previous OS's....
But according to my experience, El Capitan is more like El Recluta!
Apple sort yourselves out and give us what we deserve please.

row.Title: worst thing I have ever done

row.Sentences: had my macbook for 2 years and never bothered to update in all that time and it worked perfectly, for some reason I decided it was time and downloaded El Capitan and soon as I started using it realised it was the biggest mistake I have ever made!
nothing works smoothly anymore, one program doesnt work seamlessly with another and has caused all sorts of problems.
With the update came a new iMovie which has turned a very easy to use reliable editing suite into pure ****.
managed to get hold of an old imovie but now nothing works with it, can't add images to projects or anything.
Also had major problems with safari running slow and all sorts.
My advice is stick with your old setup and avoid this so called "upgrade'

row.Title: Mail Problems and no discernible benefits

row.Sentences: Completely removed my ability to send email from 4 of my 5 accounts (including 3 business accounts).
An absolute nightmare so far, with nothing much more than a few cosmetic enhancements in return
Well it downloaded and installed in around 70 minutes.
Then there was all the confirming of passwords etc.
All mail was there and I mean all deleted mails from 2012 appeared.
Looked to be OK apart fromthe mail.
I was asked to update a few Aps.
and drivers for my printers.
Not tried thses yet.
Used it all night with Lightroom CC no problems.

Came to use my 27inch 2012 iMac this morning 27th November and was asked for my iCloud password which I dutifully put in then asked for my Apple ID and it still trying to log on to that 2 1/2 hours later.
My machine is useable so far but not convinced about this upgrade at all.
It is nowhere near as quick as it used to be or should be.
Hopefully Apple will update as soon as possible but looking at the reviews I won't be holding my breath.
Having downloaded 10.11.1 all seemed well until I tried to open mail, it spent 1 hour saying VALIDATING MAIL, no mail is a major disaster so I looked online to find others with the same problem.
I have 6 email accounts, i managed to get mail going without my major email account but when I went to reload that account all mail had disappeared.
I have seen no benefit with the latest version and now have lost 20,000 mails of significant importanceI will avoid any further upgrades until I am sure that they have it right
My Capitan download just killed my 2009 Macbook Pro.
However, I upgarded my ram to 8GB and it seems to be working fine.
If you have small amounts or older ram, just beware before you download!

row.Title: OS X EI Captin version 10.11.1 Don't Down Load

row.Sentences: OS X EI Captin version 10.11.1 Don't Down Load !
Take the over whelming advice and don't bother mesing up your mac applications !
Since Steve Jobs has sadly past away seems like Apple is passing away in it's quality !
Now I'm going to step back on the back up drive.
( DON"T DOWN LOAD YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED )
Don't know what all bad reviews are about.
Update was fast and simple and no issues at all!
Normally, I wait a few months or so before upgrading to the latest OS, but just this once, I thought, what can go wrong?
Well, at first everything looked fine.
Then I bought Corel's Particle shop plugin for Adobe Photoshop CS6, and the brushes are so slow, they are unusable.
I need to buy the latest Corel Painter, but am now thinking maybe I can't because it may not work with El Capitan.
Does anyone know if it does please?
I also had to download an update for my photoshop shortcuts, from Adobe, (and wacom tablet) as they stopped working too.
I haven't tried my Adobe Illustrator on this yet......

row.Title: 1447 Ratings of which 50% are one star

row.Sentences: 1447 Ratings of which 50% are one star, say no more
So annoyed have Logic 10 and everything thing runs so slowly, I quote a "refined experience and improved performance" is a complete load of bullsquash.
Logic 10 keeps saying "Overload" which has never happened before sort it Apple!!!

row.Title: Kills iCloud mail and previews of .NEF photo files

row.Sentences: .... without adding any benefits I've noticed.
So DON'T DO IT if you take photos or use email.
I've had so many problems running Mainstage 3 and Logic that I've had to go back to the previous OS.
Mainstage under El Capitan didn't like my audio interface, or any other that I tried.
Even updated drivers didn't work.
This upgrade has successfully slowed down the performance of my mini mac and iPad and caused applications to hang and crash.
Im seriously thinking of ,yes im going to say it "go back to microsoft'.
Is apple employing ex microsoft programmers, whats going on.
The OS used to be fast and reliable now it gets slower and more unreliable with every so called upgrade.
Well I wont be buying faster hardware to compensate for the lack of OS speed and reliability.
Stop releasing Beta versions apple !

row.Title: Makes a 5000 computer crash every day.

row.Sentences: I am running this on a 5000 Mac Pro.
On Yosemite, it was flawless.
On El Capitan, every morning when I wake the computer from sleep, it has crashed with a Kernel Panic.
As a result, I have to turn it on from the power button, which on the Mac Pro is right at the back and it's hard to see because it is flush with the IO plate.
When it starts up, it shows an annoying popup saying that the computer was shut down because of a problem.
After clicking OK, it shows you an error window and lets you submit an error report to Apple.
I submitted maybe one hundred (no joking) already and it is still doing this.
Thinking that maybe it was a buggy installation, I erased the entire machine, even the recovery partition and started from scratch installing a fresh new copy.
It was time wasted, because it still has the annoying error.
So Apple, I would like to tell you, now I know why the Mac Pro looks like a trash can, it is because it is garbage.
Will not buy another Apple product ever again.

People may read this and downvote thinking that I am over reacting but before you do that, why don't you go spend 5000 of your hard earned money and see how you feel when your computer crashes every morning?
For this price you can buy a basic new compact car in Europe.
I expect PERFECTION.

Apple loves to pretend that it is the best but Apple is just all talk and no action, it is just marketing, next time I will spend 2500 on a PC workstation and use the other half of the money to buy other stuff.
Sure, it will still have bugs but at least it will cost half the price.
If you want to charge a premium price for something then make damn sure it is flawless.
Installed El Capitane on my late 2009 iMac.
Things ran fine for a while but now my 3rd party mouse has stopped working and what is worse, I can't update software as the Aple installer refuses to launch.
It's been a long time since I have crashes on the mac, but they are back!
Seems there's more to hate with every click.

row.Title: El Capitan is like downloading a virus

row.Sentences: If you want your email sending to be disabled, Word and Excel to be constantly crashing, iPhoto to be relegated in favour of the awful iOS equivalent of Photos as well as your machine to run as slow as a constipated snail then download and enjoy.
I cannot believe that Steve Jobs would have allowed the complete wrecking of what was a visionary operating system.
What's more I haven't been able to find any new features worth having in this release for most users.
By the way Apple Support doesn't know what is going on either !
Like others who have completed ratings, I had some reservations about this update, but decided to take a chance as my version of Yosemite regularly hung.
I found the process completly trouble free, and so far have not found any apps which do not work, although initially Firefox, my preferred browser did have a hiccough or two.
The computer now does appear to be faster to load images and although the OS doesnt look significantly different, I think this was worth the update.
Just in case though you might want to backup first though
Waste of time to download, waste of time to use.
Not only do many applications no longer work but what makes a mac so sought after (i.e its beautiful design and smooth operation) is ruined with this update.
Oh Steve Jobs, why?
did I download OS X El Capitan, WHYYYYYY!?
All in all it isn't that bad.
OK, there are a few issue.
For me these are mainly to do with Adobe's Lightroom and Photoshop, neither are anything like as quick as they were previously.
Still everything else works fine, a classic first release really so looking forward to the patches that are bound to follow.
Never leave reviews really, but this has to be one of the worst decisions I made.
It completely crashed my MBP 2011 13'' from which I thought I had lost everything.
Fortunately (and I don't know how) the hard disk is ok, with all of my data.
However, the whole process took the best part of four hours to get my Mac going again.
Each OSX update has made my Mac progressively worse, and I will not be updating my iMac.
It is now even more sluggish, my emails have all gone and I now totally detest working on it.
Put it this way, my Macbook (bought in 2007 and running OS Leopard) runs quicker and is more efficient than this expensive paper weight.

As a huge advocate for buying MacBooks over Windows, unless Apple go back to proving their operating systems are not only more reliable, quicker and in general just a pleasure to use, I will not be buying another Macbook.

row.Title: Adobe Flash Player does not work!

row.Sentences: I recommend against an upgrade to El Capitan at this stage.
The current release is not bug free.
Very frustrating to see that the basic application "Adobe Flash Player" does not work anymore, which impacts many websites, including my online banking application and BBC iPlayer.
Even more frustrating to find out that Apple Genius team that is ment to help, i) did not acknowledged that there is a problem with El Capitan and ii) was not able to fix the problem.
I have never had problems before and foolishly didn't back up my computer before downloading this.
What a HUGE mistake.
My computer lasts for about 5 second intervals before doing the stupid rotating ball thing.
Plus, e-mails were all lost from the folders that were set up.

row.Title: So many problems and unable to solve them

row.Sentences: Oh, how I regret updating.
My emails via Outlook will send but I cannot receive so I am reading them on Mac mail and sending on Outlook because Mac mail won't send!
Microsoft office is not running as well; scrolling in Excel doesn't work properly because it is so slow.
Start ip anddown are so much slower.
I have been on countless forums to try and get fixes for these problems and nothing has worked.
I used to love Macs over PCs but I am now not so sure.
I have had to transfer alot of the business work onto the PC which despite taking days to download Windows 10 is at least functioning efficiently.

due to software demands i had no choice but to download the new OS and it could be the worst decision i have ever made, it makes evvvveeeeerrrrryyyyyttthhhiiinnnggg so sssslllooowwwww and why up with reversing the scroll up to down?
Don't Use This Update, I Was Rendered Unable To Use My USB Ports With Certain Hardware.
Seems apple have adopted the same mentallity as windows now by throwin gout new spoftware and getting the customer to snag it and let them know what is wrong.

i have had nothing but problems with this since installing it and to rewind is not a simple process oh no you need to be a computer programmer to do this and have additional kit to do it not everyone has a spare external dirve to use.
Thanks to you i have no skype and any other of the spps loaded from your store that use a camera no longer work cheers.
How about putting out a fix for this terrible update which is a step backwards.
Try using Google there are reports all over it showing all the faults!!!!!!!!

row.Title: Even Worse Than I Expected
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I held off on updating from Mavericks to Yosemite, after reading the poor reviews, and held off updating again when El Capitan was released for a similar reason.
A couple of days ago though, on a whim, I decided to "make the move' as I was a bit wary of running an OS two releases out of date.
I wish I hadn't!
* Startup on my 11" Macbook Air used to be almost instantaneous.
Now I have to watch a progress bar crawling along for about three times as long, before I even see the login screen* Messages has completely messed up.
My conversations from each person have split up into multiple conversations and I've had to manually add back in the user pics, as all had vanished.

* The ability to customise the speech bubble colours has now been removed as a preference and isn't even "hackable' as the CSS file which controls it is in one of the directories protected by System Integrity Protection and can't be changed or over-ridden by the user "WTF?!
* Disc Utility has been dumbed down to the point of being almost useless.
Reports directory error but seems unable to fix it* The OS interface is awful.
The icons are horrible and pointless washed out gradients on window title bars keep making me think there's something wrong with my monitor, or my screen is dirty.
* On the plus side, at least I haven't experienced any slow-downs yet and El Capitan isn't quite so useless at finding other computers on my network as Mavericks was.
Overall I'd say, if you're still on Mavericks and it's working for you, there's no reason to "upgrade'.
Users of Yosemite might as well take the plunge as.... welll.... it could hardly get any worse, could it?
Ill try and keep this simple.
So far so good nearly.... its early days though.
The general speed of my 2 Duo 8g mid2009 macbook pro following the update to El Capitan from Mavericks is the best its been since Snow Leopard.
However there are one or two apps which it has broken that i need to update etc.
The biggest problem for me has been doing the switch over from I Photo to Photos app.

Basically i Managed to get I photo back working after the instaul through updating on the app store but when i realised that it no longer supported i cloud sharing i attempted to set up Photos app and import my I photo Library.
For some reason or another i was unable to import as there was an issue with the permissions on the system library folder blah blah blah.
So ive give up with it for now and carried on using i photo.
Apart from that all good!
Fonts wont load, Indesign takes an age to open a file.
Split screen only works with a few apps (not CC)

row.Title: A few niggles, but overall an excellent update

row.Sentences: Pros:- Love the new look- Late 2012 MBP feels much quicker & more responsive- Updating has actually freed up hard drive space- (Almost) everything "works"Cons:- A few irritating bugs - migration of calendars fails & needs a manual fix; flagged mail not re-instated; contacts not displayed properly in Messages
i cant tether connect to Adobe Lightroom 6 and after reading online its some problem with OS X El Capitan
This update completely trashed my mac, had to wipe the hdd and restore from time machine.
During installation it took ages, restarted then only ever got to about 90% on the progress bar.
I left it for hours and althouigh eventually showed 100% on the progress bar still wouldn't boot.
Come on Apple get your act together!
Updated with loads of other apps in early October.
After updates neither Cubase 8 or my Lexicon U42 S I/O worked.
I use both for for recording.
Hoped that patches would appear but after 6 weeks decided enough was enough.
Fortunately I was able to use Time Machine to revert back to Yosemite.
Couldn't recommend El Capitan right now.
Please, just dont do it, what has happened to Apple always so reliable, but now, O dear!

row.Title: It's Not Apple finest work
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, Mail, N/A, Performance, Safari, Speed

row.Sentences: I applied (was going to say upgraded) 10.11.1 about 5 weeks ago and have been struggling with a number of issues ever since.
Primarily anything connected to the internet seems slower and in some instances a number of errors have occurred most in connection with file operations and iCloud.
Safari seems a lot slower especially if you use google so switching to bing does help.
Side by side an IOS device way outperforms this OSX version when compared together.
Mac mail does crash more regularly and I have had a mail crash cause a complete reboot of this Mac Book Air something I have never had before.

Wifi has had issues but then it did with Yosemiti I have deleted and reinstalled the wifi in system preferences and the wifi connecting did work much better after that which got me to thinking that perhaps the only way to apply this version is through a fresh install!

It's a shame because we all like Apple products but more work needs to be done to improve the performance of this product in the meantime I will consider using the OSX recovery feature and wait for a more rounded fix to the issues many have described.

I had held off upgrading since I'd read of so many problems and my Yosemite installation was working well (MacBook Air), but I decided to take the plunge, based largely on the increasing number of positive reviews.
The installation worked flawlessly and I was straight into my familiar desktop.
I will add more if I encounter difficulties with apps, but I wanted to post something immediately to reassure other waverers, of whom there are likely to be many.
I have test-run a few key applications, and all run well and open noticeably quicker than under Yosemite.
So far I am very happy.
Expected the worst upgrading my Core 2 Duo 4GB MacBook of 5 years but it all works fine.
All the Apps I was using are compatible.
Only thing now I need to spend time learning about the OS features and how to use them :)
Installed this wretched thing.
Half of my e-mail messages dsappeared.
Keyboard freezes and lags behind.
Calculator types 0 instead of 9.
This upgrade is outright criminal.
Can no longer see my camera (fuji x100t) when plugged in as a drive, yet I can transfer the files with this rubbish photo app....
I used to transfer my files direct to an external HDD for storage before editing in photoshop/lightroom.
I am now unable to write to my external HDD.... What a joke of an operating system.
How apple thinks they could get away with this is beyond me.
Will not remain, will not return.
Since the days of Panther I had always been an early adopter of OS X upgrades and I had been running Leopard on my old iBook G4 PPC for the past few years.
And then I recently bought a new MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015); 2.9 GHz Intel Core i5 and 8 GB 1867 MHz DDR3 RAM running Yosemite.
After reading so many negative reviews about El Capitan I decided to wait a while but then curiosity got the better of me and I decided to take the plunge.
The download took a while because of my slow internet connection but the installation of El Capitan took about 45 minutes if that.
I have had no problems whatsoever with any Apple software or third party software.
As other reviewers have noted El Capitan is more evolution than revolution - my Macbook works as well as it did when I took it out of the box.
So, for me at least, this has been a painless and trouble free upgrade.
Thanks Apple.
I was doing some work and I paused the download.
It is not allowing me to resume the download?
Being an Mac user since OSX 10.4 aka Tiger, this is the buggiest OSX release since I switched to Mac.
Safari freezes all the time, fixed using Chrome , Preview has introduced errors I never thought it would, like the green screen error.
The new Disk Utility it is just a joke, not being able of formatting an USB drive without restarting the computer.
Samba drives are not able to refresh modified files and the list goes on and on ....
I hope Apple will work hard on this release but in the meantimeI cannot recommend its use.
I have had to use "Force Quit" several times since updating to this new OSX,which is a bit of a worry.
Until the update I only used Force Quit twice in three years Safari , iTunes and Photo apps are the most frequent offenders.

I have just visited my local Stormfront store and signed up for their 1 year support and they have directed me into making this new OSX work correctly and have now got a whole year to book as many 1 hour tutorials "IN STORE" as I require,brilliant idea thoroughly recommend this service as takes the worry and guessworkfor those who are not in the know.......
Watching the newly designed multicolour disc spin around for an age takes me back to halcyon days in the university library wasting my life trying to get Vista to do anything remotely productive.
It's difficult to say whether the El Capitan experience is really as bad as Vista.

Performance is undoubtedly better (I don't get the spinning disk ALL day long) but it does have the luxury of a quad-core processor and 16GB of ram with which it can produce these lengthy periods of "reflection'.
If anything, it also reminds me of 10 year old OSX 10.4 'Tiger', which loved the odd crash.
I bought two MacBook Airs last year, one for me and one for my wife.
My wife's Macbook was upgraded to El Capitan whilst I resisted and stayed with Yosemite.
Yosemite is undeniably faster and less buggy.
Thanks for the memories, Apple.
Any chance we could return to something resembling progress?

row.Title: Macbook Pro 2012 (Mid) very laggy and freezes with this IOS!!!!

row.Sentences: I have installed this IOS and it is terrible, I can no longer use my macbook pro because it lags and freezes all the time.
The most annoying part is that it never had this problems with previous older IOS.
I can't downgrade this IOS and I'm very desperate to find a solution because I know my mac specs are still fast and good for today's technology.
Please do not install it if you have macbook pro 2012 ( mid)!
If you have a solution for this problem please contact me!
This mac was expensive and now I can't use it!!

row.Title: Upgrade went so smoothly.
row.Topic: Compatibility, El_Capitan, Installation, Mail, N/A, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: Having read several reviews, I had been put off making the upgrade to El Capitan from Mavericks; however, in recent days the reviews have been more favourable, so I decided to upgrade.
I bought my first Mac in December 2013 (MCB Pro Retina Late-2013) which was loaded with Mavericks but given various iOS 9 developments and new Mac accessories, wanted to upgrade.
In terms of the installation I was pleasantly surprised to be greeted with an anticipated installation time of 26 minutes.
As past experience makes me believe that software developers appear not operate on "earth time', I was sceptical about the length of time I had been told, but was happy to be proved wrong.
Within 30 minutes, the upgrade was complete and I cleared off to bed.
After restarting everything worked perfectly, most importantly for me my personal finance and Adobe Creative Cloud apps are all fine and now a few days on, that remains the case.
I did have two minor snags both of which were easily resolved:1.
"wado_d.kext' being incompatible with El Capitan.
This was addressed by installing the latest version of Trusteer Rapport (IBM) and2.
I needed to create a new Wineskin wrapper for El Capitan for a particular program that is not available for Mac.
This took me less than 10 minutes to resolve.
In terms of more specific Mac observations: I have read in some reviews that after upgrading to El Capitan, users have suffered problems with Mail.
Personally, I have found the opposite.
Using Mavericks, Mail used to shut down inexplicably at least 4 times a week, and although it's early days, I have found Mail to be more stable with El Capitan.
If things change in coming weeks, I'll edit this accordingly.
My 3.4 Ghz Intel Core i5, 8 GB 1600 MHz DDR3 has now ground to a halt!
Why oh why did I update!?
Nothing appears to work well now.
Time to ditch apple sadly

row.Title: Amazing for my MACBOOK PRO with Retina display 13. Happy

row.Sentences: Great version of osx as it has many Advanced features including maps , mails and etc ,it is working really fast and i haven't faced any type of difficulties with it , Thanks to OS X El Capitan.
Since Snow Leopard, OSX is getting further from what I loved; this is a new low however.
Buggy is an understatement, even the bundled itunes, safari and mail crash reguarly.
The MS office and AU validator issues were know so I waited for a fix but I wish I'd never bothered.
If MS weren't doing such a shoddy job with their own OS I dare say I'd be looking at making my next Mac a PC.

row.Title: Super buggy pile of fecal matter

row.Sentences: - Everytime I put the computer to sleep and open it up again, it doesn't recognise my password as being correct - meaning I have to force shutdown the computer and I lose work.- iCloud is buggy and therefore useless.- Many other oddities I don't expec
Stable All software works.
No problems with Office despite a big song and dance being made about this.
Fast on both my 2011 13"MBP and lightening on my 2015 15".
Skipped the last update as it had so many bad reviews, so updated from Mavericks.
Have to say i was not sure, anyway it took a few hours to download and install.
Everything is fine, no problems to report at all.
it does not seem to be any faster or slower, just a brand new interface.
So all is good, would recommend for any one hesitant with an older iMac like mine, but ours is the intel core 2 duo.
Three days ago tried to install.
Let everthing run for about 2 hours, and I thought that it had installed, but today find that was not installed.
Now is in wait and nothing is happening.
Don't think I will bother any further.
Nothing but problems with mail.app and no fix at this stage.
Still terrible despite revisions.
since this update my laptop has run incredibly slowly, almost like its lagging, when there's barely anything running.
For some reason any program that has a "most recent' function has everything "most recent' completely gone.
the finder is now more obnoxious to use because the shortcuts on the left side are mostly gone, and using anything that needs to buffer suddenly barely works.
I had zero issues before the update but the last time I didn't update soon after it came out I had a hard drive failure, and I wasn't going to ignore it this time - just in case.
Wish I hadn't bothered now.
The previous one wasn't great but at least I could actually use my laptop.
As usual I installed the latest operating system, el Capitan, believing that improvements should be forthcoming but it seems that the thing has not been thought through properly.
I found my Epson printer would no longer scan and I had to download new drivers.
I am not a high level computer expert so even that took me some time to work out.
I have a Blackberry Playbook which I am very happy with, using it mainly for downloading and playing music.
However, el Capitan has stopped all that, I can no longer connect to the Blackberry with the Mac, even using a cable it refuses to see it so I cannot sync with iTunes.
Why oh why do Apple not properly test these upgrades before imposing them on the unsuspecting public.
Having been running this since it became available.
Far more issues and bugs than with any other previous release of OSX.
My iMac keeps quiting unexpectedly and restarting since the upgrade.
It didn't recognise my email accounts and started loading all the emails from my work's office google account.
It lost all my wife's mail folders that were stored on her macbook which I had to reistall manually once I found the storage location.
iTunes keeps freezing after my iMac has been in sleep mode and I have to quit and restart to get it to work again.
On the whole not good and not as smooth a transition as other updates.
10.11.1 hasn't solved any of the issues, although things seem a bit smoother and quicker than they were before.
I know it's free and all that but seriously, with the number of one star reveiws for this version Apple really need to pull their finger out of thier backsides and get it sorted, pronto.

row.Title: If it's not broke don't fix it !

row.Sentences: Well Mr El Capitan you have just won the highest award for buggy, problematic, time consuming software ever pushed to the unsuspecting Mac fraternity.
I am not wasting time explaining my problems as the web is already heavily splattered with the same El Capitan problems.
but I will give this valuable advice.
CLONE YOUR HARD DRIVE BEFORE INSTALLING ANY NEW OSX so that you can easily go back to your original OS.

In my case within three days of the El Capitan installation after literally hours of un-necessary messing about to no avail all three of my machines have been reverted to the previous OSX 10.10.2 (Yosemite).
Just a reminder CLONE / BACKUP YOUR HARD DRIVE

row.Title: Unnecessarily worried by the negative reports

row.Sentences: Had avoided updating OSX for some time due to negative reports.
Despite the dodgy name El Capitan, decided to take the plunge anyway with the idea of backtracking through Time Machine if all went wrong.
Download seemed to take no time at all in comparrison to what I was expecting.
Then left it to do it's own thing.
Again no concerns about the time taken.
It all went swimmingly.
Have been using El Capitan for about a week now.
No issues with the apps I use.
Things obviously appear differently on screen due to a different operating system .
I will take a little while to get used to the different format, but then what would you expect.
I believe My iMac 27" mid 2010 is working faster than before, Not sure whether thats wishful thinking or fact, but overall I'm glad I updated to El Capitan.
Can't see any difference between El Capitain and Yosemite.
Apply updates (inc. iOS) should be as exciting as opening a Christmas present on Christmas Day.....they are actually as exciting as opening junk mail that gets out through your letterbox.

row.Title: Extremely good version of OS X
row.Topic: Backup, Compatibility, El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Performance, Speed, Spotlight, Update

row.Sentences: "El Capitan".
I mentioned the name to non-Apple using friends and they laughed at it.
Good job there Apple.
Really great job.
I understand WHY the name was selected, but that doesn't change the fact that it is a silly name.
Pedantic feelings on naming conventions aside;El Capitan works extremely well on my Late-2012 MacBook Pro.
Its faster than Yosemite, and the new features are good.
The upgrade process was easy and painless.
I do have a bit of an issue with the new System Integrity Protection (SIP) since it broke a few apps at first, but you can disable it in recovery.

I dislike SIP, as they are using "stopping viruses" as a means to force developers to ask for certificates from Apple (which could be refused), essentially locking 3rd party apps out of certain functions unless they agree to Apple guidelines.
This feels like the start of locking down OS X, turning it into a closed system like iOS.
Other than SIP, I have no issues.
The broken apps quickly sorted it out and released updated versisons for El Capitan.
It works closely and very well with iOS 9 on iPhone 6, so no issues there.
Most apps worth getting that are not on the App Store should have updated to compensate for SIP by now.
Spotlight seems to work a little better.
The new system font is nice to the eyes, and the new Japanese font is very nice.
I like the new changes/features in the Japanese input system, it makes typing and kanji selection a little quicker, though is still used essentially the same way.
I LOVE the new split-fullscreen view.
It makes it easier to take notes whilst watching a YouTube video without wasting screen real estate.
Just press and hold the green fullscreen button and it will fullscreen but allow you to select another window.
You can pull the middle divider to give more space to one window or the other.
The new under-the-hood features really do improve speed and load times.
El Capitan runs much better than Yosemite on my Mac, contrary to the people who are having issues.
I really recommend upgrading to El Capitan, but maybe not if your Mac is 2011 or earlier.

I also suggest that if you have an app that you NEED and is imperative for your job or something else, that you check with the app developer to ensure that their newest update supports System Integrity Protection; if it isn't, maybe hold off upgrading until they support it, look for alternatives, or stay on Yosemite.
Better to have your important applications working than the flashy new OS.
Please, please remember to back up your data before the upgrade!
There probably won't be any data loss, but it doesn't hurt to make certain.
:) Mac OS X "El Capitan' gets a 4/5 star rating.
If System Integrity Protection was an option, rather than the default, it would get a 5/5.
If you know how to disable SIP and re-enable it after giving access to apps, then consider this review a 5-star one.
Thanks for reading!
After my experiences with previous updates, I decided to do a clean install of El Capitan.
No major problems on an OS level, although a few app developers had trouble coping with some of the under-the-cover changes that required muliple app updates.
I've had a few crashes but no data loss.
Such events do dent your confidence in OS X but fade from the memory after a few hours of trouble-free use.

I originally updated earlier this year to yosemite from mavericks but was forced to go back to mavericks as my wireless lan and graphics tablets, bear extender and other gismos that I use with my mac for work, stopped working.
The revert back to mavericks worked fine, however it messed up the macs communication with iCloud so basically put me out of sync with anything previously saved to the cloud.
Last week I thought i would do the el capitan upgrade, so upgraded first to yosemite, backed up then up to el capitan.
At the yosemite point in the upgrade I was able to use my wirleless lan without issue and did the actual upgrade to el capitan via this network.

El capitan downloaded and i went though the stages of the reboot process and updating software etc, I now have communication with the cloud again, the graphics tablets I use now work without issue, the speed has definately improved, the onboard wireless is better and seems to be stronger, the display is crystal clear and besides a slower start up time I think apple finally have a reasonable upgrade that I can say is working.

My only gripe would be that the wireless lan does not work but I have hope that this may be addressed by apple in the next few months, the fact that the onboard wifi is working better does not make that such a huge issue anymore as I can now pull in wifi at around 30+ meters, far better than previous.

For the need to know people out there, I run a 2011 macbook pro non retina display, I do have 16gb of memory installed, its gaming memory as that is more suitable for my graphic intense work, I dont play games.....but find that the accelerated memory modules work far better in the design apps I use regulary.

I have read about the reviews of others again before trying the upgrade to el capitan and do hear abot the spinning beachball, I have seen it once since the upgrade so imagine if I was running on the original 4gb I would be having problems, my advice would be to clean the clutter, get the max memory you can afford, back up and try it, its working for me.........

row.Title: Creeping doom
row.Topic: Backup, Installation, N/A, Performance, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I dislike giving negative review, but this is hopefully constructive criticism.
After waiting to see any major bugs I went throught the installation process.
After checking whether the frequents apps worked everything seemed fine on the first glance.
However two weeks later during a project working in Adobe suite many faults and glithces started to appear.
The workflow became so frustrating with random crashes, dissapearing windows, flashing assets and constatnt memory overload dispite having a smooth workflow with Yosemite.
My adobe suite is still legacy at CS6 level as there is a certain robustness in cross-platform workflow.

I'm annoyed that I did't flag this for so long, as the faults seemed to slowly increase in frequency over time until despite using Java 6 (which incidentally slowed the other Apple apps down) until I had to do a full uninstall and go back to October.
Gratefull for the time Machine app in this case.
I feel that more could be done in these updates.
Apple had made a name with the creative and designer community who were the early adopters.
Many of us who have clocked decades with the company are finding the lack of communication in creative support frustrating.
I hope in future these would be better vetted.
In meantime I'm staying with Yosemite.
After upgrading from Yosemite to El Capitan few days ago I have experienced nothing but problems.

I cannot access my mail, my MS office for Mac does not work anymore (just keeps crashing) and now my home wifi drops the connection every 5 seconds or so (I have tried all the different solutions from the forums to try to fix this problem).
I did not have any of the problems with Yosemite.
Do not do upgrade to El Capitan until you have to!

row.Title: Very poor Macbbok performance after upgrade to El-Capitan

row.Sentences: Since upgrading to this version of software my Macbook has slowed to the point it is, at times virtually unusable.
Web pages either takes ages to load or do not load at all.
Microsoft Apps take a long time to load, E-Mail attachments either take a long time to send or will not upload at all.
Despite a huge amount of reported faults with this upgrade there is still no update from Apple to fix the numerous problems with this operating system.
The Macbook is an excellent laptop that is deserving of far better support from it's manufacturer
Installed the operating system, there were few problems in the instalation but now certain aspects of my Adobe CS5 are not functioning correctly (such as the eyedropper tool).
Research on the internet shows I am not the only one with new problems with Adobe CS5 and El Capitan.

Can I just remind Apple that design softwear costs a lot of money in the first place and the operating system used to run it MUST be first rate - your new operating system has crashed my Illustrator many times now, losing hours and hours of work in total.
Give me an operating system that works instead of a Dummy OS that has a million new emojis - BAD BAD BAD SHOW APPLE.
My advice is DONT UPDATE TO THIS NEW OPERATING SYSTEM DESIGNERS - IT IS A POOR COPY OF A GOOD OPERATING SYSTEM!!!!
Since installing an update for el capitan, I found that my thunderbolt display port does not connect to my external display.
Through a lot of trial and error, I found that the problem is not with the cable, or the external display, the problem is with el capitan.
I'm annoyed with apple.
Please fix asap

row.Title: Running well on Macs old and new.
row.Topic: Backup, El_Capitan, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update

row.Sentences: I have installed El Capitan on a 2015 MacBook, a 2009 iMac and a Mid 2010 MacPro.
We usually wait until the 10.x.3 or 10.x.4 version before updating.
We wanted the greater integration with our iOS devices, so took the plunge.
All three machines are running well.

I noticed on the first restart after install that for the first few hours the system would be "optimising" things in the background and so its attention would be divided and it would appear a bit slow.
Once El Capitan got that stage over all three Macs ran faster and had no unexpected compatibility problems.
I would always recommend running a Disk Utility check/repair before a system upgrade and also make sure that you have an up to date full Time Machine backup.

row.Title: The best upgrade I've done to my Mac.

row.Sentences: I always wait for a short while after major upgrades as I am too dependant on the software I use for my day job.

Having read the mixed reviews I was a little sceptical and did a backup onto to a new SSD (old disk also an SSD) and swapped the drives over, once all was confirmed working, I hit the button and let the El Capitan upgrade process start, it was complete including download within 2 hours.

Minor issues, MS Office needed the Security Key putting in again and Outlook Hotifx applying as it stopped working, and an old version of VMWare 5.05 no longer worked, downloaded the new version and my old VM all work but are now a little faster.
The whole thing was fairly painless and nothing that happened after the upgrade was unpredicted, had I Googled for any expected issues beforehand I woud have known about the VMware niggle.
Make sure you have a good backup and try it, I am completely satisfied with the upgrade it has improved the whole experience of using my Mac without question.
Having a larger SSD or the El Capitan has sorted an issue I was having of the Macbook coming off standby while in my bag and overheating.

row.Title: Great new features and updated clean look, but I've had issues...

row.Sentences: As above, the new look is great and some things work better:- Great interface.- External monitor colours are much improved with standard monitor profile - previously, I had to use an xrite device to calibrate it, as the colours were way out to the point that they were distracting for web browsing, let alone working on photos.

However, I've had quite a few issues with it on my MacBook pro (2009):- Mouse and external keyboard no longer wake laptop from sleep when using an external monitor - work around is lifting the laptop screen and pressing any key, but this get annoying very quickly.- System now crashes fairly regularly.
This hardly ever happened with the previous OS.- when the laptop goes to sleep, it disconnects the time machine external drive.
On waking the laptop again, a message is displayed saying the drive was not ejected properly.
Again, this never happened with the prevoius OS - work around is to eject the disk manually before the laptop goes into sleep - clearly far from ideal!
Don't upgrade to El Capitan!!!!
It has loads of crashing issues.
You'll regret using it.
I'm reverting to my Acer PC which had no problems using my song-writing program Finale 2014.
Tom Burns
Installed on my 2012 MacBook Pro.
I don't know what all the fuss is about.
A really unstable and rubbish update making mac os slow and laggy.
Had several random crashes and restarts as a result of OS X El Capitan, would definitely wait for a further installment of OS X before installing!
Not worth the constant beach balling!

row.Title: Next to useless for Pro Aps like Logic Pro X

row.Sentences: Installing this makes a few things clear.
First, it's pretty obvious that anyone who is at all smart at Apple isn't working on the Mac OS (or indeed on any of Apple's own pro software).
They're working on the "interesting' stuff, the consumer stuff, the iphone, the iPad, the watchy thing, the Apple pay thing and any future stuff.
The tedious minimal upgrading of the Mac is left to the cookie cutters, the incremental ant people.
As a result things like innovation, care and attention to detail are lost in translation.
The result is the first OS upgrade that I'm going to immediately delete.
Second, it's clear that Apple aren't that bothered about the pro community.
Despite Logic Pro X being one of the best grossing apps on the Mac, El Capitan renders it almost entirely unusable.
Apple's initial release of El Capitan failed to recognise third party audio plugins, which were programmed to their own specifications.
Apparently this issue has been "fixed'.
The plugins now actually validate.
However, the programme no longer seems to bother to use any kind of multi-threading, which makes actually using it somewhat pointless.
For instance, simply trying to use their own Alchemy soft synth overloads the single thread that is being used, corrupting the audio before you've even bothered to record it.
Releasing a new operating system that doesn't so much worsen their pro products but obliterates their functionality is really pretty impressive.
This is the first OS "upgrade' that makes the Apple experience significantly worse for me.
I can't wait to get rid of it.

row.Title: OS X El Capitan update - iMac keeps crashing

row.Sentences: Since the update of El Capitan, my iMac and apps have been crashing constantly.
Mac Mail also is experiencing endless crashes, email accounts keep requesting for passwords again.
I have been sending the reports back to Apple but there has been no feedback.
Will appreciate any suggestions, as this is becoming annoying now.
For those using external drives with NTFS , kiss them goodbye as you wont be able to write to them anymore without buying some proprietary software such as Tuxera NTFS .
Other than that it's ok ish .

row.Title: Icloud mail accounts disappeared from Macbook

row.Sentences: Installed this and my icloud email accounts "disappeared'!
Being honest, I wasn't expecting much!
And having had Yosemite almost crash my Mac Book Pro 17", I had approached this download with caution and trepidation.
But I had to do it as the OS on my machine was becoming redundant, having stripped Yosemite off the machine and reinstalled an older OS.
So given my worst fears, imagine my joy when El Capitan was quick to download and install.
Not only was it quick to download and install, but it only went and worked!
I couldn't believe it!!!
My machine now has a new lease of life and is overall, far more stable.
It has solved a number of old glitches that I'd had with Mail, iCal and more, as well as looking sleek and clean.
My faith has been restored!!!
My Mac world would now be complete if Apple were to tell me that they will continue to support Aperture - that was a hint by the way!
It took a while starting and stopping to actually download it, but I love the look (didn't update to Yosemite due to the terribe reviews).
I love everything, apart from the speed.
It takes a lot longer to do anything from opening a webpage to signing in when starting up or having two tabs open at once.
The weird thing was that once I had downloaded everything I went onto the purchased tab on the App Store and it says I haven't downloaded El Capitan.. Apart from that, it's good!

row.Title: Has ruined the peformance of two of my machines

row.Sentences: It started out with the continual crashing of dashboard, then applications started to randomly shutdown.
Peripheral devices are no longer supported properly.
This software update has brought me nothing but fustration.

row.Title: Not as fast as Mavericks still

row.Sentences: On my i7, 15" late 2011 mbp with 500Gig SSD and 16 GB RAM I have found a clean install of El Capitan to suffer spinning wheels a lot more than Mavericks.
I hope they fix it in future updates but I am not holding my breath.
Mavericks was very fast and slick.
My MacBook Pro was the best purchase I ever made, it replaced my old PC's.
Fast efficient, magic, then I upgraded to EL Capitan, how dissapointed I am, now back to the old days, wasting time waiting for it to load etc.
I hope apple soon upgrade EL and put it in the rubbish bin, and my macbook returnes to it's old self.

row.Title: Really good update, but some teething issues...

row.Sentences: So I've sometimes been skeptical of updating my OS near the start of the launch, but I thought I'd give it a go this time on my iMac, as I still occasionally use my macbook so I wasn't going to lose out.
So far so good in terms of my applications work, my Final Cut Pro is working seamlessly when I'm editing videos, as well as all the usual Apple apps like Photos, iTunes and the like.
Safari has been very slow, and constantly freezing.
Originally I thought it was internet connection, but after using my game consoles and macbook, this wasn't the issue.
It takes forver to load a page, and crashes all the time.
It is getting a little annoying, and I'd like to think there may be an update to resolve this issue.
Otherwise, I'm incredibly impressed so far!

row.Title: Upgraded smoothly and everything is snappy and looking good! :)

row.Sentences: My machine is a late 2013 MacBook Pro Retina 15-inch, 2.6GHz i7 w/ 16GB RAM and 1TB SSD.
Upgraded from Yosemite (which had been upgraded every release since Mountain Lion).
Set the upgrade off when I went to bed and it was immediately alive at the login screen when I went use it this morning.
No dialogs or prompts to respond to so pleased that it sorted itself out completely.
So far everything is working very well and everything is very fast indeed.
My machine was far from slow before but I must admit that the UI seems particularly lighting fast.
Spotlight is fast and responsive so no issues with files indexing and I have a good 900GB or data on my SSD.
When you have to us a Windows machine for work (software development), whilst it's not terrible, you really do appreciate how good Mac OSX is and what a joy it is to use!
Upgraded my iMac, macbook air and macbook pro.
Just clicked the upgrade button all worked fine.
All my apps work (all from app store).
No loss of data or performance.

row.Title: Minor Bug thats really annoying, why cant it just work, every major update has an issue

row.Sentences: Everything went well, except that it knocked out all of my custom program settings, Yosemite was a hundred times better, had no issues downloading that on my late Macbook pro 2013 edition, but el capitano has issues, the preview function no longer works, for the documents, pdfs, pictures etc.
Rather it opens the app on some occasions, Frustrating.
Overall i dont have major bugs, OS works fine, no crashes, shutdowns, no lag, better battery life i have a feeling.
The only problems are previewing which to me is a major problem as i have to open each and every document during heavy use.
Please apple fix this.

row.Title: Absolutely rubbish update!!! SHAME ON YOU APPLE!

row.Sentences: My Macbook has gone shockingly slow.
Keeps loging out of iTunes account after every restart.
I thought it will improve the performance but instead it has worsened it 1000 times!
Very disappointed and honestly considering switching again to Windows again!
My 6 years old Windows laptop works faster than my Macbook!

row.Title: Terrible - crashes all the time - avoid!

row.Sentences: My Mac Mini (late 2014) has crashed 16 times since installing El Capitan and its update.
Also, my Mac has now stopped connecting to my Apple Bluetooth keyboard, so I've had to go and buy a new wired keyboard.
Neither of these problems happened before installation of El Capitan.
Avoid like the plague.
Since updating, my Logic began being affected by a weird interference sound that came through on recordings.
This only occured on my iMac though, On the Macbook pro the update is fine and has some pleasant features.
After a little research it seems I am not the only person suffering this interference issue.
Hopefully a little work from apple can produce a cure and update to fix this.

row.Title: Think twice and check your hardware before upgrading
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, Mail, N/A, Performance, Update

row.Sentences: Seriously disappointed with El Capitan.

Upgrading to it on an old Macbook Pro was a mistake - machine now ruined, but my fault for not checking first - but also running it on a Mac Mini and there seem to be a number of minor but infuriating glitches:- Generally slow: slow to start up and some lag whilst working- Calculator disappeared for a couple of days before magically reappearing.
No restart or upgrade involved!- MAIL is beyond belief.
Clicking "REPLY' or "FORWARD' crashes the program.
These are pretty fundamental aspects of using email.
You have to pop the message into its own window before replying but, again, it's temperamental.
Some days it works some days it doesn't.
- FINDER has all of a sudden decided that files will no longer be arranged in alphabetical order!!!!
Similar to calculator, it happened without warning, and I'm hoping resolves itself.
All of my files - drawings, invoices etc - are now listed at random and the filters don't change it.
WHY?I'm not using many programs that require heaving processing power but what I do use can be slow.
Why these basic functions are going wrong is beyond me - trying to cram too much into the OS?
Apple showing off?
Don't know.
But think twice before upgrading, at least until these things are sorted out.

row.Title: Problems with Mail were just the start
row.Topic: Backup, El_Capitan, N/A, Performance, Speed, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Having installed El Capitan on my late 2009 iMac I have found that everything seems to be running pretty well with the exception of Mail which has started to "Unexpectedly Quit" when I send emails.
I have lost a couple of apps that have not integrated with El Capitan yet but hopefully they will catch up before too long.
All in all (apart from the problem with Mail) the iMac seems to be running better and providing nothing else goes wrong I will probably be upgrading my Macbook Pro.
I am having to revise my comments originally posted on 10th November.
Having had El Capitan installed for a week, I was experiencing further problems that eventiuully made working with El Capitan impossible.
Mail continually crashing was the first problem, I then lost the ability to connect to my router via ethernet though wireless was fine and then my iMac stopped recognising my WD external drives.
Running through all this was a significant slow-down in speed.
I eventually found it impossible to work and yesterday wiped my hard disk and re-instaled Yosemite from my Carbon Copy Cloner backup.
Everything is now working properly again.
I am assuming that El Capitan problems will probably be sorted in the next 12 months and I will re-visit it then.
In the mean time I would advise extreme caution before upgrading and make a full back-up of your entire hard drive first so you can revert if El Capitan doesn't work for you.

row.Title: Please, please don't use this until you have checked USB problems

row.Sentences: I am now unable to use 30,000 photos, which is 3 years work, because this upgrade has stopped my USB's from working.
Having looked up, too late, other people's problems with this, it is going to take days off Mac phone calls and probably visits to Mac Store miles away and this may not fix the problem.

row.Title: Dont update if you use it for recording

row.Sentences: El capitan will most likely not support your audio interface.
.... the ability to rename Desktops in Mission Control.... Why not to introduce that?
It'd make the life of many of us really easier.
Great OS otherwise, but I've noticed a decrease of battery life from Yosemite.
Regret installing this.
Have new MacBook.
Since this OS the whole thing just goes AWOL for 5 seconds at a time, several times a day.
I don't have anything strange installed or active.
In fact, I have a very minimalist configuration.
So the OS is the culpritDisappointing.

Since "upgrading' to El Crapitan and adding the mini upgrade my iMac runs slower; the sound alerts on Mail are either non existant or only play when sending mail, not receiving mail; icons for photos, especially tiffs, are not drawn by the finder (This alone has made the computer almost unusable); Safari takes a very long time to load; installation destroyed a disc activity monitor called "Disk Light' and the newly colourful waiting beach ball is seen far more than before.
I wish I had not upgraded.
I can honestly say my computer shows no advantages whatsoever.
My advice would be to wait for a substantial upgrade in the hope that these issues are sorted out.

row.Title: Clashes with WD My Cloud and has Email Problems

row.Sentences: Initially thought it was a good upgrade, but I've had hours of problems with WD My Cloud access.
Works fine will all PCs on my network, but not my Mac.
You can map the drive and reach it for some applications, but as soon as you reboot, it disappears!
You can access the dashboard through a browser, but you can't see it using Finder.
Spent hours looking at it / forums etc, but no closer to getting it working.
First fail for apple that I've seen!

I had a lot to lose by installing this, I have a pro recording studio and if I installed this, I would be putting everything at risk, I am happy to say, this works better than Mavericks and Mountain Lion ever did, if you have a 2011 iMac or MBP and your struggling with Yosemite or Mavericks, this works brilliantly, I am glad I bit the bullet.
Cannot even download the software; just hangs.
Seeing the ratings it's best left hanging.
I often use the Thunderbolt connection to HDMI to output video to my TV, via an AV receiver.
After updating to El Capitan, the picture output flashes green intermittently, and won't stabalise.
I had to revert back to a previous time machine back up onto Yosemite, and it now works fine.
Worst upgrade apple have come up with, have stripped back my machine and returned to previous version and comouter has never ran better.
sick of the dredded beach ball, sick of apple music changing my songs and not allowing certain song on playlist, and photo application is the worse ever!!
infact becoming ver disillusioned with apple products in general.
maybe time for a change.
I read many of the reviews and, feeling optimistic, downloaded and upgraded.

Before I knew it I was lost in a loop of "insufficient space on the hard-drive', shutting down, restarting, reading up on options via my iPad, shutting down, restarting in safe mode, trying to delete files, restarting.
My late 2013 went from having 700gb available before El Capitan to having no usable disc space.
After a day of frustration I reverted to a pre-update back-up and sanity is restored.
How have Apple allowed this to be released?
I honestly believe that the only reason this version of OS X has been rated 4+ in the App Store is because It's going to take atleast ten years before you even think about getting anything done....
The only noticable new feature for me so far is the spinning loading wheel.
I'm running a Macbook Pro (2.9GHz Intel Core i7, 8GB 1600 MHz DDR3) and mainly use Firefox, Office, Messages and the Adobe Packages and it is absolutley dreadful!
- I honestly feel as if I've gone back in time and turned on my Windows 95 Apricot Machine!

What's more, After update, I've had a number of .plist errors happening regularly, mainly the Side Bar in Finder disapearing off of the face of the earth until restarted and I also had a number of Adobe programes become incompatible....
I feel as if the OS's are being rushed, please take us back to the Snow Leapord/Lion days.... OSX El Capitan is a major disapointment!
Uploaded quickly.
np problem.

row.Title: disasterous consequences if you are a novice...

row.Sentences: and simply read an email from Apple inviting me to hit download and promising me the earth with the upgrade.
And being that novice, didnt have any form of back up.
Photos, emails, the whole electronic life between 2011 Macbook pro and now - vanished in a puff of seemingly ill-tested and very poorly explained "upgrade".
Im sure the judgmental out there will scoff at the naievity and lack of back-up but, we exist and, feel massively let down.
Since updating, my MacBook Air crashes all the time, is generally much slower, and vital apps like Preview and Word often don't work properly.

As a student, most of my time is spent reading pdfs which means I have to force quit Preview about a dozen times a day because for whatever reason the pages suddenly become blurry, as though they haven't loaded properly.
This is incredibly frustrating and just taught me that I won't ever update my Mac OS again until a few months after release when all the bugs have been worked out.
This OS X is not ready yet.
I would recommend you check compatibility to meet your current software/interfaces etc.
My interface is not currently compatible so I've had to downgrade my OS X to get it working again.
Also I found internet sluggishness and issues with menus and buttons not working in Photoshop Elements.
I like the new look but I'd recommend waiting for a few months for Aple and other companies to get everything working together fully before upgrading.
Updated after seeing mostly good experiences, macbook freezes when restarting, downloaded os x and tried again, still no good, ran disk utility and no problems found.
in the end I had to restore to a time machine backup just to get it to start properly
Horrible, horrible, horrible.... word and office products continue to crach and freeze up.
I see no value of upgrading to this.
It is just hassle.
I have lost so much work I am going to go back to the old software.... Horrible!

row.Title: Lots of problems if you have a 3 year old machine

row.Sentences: Downloading El Capitan is the worst thing I've done.

I had to download lots of additional software just to use my exisiting adobe programmes and it has very negatively impacted on the speed of programmes with the egg timer now appearing about every ten minutes.. Several of my office programmes now frequesntly crash whihc wasn't happening before El Capitan.
untill this year I swore by Apple and their customer service but no longer.

The service from Apple seems to have deteriorated significantly this year with a push to servicing only those who can upgrade their macs every year and El Capitan appears to have followed this trend, such a shame.
I'm hoping to find a way to uninstall it.
Held back on updating El Cap on my early 2013 macbook pro due to the number of negative reviews and only took the plunge yesterday.
So far everything is working really well, no problems with mail or my myriad of apps including Adobe CS6, logic pro and final cut pro, office suite etc.
Fingers crossed my patience was rewarded.
Looking good and noticably faster in both start up and app launch.
Don't see much difference between this OS and Yosemite - that my iPod Classic will not sync with either my iMac or Mac Mini is the biggest upset - hopefully an upgrade to the OS or iTunes will fix.
Did seem to be slower to begin with using Applications - but that speed has increased nowFast to install once downloaded; and seemless installationIf they can fix the syncing issue I'll be happier!
Thought that I'd give this OS ugrade a go based on the more recent/favourable reviews.
Unfortunate error on my behalf.
Not everything is a complete loss, but I am irritated by the fact that a company such as Apple can release a software upgrade that has so many unfavourable reviews.
The look of the upgrade is ok, but what you want is streamlining and performance, this is where it failed!
Like so many others, my machine went frustratingly slow.
This was all through the power up sequence, logon screen and OS mounting.
This continued whilst accessing applications and using the internet.

The spinning rainbow wheel that I had seen so little of in my past 5 years of using Mac's has been making many an unwanted appearance, in fact pretty much any time I attempt to multi app, switch screens or when scrolling large webpages.
None of which had been experienced previously.

I accept that my hardware is perhaps not best placed to accept the latest software (MacBook Air, 2nd gen), but it seems that no matter which Apple device I update (I have 6 devices including phone, ipads and iPod) if it is not the latest generation of a product, the device suffers in someway.
I've reverted to my previous OS and am much happier (although I think a couple of Gremlins came back with me!).

Shame that for whatever reason this didn't really work for me, was actually looking forward to getting a bit more utility from my Mac, but look like if I really want that I'll have to part with some more good money.
Someone within the organisation shoud be locked up for giving so many of us shiny metal Apple addictions!

row.Title: Works for me .. and great service
row.Topic: Download, El_Capitan, N/A, Safari, Support, Update
