It's fast, fluid and what a well-built operating system should be.
The "pinned sites' functionality in Safari is brilliant and allows me quicker access to the sites I visit regularly.
Transit options in the Maps app are greatly welcomed.
I'd like Apple to work with more third party companies to extend this feature outside of already supported areas.
I thoroughly recommend El Capitan.

row.Title: not as bad as people say!

row.Sentences: I've downloaded on an early 2015 mac book air, it downloaded without any problems and took only about half an hour.
I havent had any issues but as not much of a computer buff it seems almost the same to me if not a little quicker.
My only issue is that it seems to have reduced my battery life by about an hour/ hour and a half, which is a bit of a bummer
Download and installation easy.
Everything was as I left it when I rebooted.
I love the split screen option but apart form that do not see much difference.
i read the reviews and i installed it , itunes is not working, i can not use my external soundboard .
and i "ve just tried few minutes , probably 100 other things don't work properly
The split screen feature could do with being simplified and I've noticed a few bugs with it which is a shame because it's the one feature I was most looking forward to using.
All in all, a great update with largely superficial tweaks and updates
Don't update if you need to access Mail via Outlook for Mac.
I did and do - and I'm now regretting it.
I appreciate this isn't an Apple issue.
Microsoft is aware but there is no timetable to resolve the issue.
Otherwise the update OS looks and feels great.
I have to say not the best upgrade, I've now spent two days re sorting lots of things that the upgrade messed up.
Most importantly, MAIL, completely screwed up my mail boxes.
WATCH OUT> this version deletes all your old POP mail boxes and replaces them with IMAP!
you'll find a new folder called Lost & Found where you'l find lots of redundant folders, the thing is I still can't find some, I've lost years of emails.
Also Photos, not all the features listed as new seem to be in the App still trying to fathom that out.apart form that any new features are very smal improvements
Over the years I have been fortunate not to incur propblems with updates.
However, this upgrade has caused no end of problems and continues to do so with all my business email accounts which have always run faultlessley.
It should be noted that my private Mac accounts experienced no problems.
Firstly, for some unknow reason the upgrade deleated all the passwords to these accounts and then once re-inputted, transmission of the emails(no attachments) seem to take an age!
Problem appears to be on going.
I foolishly upgraded thinking this would resolve some of the issues caused by Yosemite.
Unfortunately it caused more.
Applications crash, including Outlook which I use for my work email.
Even my native Calendar won't sync properly with iCloud.
I wish I could go back to Mavericks - everything worked then.
Apple seem to be chasing the Microsoft reputation of hit and miss on their releases.
I scoffed at one user suggesting he might go back to Microsoft - now I'm giving the idea more credence.
Subtle reinterpretation of existing OS which fails miserably to assign any control whatsoever to anyone other than "apple' employees.
If you, Apple, are in the slightest part interested in innovation as parcel of a creative participative process then you have to let people inside.
OS X is back on track - reliable install and works just as well as the previous version.
Extra features add to your experience rather than confuse you (It's NOT Windows 10 !).
I am a 13 year Mac user and very pleased with "El Capitan"

row.Title: OS System is great - Major issue with compatibility though

row.Sentences: For the system functionality I would give 5 stars - however; the reason for 1 star is because Microsoft Outlook crashes continually.
This is a known issue.
Do not update if you need MS Outlook for work.
To date, there is no patch to fix the MS Outlook issue.
Very quick, clean update from Yosemite.
Only two minor issues.
Bluetooth stopped working and I had to delete a plist file to get it back.
Outlook2016 doesn't support the split screen feature, so it isn't universal and seems to need some sort of support in the app.

row.Title: 2011 mac book pro
row.Topic: Download, Feature, Installation, N/A, Speed, Update

row.Sentences: i eventually took the plunge and updated my early 2011 mac book pro from its origional OS.
the download and install did take most of the day in all with a 4 mbps connection,although i wasn't watching it constantly.
the download took maybe 3 hours.

i got a blank greyscreen at the start of the install which i cleared by powering down and switching back on-the computer then continued to install with no problems-it took longer than the progress bar indicated so dont be in a rush to get this done!
when the install is complete the computer powered up and i logged in-it then takes some time to load up as its still "thinking'- then you are in.
eevrything works fine ,almost seems quicker than before.
wi-fi works fine, all my files transfered fine. '
I photo' no longer works,but the photos app is in the dock,i had to add my iphoto album to photos from my pictures file- all works fine- very similar to i photo.
new spotlight search is good.split screen is handy, i havn't used much else yet.lightroom 5 seems to load up and work fine.in all i'm very happy!
Dont know about macbook pro.
but for sure for its not for Air, extremely slow, strugging with window selecting.for me its a huge disappointment

row.Title: Stable and worth the small upgrade

row.Sentences: I'ts not a massive jump from 10.10 but the small improvments such as finding where sounds are coming from in Safari or what processes are draining the power, all of these little refinments are never a bad thing and the size of the download is small in comparison to Win10 or 10.10.
I've tested it all the way from the start of the public beta and there were a lot things not working at first but this latest release is fantastic!

row.Title: Killed my Email and Calendar, thanks Apple.

row.Sentences: So it turns out that this update does not work with Exchange, but Apple in their wisdom failed to mention this so now the MacBook Air I bought for work is screwed.
Now I have to waste my life trying to undo this nonsense before work tomorrow.
Thanks , you're the best.
Definitely worth the time downloading, it improved the speed of all my apps on the 2012 MacBook Pro.
The new feattures are useful too but manly the overall speed improvements are the main reasons for downloading.

row.Title: MS Office Users DO NOT Install

row.Sentences: Stupid stupid me.
I read the very favourable reviews which mentioned that the wifi issues had finally been sorted out and everything "runs quicker and smoother' - so dived in and upgraded.
Now I find that all my MS Office 2011 apps are wildly unstable and crash, so much so that I now cannot use my laptop for work.

If you google "ms office el capitan hanging' you will get 117,000 results - and clearly this issue has been known about for sometime - so why Apple don't own up and warn people before they download I have no idea.
I've also found two other issues - Dropbox does not appear to be compatible with this OS and my Private Internet Access VPN no longer works in Safari - though it's fine in Chrome.
I pay a premium for Apple products to be properly tested and NOT have issues like these.
Consider yourself warned.
Another nail in Apple's coffin as far as I am concerned.
For those with Wifi issues - here's what worked for me - a fix I discovered entirely by accident as the Genius Bar guys had no idea how to fix it.
I was having terrible trouble keeping a wifi signal even when standing next to my router, a BT Home Hub 4.
The fix was simple - I disabled the 5GHZ signal in the router admin menu and my connection problems dissapeared.
This fix also worked for a 2012 macbook air and a 2013 iMac.

row.Title: Basicaly what OS X Yosemite should have been

row.Sentences: So far I am impressed.
Basicaly a de-bugged version of OS X Yosmite that feels snapier and more polished.

row.Title: BEWARE: MAILS DISSAPEAR FROM POP ACCOUNTS

row.Sentences: As soon as you install all your emails set up using pop accounts will disappear.
I just spent 2 hours getting some of all the emails back by deleting some folders in the library and restarting.
Luckily this happened to me during a weekend but I would have been super stressed and pxxxxd off if this happening during work..
I recommend you wait a couple of months while they fix these glitches!
Tried to do the update.
It started to download but got all the way to the end and it errored!
Now I can't even get it to recognise that I can update my operating system!!??!!
What on earth is going on??
Apple get a grip!
I have tried to install this however it says i cannot install on the macintosh HD what can i do about this?

Machine installed on:MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Mid 2014)2.8 GHz Intel Core i716 GB 1600 MHz DDR3What can I say.... painless installation and everything is working so far (even the WiFi, which am sure many of ou cursed during the immediate updates to Yosemite).
Definitely no loss in performance following the update.
I tend to be a hoarder and always copy these installation files to an external source before running the installation and my favourite thing about them is the "untouched' nature of my machine.
It starts where it left of, just with a new operating system.
Thus, I can hop back to Yosemite relatively easily if this one doesn't suit.
Took a long time to install.
But have had to delets icloud accounts completely as mail stopped working after a day.
Had to do the same on my iMac and macbook air.
If you rely on only one apple device, wait for fixes before downloading.
However my machines are now even faster than previously, particularly Photo.
Great update.
THis has got me my mid 2012 MBP back..... Everything is super fast.

row.Title: Prepare to lose all your e-mails

row.Sentences: I spent over an hour on the "phone to Apple Care yesterday trying to restore my mail archive from Yosemite.
They have raised a "TRA" to the softies to try to get a patch done, but they have yet to fix this issue.
In the meantime, I have rebuilt my machine back to 10.10 Yoesmite - lucky i have a Time Capsule!

row.Title: Dont update if you want MS Office to carry on working

row.Sentences: Upgraded and the El Capitan operating system at first seemed fine with lots of good features.
However, when it comes to starting MS Office 2011, Outlook will crash after about 2 minutes of using.
Sometimes that crash leads to Excel crashing too.
If, like me you use Microsoft Office for a lot of the time you use your mac, you should wait for a fix for this problem, otherwise you are going to have a seriously bad user experience.
There doesn't appear to be a timeframe for any fix forthcoming from Microsoft so who knows when it will be fixed and my mac running smoothly again.
well my Mail was working fine and now it appears that its not!
sayssince installed to this EI CAPITAN
MacBookPro Late 2011 - Download and install went ok apart from Mail showed up as an empty application, didn't bring any accounts or folder structure.
Restored files from Time Machine but Mail said these were unsupported formats and still failed to load.
After several reboots and restores still no accounts or folders so restored full laptop from Time Machine to Yosemite.
It has been acknowledge by FCP.
CO and becoming widely known by many pro users that due to required updates in CoreImage (and possibley other areas of the OS), FCPX is displaying corruption of its TimeCode Window.
Evern worse, some pro users reporting frequent crashes and slow performance on MacPro (Late2013).
Though all of these are not present on all machines, all of the time, Caution should be taken when upgrading, especially if you are mid-project.. then common sense prevails!
Personally, I too have the corrupted TC window, and some crashing when using FCPX.
3rd Party Plug-Ins should be EC ready before you install this OS.. many have reported issues with 3rd party plug-in software.
Hopefully, Apple will address the relevant issues very quickly, either 10.11.1 (or 10.12) and/or FCPX 10.2.3 ?!!
Sort it out Apple, please!
I'd begun to think that some nasty maggots had invaded my beloved Apple, especially with the last two updates to OS X.
But this has restored my faith.
My machine (MBP mid-2013) has become faster and the general sense of it feeling cool has been restored.
I'd migrated to Chrome but am happier that Safari runs better now.
I still don't like the way Apple hegemony has become more important than true customer service.
There is still a danger that Apple will go the same way as VW, once the over-arching principle of the customer coming first gets forgotten.

row.Title: Not Bad - Not Noticed a Difference
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Installation, Mail, N/A, Performance, Support, Update

row.Sentences: I have a late-2013 iMac (purchased in April 2014) which started off with OS X Maverick but then upgraded to OS X Yosemite 6-months ago.
A few days ago, I upgraded to this new OS X El Capitan and to be honest, I have not noticed much difference.
To be honest, I probably use the iMac for about 15% of what the machine is capable of.
Installation was simple, still took about 90-minutes but I think the Apple Servers were busy.
Not noticed many issues apart from my iCloud Mail account of which I had to get an Apple Online Support to share my screen which ended up in removing and then readding my iCloud Mail account.
One of my Flight Similator Apps will not open in a Full Screen mode anymore and just crashes overtime.
I have to play it in a "windowed" mode which then prevents me from seeing the Flight Controls.
I have contacted the Support team regarding this.
Other than that, I like the new split screen viewing but I have not noticed any subtle difference with the speed of El Capitan from Yosemite.
It does seems a tiny bit glitchy but not enough to annoy me, just yet.
I guess only time will tell.

row.Title: Painless upgrade
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, Installation, Mail, N/A, Safari, Speed, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I have just updated my MBP r2015 13" from its original Yosemite to The Captain.
Installation took 25 minutes at which point I signed into a system which obviously looked exactly as it did before.
There are no obvious differences.
The computer is not noticeably faster or slower, I already had the latest iTunes and Safari, and all apps work as they did before.
Yosemite was perfectly stable and I have no reason to suppose this new version will be any less so.
The minor changes to Notes and Calendar do not merit comment and the same could be said for Safari 9.
The mail client is a different matter.
Checking for mail now takes about one second for eleven pop3 mailboxes.

The previous version was quite arthritic and often I could finish reading the mail before the sound played to tell me I had receved it so I am delighted that it now functions like a normal computer in this respect.
I cannot comment on graphics speed as I do not play games.
HD films look good but then they did before.
Some reviews suggest this OS runs more smoothly but the previous version had no issues for me in that respect so it would not be possible for me to appreciate the change.
I am perfectly happy with 10.11 thus far.

row.Title: Slow down for third party SSD with TRIM ENABLED

row.Sentences: I first installed El Capitan as the preview beta, lots of people were saying it was fast and very responsive.

I had Yosemite installed on a Crutial 512 SSD with 16GB of ram on 2012 model Macbook pro, i had enabled trim with the command line in terminal under yosemite and had no problems it was extremely fast and stable.
I installed El Capitan preview as a fresh install and all seemed well until i enabled trim support, everything became sluggish and unresponsive.

This is exactly the same with 10.11 El Capitan as soon as i enable trim support my Mac Book becomes sluggish and apps opened slowly, i have since done another install and left everything to garbage collection.

There seems to be a massive difference between yosemite and El Capitan with trim support enabled at least with my SSD, without El Capitan appears to be more snappier and more responsive than yosmite, an improvement in the right direction.

row.Title: Nice evolution of the operating system

row.Sentences: Works fine on my old "Early 2009" 24-inch iMac.
Doesn't seem any slower than Yosemite was as some people have said on older iMac's.
Only odd thing is the notes app (really nice updated by the way) constantly shows the iCloud busy icon, not sure why it does this but works fine anyway.
These new OS systems seem very selective in what they transition over.
I'm now stuck trying to reestablish all the family's email accounts etc.
I'm so happy with this update!
My Mac now works faster, everything looks cleaner, but I'm a little upset with the split view.
I don't understand why Word does not cooperate with this?
Being a student, having word open, along with sources from the internet (or netflix if it's not too hard going) would be ideal.
Three days I have been waiting, expecting performance improvements and lots of magical things.
thought it was my wifi but wont download at work or in Pret.
My raiting isnt really fair but im not changing it till they do something so i can actually get the dam downloads!!

updated to this supposedly better software but to my dismay ibooks not functioning with it, failed to open, tried everything possible to opne it but to no avail, thought maybe i did something wrong, i re-downloaded the software again and same thin, ibooks not opening at all, tried reverting back to yosemite but unsuucessful after i got so frustrated with it cos all my books on iBooks.
This is really frustrating for me, Apple can yu kindly do something about this PLEASE!!!

row.Title: dont install if you have a bootcamp partition!

row.Sentences: I have a late 2013 macbook pro retina 15" and since I upgraded to el capitan my bootcamp parition has vanished from the startup options, finder and Disk Utility.
Researching on the apple forums there seems to be a fix involving terminal/testdisk but it's really, really complicated and not for beginner-intermediate users.
I'm not sure if i'll be able to get it working again and i'll potentially lose a huge amount of unsaved data / progress in games etc.
If you have a bootcamp partition make sure you backup before upgrading to el capitan!
The actual update for osx is nice enough but i'd advise bootcamp users to wait until it's properly patched before upgrading.
Since installing this my audio interface refuses to work simply flashing in the settings menu in sound under system pref..........now cant do any studio work!!!!

row.Title: add some speed to your old macbook pro.

row.Sentences: Forget the gimmick apps, the great thing about this update is speed.
nearly recovered an old 2011 17" MacbookPro pumping up from slughish to ok. and my 2014 15" Retina MacbookPro from fast to instant.

row.Title: El Capitan - best OS X yet!

row.Sentences: Upgraded 4 iMacs in the family ranging from current model 21 ins (not fusion drive) through to 2007 20 ins - all installed quickly, each one was left to optimise for an hour or so and once completed they all run much faster than before.

Everything opens and runs quicker - Office Mac 2011 opens almost immediately and runs brilliantly, (no pauses or spinning wheels) opening of all existing apps work without any problem and a pleaseure to use.
Highly recommended.
nice one Apple - more again next year please.
I'm reading so many positive reviews about El Capitan, but I havent noticed a difference - maybe I'm not using my iMac in the same way as others??

The update took quite a while to install (a minute lasted way longer than 60 seconds), and I haven't noticed any improvement in the machine's performance.... in fact I'm seeing this new beach ball timer thing more often than I did before.
I'm not saying El Capitan is bad or don't update your machine; I just wonder if there was any point to releasing it as a new OSX?
The majority of the changes appear to be "behind the scenes' so why didn't they just do these as a software update for Yosemite?
Although, when hundreds of people have given it five-star reviews - how can so many be wrong?
This update is awesome, the actual additional features do not amount to much but the performance improvement is stunning.
I have been running the public beta for the last few months and there has been no problems at all.
My rMBP was fast before but everything is now instant and so smooth, well done Apple

row.Title: Nice update but AirDrop not working?!

row.Sentences: Great update to an already great OS but it would be good if testing core functionality was part of the release.
Bit of a big error to release this and not fix the AirDrop bug that came with iOS 9!
Please fix this asap.
It WAS a very useful utility....!

row.Title: Installation will not complete MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Early 2013)

row.Sentences: Do not attempt to install this update without having made a time machine backup first!
I have made four attempts to install the release version of El Capitan.
Every time it gets stuck around the 85% mark.
I have updated all apps in advance.
I have uninstalled old apps, and apps that did not come from the App Store.
The vendor of Serato has issued an email about serious compatibility issues.
Since installing El Capitan, the time taken for startup has greatly increased, performance is greatly reduced when multiple apps are open such as Chrome, Safari and Pages.
Videos playback is also degraded and the Mac freezes if it goes to sleep.

row.Title: Don't do it (yet) - lost my mail !!

row.Sentences: I installed this based on the latest reviews but now find all my emails have gone and I cant connect to my old account!
I dread to think what else has gone backwards...
I updated to El captain and i must everything looks nice and modern.
I had to reset my apple password because there were issues, and then it started to ask me my password for everything.
But the worse was that outlook wouldn't work anymore.
It would just work for ever, trying to connect to the exchange server.
After looking on the internet, that's the same for everyone.
I had to restaure my system to Yosemite (thanks time machine!).
I will update when all the early bugs will be cleared.

row.Title: Backup BEFORE ANY Upgrade: this is a must people!

row.Sentences: I have a lovely MacBook Pro (Retina, 13-inch, Early 2015) 2.7 GHz Intel Core i5 and it did not love the new upgrade.
After upgrading it took 38 hours before i had to crash it.
The progress bar stayed there on reboot for another 4 hours before i rebooted and then it started to boot properly to the main screen.
Never got past the colourful spining beach ball.
I have learnt to back up before upgrades so that i can put my computer back to how it was when it was working properly.
I suggest we give Apple a few months to sort out software issues and try it again then.
I am bitterly disappointed it has failed Apple, at least for me.

this OS X at first seemd to be fine everything working faster than on yosemite, then my imac got switched off this is were i have had the problems as when it is rebooting it goes to the grey screen with a dark grey apple sign and a progress bar under the apple i left it for over half an hour and nothing changed then restarted in recovery mode and reinstalled the OS X again all seemed to work ok so i tried restarting again and again same issue as before ,so whilst in rec mode went through disk utility to make sure all was ok then reinstalled the OS X again have not restarted since as it is a pain to go through the install process btu other than that issue all other aspects are working well and app opening is alot quicker
I have just upgraded to El Capitan and seriously wish that I had not.
Some major problems that I cannot find solutions for:1.
The system no longer sees my NAS Drive, so I cannot get to any of my files.2.
Microsoft Office 365 Apps do not open under it.
Now have to find a way to go back to Yosemite!

row.Title: Don't feel any difference on old Macbook

row.Sentences: A lot of people are praising El Capitan due to improved performance.
I was hoping for this, but it did not happen in my case.
Obviously new macs will work better due to Metal.
Older macs seem to be praising El Cap due to fixed UI lag.
I am in the latter case with 2010 mid MB pro.
I was really excited about the fixed UI lag before instalation but afterwards (and after indexing was complete) everything works exactly the same and UI lag is still here.
My bet is that El Capitan improves performance on HDDs, which in my case does not matter since I replaced stock HDD with SSD.
Summary: if you have older generation macbook with an SSD, don't expect a significant performance improvement.

row.Title: Upgrading cost me 150 in repairs - Don't Install!

row.Sentences: I upgraded to El Capitan and it crashed itself while installing causing a kernel panic crash loop that I had to take to a repair shop to wipe the laptop clean.
Not impressed Apple.
This is a fine OS upgrade.
I've been running the beta for some time now, and it had already earned 5 stars from me, for the most part.
Just one more thing, however.....+++++ Apple, PLEASE can we move away from this ghastly grey-on-grey-on-grey text theme?
It's really hard on the eyes in anything but perfect viewing conditions, and soon becomes unreadable during outdoor use.
My eyesight is pretty good, but I find the text in Mavericks and earlier OS X versions much easier to read.

row.Title: Worst apple OS for the last 10 years!

row.Sentences: As a long time mac user and consumer i upgraded my 2011 macbook pro to El Capitan....
This was the singular worst mistake i have ever made!

Not only has it slowed my mac down to the point where it is not usable, the spinning wheel appears when i try to move the cursor.... it won't even play a video file without stopping every few seconds!
I've had to reboot my phone as it lost all my phone backups, which meant having to download my apps all over again and set everything back up the way I had it....
I've even had to reset my Apple Watch all because of this awful update!
I had everyhting in my house setup for mac, the home cinema streamed from my mac - this no longer works!
I am beyond annoyed to the point where i could could actually smash my Mac.
For the first time in years I feel completely let down by Apple!

Dont know how these people get things to work so well and quickly,this took all night and next morning to install,it keeps insisting i need update for i photo and leaves big red 1 update in app store even though i photo doesnt exsist any more(changed to photos in last update to yousamite)Now its downloading el capitan again even though im now running it and i cant stop it.
Guess it will be doing it all weekend now.
Wish i stuck to crappy old pc!
I tried and failed to install El Captain on a macbook pro 2009!
I am running Mavericks, It went round in circles, constantly trying to install El Captain.
Have now reinstated my mac book to Mavericks from back up software, thanks apple another great download.
I am really disapointed as I have read so many positive reviews.

Since updating all pof my N-I and UAD plugins are no longer being validated on Logic Pro X, I sincerely wish that Apple would make sure that their products work properly before releasing them..... this is not the fiorst time they have done this..... if you make music on your mac as a job..... DO NOT UPDATE!!!!!
Installed El Capitan after reading how pleased everyone seemed to be.
Installation took quite a while but everything worked as normal, until I turned off.
On rebooting the progress bar stayed blank and after a while I forced my Mac to shut down.
I restarted it and tried to reinstall, again the installation took several hours, but patience paid off and my Mac booted up.
The following morning, again the same problem.
This is so frustrating, im not really 100% computer literate, so it looks like I will have to take in my Mac to a Professional and have them return my Mac to its previous state.
Thank you Apple for your update, its been nothing but a pain in the neck so far.
Mail now requests passwords all the time; and erasers them once input.
USB devices not recognised....programs incompatible and force paid upgrades.
I am running on a retina Macbook Pro so it's not the age of my system.
All other people that I know with Macs are having Mail problems.
Very poor from apple.
Since downloading this my Safari has stopped working and the cooling fan is running non stop, looks like a trip to an apple store to fix
I love the new multitasking feature and new notes app along with other features like the spotlight search, however some issues have plagued my macbook.
The biggest issue is that I cannot drag files around, which makes moving files very cumbersome.
Other than that, It's great and anyone who hasn't should upgrade.
Updating gets easier and slicker, updated all my family's machines, some dating back to Snow Leopard.
Did a clean install on an ageing Mackbook and it's like new.
The only glitch emerged when re-downloading a purchased app but I had a copy anyway.
Everything works fine and I like the new features (even the new Disk Utility).

row.Title: OS X El Capitan conflicting with my website

row.Sentences: Just downloaded OS X El Capitan all okay but my personal website doesn't seem to gel with this new OS.
My static photo's and logo's have all disappeared from my site, I have contacted Apple to see if they can shed any light on my problem, it was all fine when using Yosemite OS.
Has anyone else suffered similar issues?

row.Title: Good but a problem with images showing as green.

row.Sentences: I've installed El Capitan and just noticed an issue.
Viewing .jpg images in Preview causes them to appear in a solid green state instead of the image.
This seems to happen after a few seconds or if I go to the next image or if I gesture zoom in etc.
I hope this gets fixed very soon as it totally spoils the experience of having El Capitan for me as I deal with a lot of images.
Upgrade worked fine on 2008 iMac but failed completely (as did an attempted fresh install) on Macbook Air 2011 - kernel panic and failed boot loop is just not good enough Apple!

Having had problems with the Mavericks upgrade I was prepared and had a bootable backup so not a disaster, but the whole experience is reminiscent of the worst days of Microsoft and Apple quality really isn't what is used to be.

Clearly the majority of people who accept the upgrade will be happy (like me on the first machine) and I'm sure you all take a new backup before starting but don't be too surprised if it falls on its face :-(
None of my work Hard Drives are readable anymore, and seeing as they think that the repair permission is no longer necessary, I cannot repair them.
The first aid option in the new disk utility is useless and does nothing.
Thanks to this new OS I have lost the ability to do any of my work and will be trying to find a way to evert back to yosemite asap.
I am a huge fan of Apple, we are an Apple family all with iPhones, macbook pro, ipads etc.

I am sorry to say El Capitan has not worked for me at all, Since the update I have had numerous issues with my email, after hours of trying to work out what has gone wrong I can receive messages but still cannot send, a quick google and looking on the Apple Community forum shows I am not alone.
I have deleted accounts and set them up again to no avail, the new settting disappear and/or revert to something else.
I have never had a new OS cause me so much trouble.
safari and outlook 2011 keep crashing since I have installed this update.

row.Title: not mind blowing
row.Topic: Feature, Mail, N/A, Outlook, Spotlight, Update, Windows

row.Sentences: I primarily wanted the split screen facility, compose more than 1 e-mail at a time and increase in Mac performance.
I think I have the first 2 out of 3 and as I get to grips with the new OS.
Its not Apple's fault, Parallels stopped working and needed upgrading which takes time and effort to get it to version 11.
I was fortunate as I purchased in September which meant I got the upgrade for free, others may not be as fortunate.
Do you ever feel your being hoodwinked?Spotlight is very good.
I also like the additions to Notes (I'm a big user ( EverNote is over the top for what I want).
Have to wait and see what the external "Photo' goodies bring, but I do find previous and this verision very flat and uninspiring.
Mac has a way of inviting users in, and for me Photo just does not do that anymore.
Windows Outlook professional for me has alwys been very good for the business user .
Feels more integrated than Mac Mail.
I am nit picking as I like the "dashboard' feel about Outlook and not having to click open other apps such as Calendar and Contacts.
I use Mabook Air for work and wanted more productivity functionality.
I use iMac for leisure and photo is important for me.. Once things have settled and bugs removed, yes Apple you are slipping on this front, I'm sure advantages will become more apparent.
This OS is not a game changer.
Maybe we have come to expect too much from this company!
I'd like to have seen subtle changes like 'Today' button in Calendar appear in the same place as IPad and iPhone - makes working between devices a little more seamless and increase productivity.
More of us are using Macs for work and I feel more can be done on this front.
No I don't want Windows, having Parrallels/Windows on my Macbook Air fills me with dread, but needs must.
I love my Mac(s).
does not allow me to view gopro videos and pictures via an sd adapter at all:(

row.Title: Works on my late 2009 white Macbook

row.Sentences: I installed this on my late 2009 White MacBook which was running Mavericks and it is fine, I did wonder as it only has 2GB of memory but decided to go for it.
It is certainly no slower than Mavericks and has given my MacBook a new fresh look.
There was a slight blip with my email account and a certificate which couldn't be verified but that was more the fault of the email acount than the OS and was soon sorted out.
It did take a long time to download and install, about 5 hours in all, but when it finally finished it worked very quickly and I am pleased with it.
Glad I updated and hope my beloved white MacBook lives a few years yet.
Another great update!
Installed with no problems and I like the new features.

Everything runs smooth from the animations to app opening, only thing where I seem is slower is logging in, the time when you enter your password to logging in gives a slight delay which is noticable.
Also the OS crashed on me once where it displayed a black screen with warning information displayed in the middle etc.
For some reason cant download new os x system....
Why would you release something like this?
I've lost my email account and my wife's and I can't get it working again.
Very important emails concerning my daughter's medical conditions and appointments.
This is peoples lifes you are playing with.
Do not release something that doesn't work.
Sheer and utter incompetence.
Although El Capitan doesn't bring with it a huge collection of new features, it does bring a welcome boost in performance.
And the new features are ones you'll really use in your daily workflow, rather than things which sound great but never get touched.
There are also quite a few refinements, making things easier to use or just better to look at.
Installation is quick and painless.
This is the best OS X to date.
A home-run product.
This has not only stopped my Nikon transfer form working it also blocks all other photo editing software from gaining access to your photos so you are stuck with this very poor editor.
Fix it Apple I want to use the editors that I have purchased.

row.Title: Worth doing, not found any bugs yet!

row.Sentences: As others have already said, my machine seems to be a lot faster with El Capitan that Yosemite.
Not had any compatibility issues with 2011 Office, Parallels or any other third party programs.
Finally, the standard desktop wallpaper is much nicer than that of Yosemite.
Well done, Apple and thanks for not charging for it!
Downloaded this and now all my contacts are lost and none of my email accounts work!!
Call me sceptical, but is this Apples way of getting me to buy another Mac?
My iPhone is also barely useable after downloading latest software!
Rock solid so far.
Everything is smoother and faster.
El Capitan is better than yosemite.
Im using Macbook Pro 13 2011 late version but i got one issue sometime my macbook may take a bit longer time to restart.
Is that anyone facing this issues?

row.Title: Wait until they sort out the Email.

row.Sentences: I can't send any email and i get pop ups continuously asking me to enter my passwords.
When i put in the correct password it says "cannot verify user name or password" Hopeless.
I may have to go back to Time Capsule and reinstall Yosemite.
Beautifull crisp update, to an already wonderfull OS, apple really has set the bar high with EL Capitan, so smooth and responsive.
Installation was quick and easy enough, unfortunately I'm now unable to open Mail, which is a bit of a drawback.
This is on a top-spec late 2011 iMac.

row.Title: Scary at first - Check your mailboxes

row.Sentences: I downloaded El Capitan, eager to explore its new features, started off by checking that my emaill accounts were all in order and both worked.
However, all my mailboxes had disappeared, in a blind panic I tried to contact Apple Support only to read that it would cost 25 for advice.
I went instead to hopefully find a solution on Community Answers.
As a result I received a reply from a very nice man who told me to re-index the mailboxes.
Search "Reindex messages" In short I went to Finder>Go to Folder> "~/Library">V3>Mailboxes and there they were!.
I reopened Mail with finder still open and added new mailboxes written exactly as in V3 mailboxes, clicked on the new mailbox and miracle of miracles the emails had returned from obscurity.
All back safe and sound now.
Right, now to discover whats new.....

row.Title: Did not install, left with a broken computer.
row.Topic: Compatibility, Installation, N/A, Performance, Speed, Support, Update

row.Sentences: All I wanted was the promised speed increase over Yosemite, what I got was an unbootable laptop.
After an hour with Apple Support, who were lovely, we finally got my machine booted in safe mode, and I was able to re-download El Capitan.
After waiting four hours for it to install, I finally got my log in screen.
The good points:Lovely screen shot,The computer works.
The bad:Takes an age to boot up, in excess of ten minutes,doesn't always boot up,Apps take longer to load.
Oh and it doesn't recognise my printer anymore.
I am running a 2011 MacBook and am no teccy; however, it is supposed to be compatible.
I don't usually upgrade my OS so soon after release, but the upgrades worked so smoothly on my phone and iPad I got complacent.
Wish I'd left well alone.
....if you use microsoft products.
They are broken with El Capitan.
I have personal experience that Outlook 2011 does not work with an exchange server but others are reporting wider problems.
So Apple have broken it but Microsoft have failed to fix it despite months of beta testing - forget blaming each other and work on a fix.
My company forces me to use MS Exchange server so now i cannot properly reply to emails.
Might have to setup the (IMHO) horrible Mail app.
As for the rest of the updates - completely overshadowed by this fail.
I was prompted to install this upgrade and just went ahead and did it.
After the download, my iMac restarted and then it said Disk Error and forced a restart.
After 3 attempts I went into Recovery mode.
My disk was ireppairable, so a re-format and 4 hour restore from Time Machine.
I really think Apple could have built in a disk check BEFORE getting to the installation phase.
I had to leave my machine on overnight to complete the restore, but really in 2015 this is pretty basic stuff before a critical operation Apple...
I updated to OS X El Capitan once the update became available in the App Store and it has not disappointed.
It has made my Macbook Pro Retina mid 2014 even snappier and more responsive.
This was the polish that OS X Yosemite needed so badly.
I updated a couple of days ago!
I was a bit sceptical at first but now I have downloaded it I think it is epic!
I have only recently got a mac and this is a great way to start of!

row.Title: Feels like my macbook pro has had an upgrade!

row.Sentences: Opening apps and window transitions feels snappier and more responsive.
The added features to notes, photos, mail and safari are great additions
Faster in terms of performance?
Faster in terms of animations?
However that's what makes it so snappy and fast to use now.
There is no way to turn off the massive cursor when you fly between clicks.
Why isn't that an option?
Had no problems between the installation and setup.
Best update in the OSX range in terms of apperance.
New font = new look.... And its great.

row.Title: Watch out Photographers - Tetherd shooting issues

row.Sentences: Since updating to El Capitan I am no longer able to connect my Nikon D5000 for tetherd shooting.
Reading the forums is not limited to Nikons and seems to be an issue with El Capitan.
So if connecting your camera to your computer to take photos is important to you dont upgrade yet
I've been using Mac's now for 11 year's and they were great, simple to use, intuitive machines back then, but El Capitan really hit's the iSweet-spot.
It's not a massive jump from Yosemite, and things have been tweaked to make the good things, great!
I also wanted to upgrade to this version to keep up to date with Apple's security updates and the like to keep my little mac happy.
Thanks again Apple, you've made a graphic designer very happy.
The release is ruined by bugs.
Gets stuck while rebooting.
This is my 4th clean reinstall in less than week - bloody hell!
Never had so much trouble with previous OS Xs.
Desperately in need of an update to iron out issues.
Now terrified of switching off the machine now because it might get stuck during start up.

row.Title: Quite simply the best OSX update so far.

row.Sentences: Annimation stutters be gone!
Flipping between full screen apps and desktops is now as smooth as butter!
The photos app finally gains the option to add location data to photos!
Thank heavens!
Pinned tabs have proven much more useful that I initially thought they would too!
All around a great update from apple.
A major step up from Yoesmite last year.
Keep up the good work!

i decided to install the new update as i am a gamer and want a better time when i play games but on my launchpad it looks like something is installing so i click on it and there was the new update "installing' but nothing was happening i tried waiting....nothing.i tried clicking on it ....nothing and on the app store when it says download i am not able to click it .plzz some1 helppppp
"Don't install the upgrade" I said to myself.
Every time there's a frigging upgrade, your computer turns to sh*t. Didn't listen.
Installed the upgrade on my lovely macbook air.
Instantly everything's sloooowwwwwed right down.
Chrome is unusable.
The only thing I'm seeing more of is the spinning ball of disappointment.
Which, it must be said, looks a bit prettier.

row.Title: El Capitan on a iMac 24-inch Mid 2007!

row.Sentences: As I'm still using an 8 year old iMac (24-inch Mid 2007) 2.4 GHz Intel Core 2 Duo with 4GB of ram installed, I was a little apprhensive to upgrade to El Capitan after all the negativiity Yosemite received from Macusers with more current systems.
All I can say is, nice one Apple!
Everything on my system is working just as well as it was with Mavericks, but with new features and a clean and crisp look to it.
Thank you Apple for supporting owners of older Intel Macs with your newest OS, your committment to users like me will certainly influence my decision to buy a newer Mac as when I can afford to.
After reading over 18 pages of comments during the download I am completly put off installing this.

I have owned a Mac since the early 00's and never experinced any issues with OSX versions, but this one, with all the comments on Mail, Server and slowed performance = I'm waiting for the next version or iteration of El Captain.
I dont have a backup of my current OS X Yosemite so I'm just too nervous about loosing all my contacts, mail, perfromance (especially as I bought this 27" iMac only 4 months ago) and reliability.
Sorry Apple, but you have lost my confidence.
A long time advocate, shaken by the release of buggy software just becasue you promised to deliver it in the fall..... meet you promises AND your customers expectations, not one or the other.
Apple don't produce rubbish - but El Capital comes with a health warning.
Be aware that support for RAID arrays, and the ability to adjust the properties of physical drives, has been removed in this upgrade.
The impact is that if you use Disk Utility to do, well, anything useful, that the "new' Disk Utility in El Capitan does not do anything other than an automated "first aid' function.
In short - RAID support has been remove & the ability to amend/adjust read/write properties on physical drives has been removed.
The impact is that any user who has external drives in any form of array will find that their data becomes read-only.
I have uninstalled this upgrade and been forced to restore 5Tb data from my backups.
Frankly, whilst the upgrade is nice and shiny it has concurrently taken a backward step in functionality.
This is sufficiently severe for me to consider returning to a PC.

row.Title: Finally the O/S we have been asking for.

row.Sentences: Well it looks like Apple finally got thier s@t together and have produced an awesome platform, Everything just works as its should and much much quicker too.
Took just over 35 minutes to install and was problem free.
Maybe Steve Jobs was haunting the programmers at Apple over that pile of doo doo Yosemite that they dared called an operating system but rest assured Apple are most definatally back to form.

row.Title: Better but starting to play up after 24hrs!

row.Sentences: OK its a lot better than Yosemite was but 24hrs in and I've got some wierd things happening.
Password sign in boxes are appearing and dissapearing where they should not, over web pages etc.
Cant access Yahoo.
Funny messed up crazy screen blurs upon waking my computer up.
Another duff software design prematurely released?
Get these glitches fixed and its quite an impressive upgrade.
Its slick to use, seems faster and has some nice new features.
Come on Apple QUALITY QUALITY QUALITY, NOT QUANTITY QUANTITY QUANTITY!

Can you hear me Apple this upgrade is your last chance - I've already swapped the IPhone for a Samsung and am glad I did - if you dont sort your game out I'll be trying a different desktop computer next time I buy one!
I downloaded El Capitan yesterday and since then, although it hasn't set the world alight, it has successfully managed to speed up the system noticeably a lot more than Yosemite.
Everything is in its correct place and the opening of apps among other things is where you would point out where they have focussed on.
The other option of having dual windows open to fill the screen is also a huge bonus considering in order to execute tasks, this is generally a requirement for myself.

As far as it goes, with Yosemite it took me more than 6 months to drum up the courage to download it considering the poor reviews it received but this has taken me less than a day to decide to download it due to the feedback and I so far so good.
Games crash, MS Office crashes, lots of apps crash.
On the plus, the split screen is nice.
My MBP late 2011 was so slow before the upgrade.
Now is flying :) Thank you Apple!!!
Fantastic performance

row.Title: Probably the fastest OS X as yet!

row.Sentences: It's seamless, fast and efficient.
I first hesitated to download, but once done, I think it's worth the upgrade.
My MacBook Air Mid 2013 performs better, keeps quite and has a significant boost of responsiveness.
I barely hear now the fan working upon streaming full HD videos.
The full screen enhanced functionality is a step forward.
The split view, however, is something I'm not totally astonished with.
I think there is still more to be done on the way.
Overall, the machine performance has jumped to a higher level and most importantly, the battery life is now better.
The announced under the hood features are not a lie!
The download is very large, 6 + GB.
On a slow connection such as I have, it will take 24+ hours.
Surely there must be a better way of updating than this.
I have noticed that if I update my iPad by my computer it can take 6 hours, but if I update IOS directly from the iPad, the last updates took 20 minutes.

row.Title: Best Mac OS yet
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Safari, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Over the past couple of days I upgraded my 2013 rMBP and 2015 iMac (Fusion drive) to El Capitan.
Both were running Yosemite, pretty well I thought, with 16GB and 32GB RAM respectively.
However, since the upgrade I've noticed that both devices run just that little bit faster, and smoother.
Those little lags in Safari have gone and application switching is silky smooth.
The tweaks are welcome, particularly the Notes app, split view and Spotlight search.
It wasn't totally painless though.
While my rMBP upgraded perfectly first time my iMac definitely did not.
After the last post-upgrade reboot the progress bar stalled at about 90% for about 5 minutes followed by the "international no" sign.
Same thing after several reboots, so I rolled back to Yosemite using Time Machine, erased the "Untitled" partition and tried again, which worked.
Of course I wouldn't have attempted the upgrade if I didn't have a backup.
Thank goodness a polished Yosemite.
Its quick, snappier and everything Yosemite promised to be.
I've managed to hold back from the last buggy release so I was able to jump straight from the last big cat 10.9 to 10.11.
Stuck on pause.
i find since the update then my mac is running a lot slower expeshualy when i run parallels

row.Title: Am i really on El Capitan?

row.Sentences: i downloaded and installed twice El Captain, when i go into my mac page, it says im on os x el capitan, but when i open app store, it will again let me download it.
When i press download, it says i have already installed it, but it tells me to go updates page, and udpdate to 10.11 ( but i am already on 10.11) ?
So i downloaded and installed it for the second time, and i can still download it, and install it now?

row.Title: Poor, glitchy, slow.
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, Mail, N/A, Speed, Spotlight, Update

row.Sentences: El Capitan has slowed down my brand new MacBook.
Mac Mail now refuses to quit and have to force quit, emails also remain marked as unread even though they have been read.
The computer starts and shuts down slower negating the full benefit of an SSD drive.
I have not actually noticed any features in El Capitan that are drastically more useful than those in Yosemite.

It has improved spotlight functionality apparently which will be a bonus for the more disorganised user and more efficient contacts syncing, personally I was quite happy with Yosemite's abilities in these departments.
The OSX upgrade has also cause the computer to become generally glitchy, Logic Pro X which I use all the time has become slow, plugins don't respond, this may be a graphics related issue.
NVRAM and SMC resets may help but I have been unable to get results.
Overall the changes to the OSX are not great which is why it is puzzling that it seems to have had such a negative impact on the stability of my computer.
If you have any impending work or projects my advice is to wait a good while before trying this as I am experiencing a minor disaster at the moment.
absolutly an amazing update to Yosemite.
My mid 2012 macbook pro retina is so damn fast now.
and thank LORD for the transition animation of full screen for youtube or othersites.
i also want to request Apple to make the split view easier to manage as currently you have to press and hold green button to splitview.
please make it more like how splitview works in windows 10.
it looks very good and all from what i have read form the reviews but i carnt seem to dowlaod it of the app store!!!!!

row.Title: Awful: Reset and Ruined Mail, Slowed my iMac and Macbook Air right down

row.Sentences: Reset and RUINED Mail, Slowed my iMac and Macbook Air right downAll my accounts on mail, notes and contacts are gone, everything keeps crashing and everything freezing and slowing down.

row.Title: El Captain has destroyed my Logic music setup / Recording system

row.Sentences: Since the EL Captian update my most important plugins on logic dont work.
Also to make things worse my latest version of Serato will no longer work whilst running another app for recording ie.
logic / Quick time pro audio record.
Example Quick time Audio record cuts the Audio out on serato and crashes it.

All my software is up to date El Captain has destoryed my setup and to make things even worse its stupidly complcated to down grade back to Yosemite without time machine backup which I also dont like using for other reasons.
Absolute disgrace im sick and tired of this happening the only reason I have a mac is to make and record music smooth and professional this is a disgrace and is totally unacceptable.
Thanks alot Apple!
Updated to El Capitan and it crashed my system.
Had to restore from time machine.
I honestly cant tell the difference between el capitan and yosemite?

I've installed it on my MacBook Air early 2014 model, its no faster, no slower and no different?You get the updated notes app and I can do that split screen thing I know that much and apparently Safari has some changes but I use Chrome so wouldnt notice.
I wasnt expecting a massive change like what we got with yosemite but this is just weird, I took about 30 mins to an hour to update but for no reason whatssoever?

row.Title: Slick and solid so far
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, Installation, N/A, Performance, Safari, Speed, Spotlight, Update

row.Sentences: On first impressions on my early 2011 MBP El Capitan does seem much quicker and more polished than Yosemite.
The install process was done in 30 minutes without a hitch.
Everything has worked flawlessly since install.
Boot time is slightly faster.
Mission Control is *a lot* slicker.
Safari is faster and more responsive.
Spotlight seems faster to display results and apps seem to boot faster too.
It's just generally faster, which is surprising given how poor some of the recent OSX implementations have been.
The only cosmetic change I've seen so far is in Disk Utility, which has been given a nice spruce up.
I haven't found anything to criticise yet.
All in all it seems like a good upgrade and reminds me of my first impressions of Snow Leopard, which remains the gold standard incarnation of OS X.
Will El Capitan challenge it?
Time will tell.
I have to say, both El Capitan and Yosemite have slowed my macbook down considerably.
Every time I update my software it takes an age to load when booting up my Macbook.
It is a 2012 Macbook Pro with 2.9gz processor and Intel i7 so it should be fairly quick !.
does this mean that Apple are now writing bloated code like PC software writers do.
One of the reasons I switched to a mac was the speed of use, at this rate I may as well go back to using a PC.
If you could come back to me with some advice I would be grateful.
Not sure exactly whether this enriches my life, but in the process I seem to have acquired a load of unrequested and very much unwanted music files in my iTunes library.
Didn't Apple learn by their U2 fiasco that not everybody likes their taste in music?
The least they could do is ask if I want this mediocre trash on my computer but to have it force-fed to me is reprehensible!!!
Guess I'll have to go through and delete it all - thanks Apple.
OS X El Capitan is a great new operating system (I can't decide whether I like Windows 10 or OS X El Capitan better....) and I like the new Split-Screen support.
But the Wi-Fi bug still seems to be hanging around....
I can't stand another year of Wi-Fi bugs!
I would have rated OS X El Capitan 4 stars because of this bug, but it seems to occur less than in OS X Yosemite so I decided to leave it at 5 stars.
So, yes, Apple's new OS is great (I mean that), but please fix the Wi-Fi bugs!
I'm sure many other frustrated users agree with me.
Mail caused several issues after the upgrade.
Preview has also stopped working.
Buggy early release - Apple need to do better.

row.Title: On a scale of 1 to 10, its 11!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Installation, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: An update could not get better; Apple finally got it right and made the perfect Computer OS in my mind.
Installation was very swift - a tiny 30 minutes from start to finish.
Upon boot up, I found everything as it was before, so everything was good.
In addition, I am yet to find something which doesn't work on El Capitan, as it seems most if not all apps supported by Yosemite are also supported by El Capitan.
After the "system optimization' was complete (a process that takes place shortly after installation during which performance may be affected), all i could say is: Wow!
Honestly, my top-of-the-line iMac 2011 has always been fast, even during Yosemite and I never really complained, but this El Capitan speed is on another level.
Everything, and I literally mean globally everything across the whole system now has better performance, is more reliable, and is just amazing.
Everything launches nearly instantly, including apps and games.
Boot up is extremly fast, despite the lack of a fancy SSD.
All wifi issues are now non existent, with Safari loading websites faster than you can say "load".
TL;DR: YOU HAVE TO UPGRADE!
Whatever system you are on right now, you will not regret this update, I assure you.
It really seems Apple listened to all the complaints they recieved from Yosemite, and have now made the perfect OS.
Thanks, Apple!
Ok looks great but cannot download it, fine connection 90Mbps Down 20Mbps up, 8 hours and I have 500mb.

I called apple support, who kindly told me to delete the file and try again, but now the speed is at a meg a minute, on a call with support for 1 hour and we have done some things but nothing has made a difference, I am then told its my fault as its a busy time and they are providing it to a lot of people, OH MY GOD!!
if you are going to be busy GET MORE STAFF/SERVERS its a basic need and supply algorithm.
At current it will take 5 days, so I have given up and with be downgrading to Snow leopard.
After about an an hour to download & install El Capitan was up and running.
Thankfully I backed up everything first, as the install Nuked my Mailboxes, but I apart from that this is an excellent OS.
Take the plunge and install, you will not regret itWell done Apple

row.Title: Perfect
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update

row.Sentences: Having only upgraded to Yosemite a month ago with no problems despite the very mixed reviews I decided to go to El Capitan when it came out unless there were any major reasons not to.
Having seen the reviews here I decided to go for it.
The upgrade went smoothly and has improved performance.
it's faster than Yosemite and everything just works.
No wifi reconnect hiccups, no fans running constantly, nada.
I can only echo wnat other reviewers have said; this is of the standard we want and expect from Apple.
The only minor thing you need to know is that your music and movie folders don't show by default in the finder quick bar on the left of the window.
Go to Finder options to tweak this.
All in all a great upgrade.
Well, I downloaded it and thats as far as t went!
I have MBPro full spec 2013 model, never ha=d any update issues before but this does nothing, does not even install!
Seems like mixed reviews here but thats to be expected i suppose.
My experience is bad, simples.
To being with performane on my MacBookPro 2015 retina display has been improved meaning most processes are faster than what they were on OSX Yosemite.
However the bootup and shutdown time is marginally greater hence is it very noticeable.
I'm sure any new minor updates apple bring out will solve this issue(i dearly hope) as it doesnt make sense that when performance is greater the "boot" time is greater too.
I am yet to test any of the new features they have included.
Overall i would rate it 4/5.

MaBook Pro Retina 2014 - Everything completely updated Yosemite system works perfect without a problem, OS X El Capitan :( After Installation stuck several times on boot screen, re-install via recovery mode does solve the issue and then after restart stuck again.
Very unfinished and not what I was expecting from Apple...
I get two lines into writing an emal and has crashed 7 times.

row.Title: Downloaded the update but cant install?

row.Sentences: Hi All,Not sure the best place for this but Ive downloaded the update but I can run it, its just greyed out?Thanks,Chris
I downloaded and installed El Capitan today.
I lost all my email mailboxes (about 15 years worth), my contacts and my Calendar going back to the early 1990s,The helpline acknowledged the problem, screenshared and tried very hard to help.
They had met the problem before but haven't worked out how to solve it yet.
They failed to recover and go back to Yosemite from my timemachine backups on a timecapsule.
I'm waiting fopr them to come back to me.
WAIT UNTIL before installation

row.Title: Its okay but Adobe CC users be careful
row.Topic: Compatibility, El_Capitan, Feature, Installation, N/A, Safari, Speed, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Installed on Mac mini (mid 2011) 2.7 GHz i7, 8GB ram, AMD HD 6630M 256MB, MacHD 500GB (375GB available).
First a very slow installation, quite a bit of paused or blank screen during installation, which is a bit disconcerting.
All eventually installed successfully.
Takes a while to settle down and build cache data.
I recomend you leave machine on for a day or two.
Apps start a little slow the first time round, although now much improved.
Some apps like Safari seem snappier, quiting apps seem quicker to close, but overall not overly noticble from previous OS.
Finder seems improved, not encountered the dialogue window scaling issue anymore.
Still Capitan is a slower startup than Yosemite, takes a good 5 minutes.

Disk utility, there is no longer an option (that I can see) to repair disk permissions, I presume this now happens automatically?Important info for Adobe CC users, while all the CC apps seem to work (i.e.
Illustrator, Photoshop, Premiere, Edge Animate etc.)
the Creative Cloud desktop helper (the one which normally resides in the top menu bar) does not seem to be compatible as it just spins endlessly.
Whether this will prevent a periodic inability to sign into CC and disable the CC apps I have no idea.
If you are a CC user I would recomend holding off this OS for a while.
I chatted with Adobe Help, they claim that there is no incompatibility issues with OS El Capitan, but they didn't recommend upgrading OS without first uninstalling all CC apps.
They claim issues are a result of a corruption during intallation of the OS, and that you have to uninstall and install CC apps from fresh.
Haven't tried this however, but sounds plausible.
I would have given Capitan 5 stars, but droped off one start for slow start ups and slow installation, and another possible app corruptions for CC users.
I've upgraded my OS ever since I first got my first Macbook Pro which had Snow Leopard on it (I think).
Everytime I do i'm amazed at how Apple can make the best even better!
Yes, there are small "challenges' to get things working the way they were previously, but hey, we are talking about upgrading the actual operating system here.
I don't see any other OS upgrade going nearly as well for certain other software development houses (whos names shall not be mentioned here - but they start with M).
A big thank you again to Apple, for there El Capitan OSX.
Its made my system much faster and has some great new features i'll be utilising, such as the split screen - perfect.

row.Title: The only thing that's changed is Well, how it looks.

row.Sentences: Don't get me wrong - I love the new update, it's really great, no problems with it, and a lovely refreshment to Yosemite.
However, that's all it is - it just feels like Yosemite 2.0, not enough changes and not enough new tweaks.... As an update, brilliant.
As a new OS, not so ground-breaking.
I'm probably rambling nonsense, but that's what I think; very nice, thank you Apple, all grand, just next time this is what I'd expect as an update to Yosemite, not a new OS.
Perhaps there's more to it than meets my eye, but from a very standard user, that's all.
super fast, stable and new things excellent
WO can just about type this with out it slowing down to nothing!safari hardly works and getting wheel of death every 10seconds, and for some reason the mouse curser suddenly apparesr 3 inches big!!!
aaarrrggg fix it please :(
having had to restart the download / update process 3 times , finally updated .
The first and VERY OBVIOUS problem is ALL MAIL ACCOUNTS and files / folders have vanished.
I have several email accounts on this machine and they in themselves have folders for various files.
!time machine backup here we go again WINDOWS 10 is looking SO MUCH BETTERImac mid 20113.1Ghz i512Gb ramAMD Radeon 2048 MB
Just updated my mid 2010 MacBook Pro and late 2012 iMac and it could not have been easier.
Photos has even location services back.
Happy days.

row.Title: iPhoto not available in UK store

row.Sentences: Okay so it downloads okay and looks okay but I have an update to iPhoto that if I click on it won't download and tells me that the item isn't available in the UK store?
So you've removed iPhoto from UK users in this update?

I now can't look at any of my photo's as if i try and open from the application it tells me the version isn't El Capitan compatible (well there's a thing) and to update from the app store, where I get the not available in the UK message.
Pretty crap.
For many years I used Windows and for the sake of this review I used to programme Windows with C++.
I've lost count of how many PC's I've owned and parted company with.
However, a few years ago I switched to Apple mac (this is my second mac because I gifted my first one to my grandson).
I have found the OS X series brilliant.
I've had no problems whatsoever with the operating systems apart from a few apps (via the Apple Store) with a few bugs.
El Capitain has upheld the superb Apple OS tradition.
It downloaded OK and installed without fault within a few hours.
I'm writing this review from the UK.
Finally Apple is working as they should!

For the sake of a few improvements, you managed to slow down my brand new 2015 iMac, made a mess out of my emails and SMTP configurations so that I'm unable to send emails and will spend a whole afternoon trying to fix it, and also has disconfigured some basic settings which I will also have to manually reset.
All this to have a new colour pallet to the busy circular rainbow.
All installed ok, apart from the fact it disabled my bluetooth during the process so i had to remove it from my docking station.
Followed some online guidance regarding rebooting the computer in order to make the bluetooth work and it did in the end.
All the new functions in notes, calenders etc are usefull, but certainly not mind blowing.

It is an evoltion so thats fine but what I am not happy about is that most programs run a litte more slowly now, especially Safari.... it struggles to load pages, and I struggled to load this review page even.
I have a brand new macbook pro and it was operating perfectly fast enough prior to the upgrade.

I am not techy enough to know or understand why this has happened, all i'd say is Apple need to sort this out.... i can't help but feel every new operating systems are designed to uneccessarily slow the speed of your computer so you need to continuously upgrade it, and that comment would be more relevant if i have an old mac but i have a brand new one and now its slow :-(
Considering most audio producers pay premium for Audio Units to be used in Logic and other programs this is a massive oversight by the R&D team.
AU for EastWest and any Native Instruments do not work with this update.
Wait for the bugfix update in a few weeks (if they get round to it), I'm glad I checked the web and got advice before upgrading as I would not be able to work on any audio currently!
the new update are awesome, however i was a windows user until 6-7 years ago before i start using mac, and Windows have introduced these feathers about 10 years ago in Windows XP!
Hi Just want to say like the new upgrade as it is much smoother orating on my late 2007 i Mac.
I only have one dissapointment, that is compatibilaty with some of my purchashed apps will no longer work, and no updates are yet availible.
I need to use A program called smart translator every day, for comunications outside of the UK.
I have tryed other translation programs avalible on the app store instead of this one, and I am having problems with them too.
I know I am only one out of thousands, who is having problems, but it has put me off this upgrade a little.
Please bear in mind if, you have an older Imac and wish to use language translation programmes you may have problems With El Captin, and it may not be for you.
I am thinking of going back to Yosemity until these bugs are sorted.
Like I say mixed review Love the way the new ElCaptin runs just hate the bugs.
Hopes this may help some one else.
OSX El Capitan is a great system though it is nearly identical to Yosemite.
It slowed my mac down a lot and there are only about six new things.
For me I tried to resize the split view, it didn't work.
I tried to open a album on photos, it didn't work.
I am running this on my 27-Inch iMac (Late 2012) with top specs.
From 5 second boot times to about 30 seconds boot time.
I personally think that's because that this iMac is a few years old.
I would recommend if first you have a newer mac and second you are fine with the many bugs.
But if you want to have a smooth system with no bugs I would recommend to stay on OSX Yosemite until a few bug fixes come around.
Though all these bugs a little bit of an updated look which looks nice when you open up your mac.
My conclusion is that it is a great system with a few bugs here and there.
I upgraded as soon as it was avalible because the split screen functionality.
It's quite tricky to get the split screen to work and it only works with certain apps i think, windows did it alot better for ease of use.
other than the split screen ive not noticed any difference in speed or what every else tbh

row.Title: Really good update
row.Topic: N/A, Office, Safari, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Great improvement in speed and fluidity on 2011 MacBook Pro.
Had problems with Yosemite and the "beach ball', now all is snappy, like OS 8 ; ).
Safari has been fixed and is now much quicker.
Also works with Office 11.
Clearly the lengthy Beta release has made a difference, do not rush releases in future Apple, there is nothing to gain by this approach.
Download, give the computer time to reconfigure itself and you will be left with a much improved machine.
DISASTEROUS- I have lost all my email history - both personal and business,- - all the Mail setup and preferences, I have l lost my whole contact database and my calendar history.
Fellow Mac users, think carefully before you proceed!
Check the Mac forums and read of other El Capitan failures, I am not alone.
And Apple please fix the bugs PDQ and offer a recovery program for those who have shown trust and confidence in you and updated already.

Not only did the El Capitan update turn my Macbook Pro into nothing more functional than a doorstop, when in target mode and connected to my Mac Pro the internal disk is now not only unmountable and unrepairable in Disk Utility, it can't even be reformatted.
Oh yes, and I've lost all of my files.
Thanks Apple.
Broke my outlook with the spinning beachball.. seriously how difficult can it be to test a software update before releasing it..

I had to pause my download, came back to it, now its just hanging there, saying "Waiting" everything is greyed out nothing will work, Apple is really just an expensive Microsoft now, they use to be worth the premium, now everything they do is just Shoddy shoddy shoddy!!
So i downloaded the update yesterday and I can see the benefits from it already the machine its self is running very well..........
However my safari Is ridiculously slow now where as before it was awesome.

I use My Mac for my business mostly and some personal work and being able to send stuff on email is very important to me so when i try to load my emails up and can go and boil the ketel and make my self a cup of tea then drink it before the page loads up is a bit ridiculous.
( i know some of you may say thats my internet speed but im on fibre optic and i am getting 64MBPS so its definately not and works perfect on my laptop).
So i am not sure if the new safari download i got had a issue or theres a issue with the software but its VERY annoying.
Other than that tho a awesome update hence the 5*.

row.Title: WARNING - Avoid if your still using Flash CS6

row.Sentences: Haven't had time to go into the update in any depth yet, but be warned, If you're still using Flash CS6 you will have to install an old version of Java before it will run, and even then Flash CS6 is very very laggy.

It runs, but literally everything you do (selecting a new tool, mc, place on the timeline) causes the colour wheel to appear and a 5 second delay before your action actually takes effect - Very frustrating!

row.Title: Breathes new life into my old 2009 MacBook Pro

row.Sentences: Yes I am still rocking a 2009 MacBook Pro (Intel Core 2 Duo, 4GB DDR3 RAM, 320 HHD).
The last few OS X releases have ran rather slwoly on my Mac, but OS X El Capitan has completely revamped my Mac!
Its so smooth now and all the pro applications I use now such as: Xcode, Final Cut Pro, Adobe CS, Pixelmator, Eclipse, JIRA, etc..... all run perfectly.
Thanks Apple :)

row.Title: Outlook users: do not download until there is an update!

row.Sentences: I use Outlook 2011 for work (Exchange account) and since downloading El Capitan it no longer works - I just get the spinning wheel of death (which incidentally has been occurring much more often with this update).
I looked online and apparently this has been an issue since the Beta version, so it definitely should have been fixed before the release!
Now I'm going to try to find out how to go back to Yosemite.
What a waste of time!

So last night I downloaded the newe software and for the length if time it took,I was pretty sure it was just going to be basic update have more or less the same features but with a little design change but I was totally shocked when my mac loaded up.
By far the best software they have created to date offering more free apps like pages and a better iPhoto and iTunes.
You did good!
As the rural internet here is slow, started the download last night.
After the customary restart, the operating system seems cleaner and faster.
As a business I use EazyDraw and both it's integration with Mac and the speed of transfer has improved.

The Apple products may seem more expensive than it's competitors; the longevity of hardware, ease of use and fantastic support lowers stress levels when working with computers and saves money in the longer term.
"As said on eBay - recommended +++++"
El Capitan looks polished and slick on both my mid-2011 21.5-inch iMac and my 2009 MacBook Pro.
Little features like finally being able to hide the Menubar are welcome " thanks for listening, Apple!
Highly recommended.
Back up everything first to be safe, and be aware that I experienced a few glitches with Menubar, Dock and my Logitech mouse until I re-booted a second time.

row.Title: Why you shouldnt install thi syet ...

row.Sentences: I installed this and it seemed fine on the surface until I tried my Mail system , which despite being set up for manual download was automatic and I couldnt change it..
It made the add-ons in the browsers not function , ie the plug-ins for Slingbox were inoperative.
The larger cursor control was annoying at best , and varius other software incompatibilities.
ie looking at various web sites, the cursor controls had disappeared .
I will wait for the next incarnation ...

row.Title: El Capitan
row.Topic: El_Capitan, N/A, Performance, Safari, Speed, Yosemite

row.Sentences: In case anyone is doubting, I run a MBP Late 2008 model, 2.4ghz Core 2 Duo, 750 Hybrid Seagate HHD/SSD drive 8gb DDR3 1067 mhz RAM with NVIDIA GeForce 9400M 256 MB graphics card - (just for comparison of others who have the same model?
)El Capitan runs flawlessly.
It seems to be a very very cleared and polished Yosemite.
Safari runs a LOT quicker and smoother.
Logic Pro X 10.1 runs like a dream as do the other built in OS apps.
Photoshop CS6 and Illustrator CS6 run very quick.
Quark Xpress 10 seems to crash as soon as I move the cursor, I hope its not just me!
I am one of the people who had a bad experience with Yosemite and gave it a less-than-glowing review.
I happily reverted to Mavericks after that experience.
So, it was with some trepidation that I chose to install El Capitan (after making sure that I had a system backup to fall back on if necessary).
It's only been a few hours since I upgraded but I'm delighted to report that everything appears to be working just fine!
Really, not a single issue so far.
I know that the bad reviews of Yosemite reflected the real experience of many users.
Those without problems were the lucky ones.
I'm sure that Yosemite left many Mac users disappointed and pessimistic about the future of their computing experience.
If you were one of the unfortunate ones I encourage you to grasp the nettle and install El Capitan with some optimism.
Of course I can't guarantee happiness but based on my own experience you just might be delighted.
Are you feeling lucky?
Upgraded a mid-2013 11" MacBook Air and a mid-2012 15" Macbook Pro.
With the Air, no problem.
With the Pro, the upgrade erased all email (other than iCloud), caldav and carddav accounts.
"On My Mac" mailboxes were not preserved and the carddav account to an ownCloud server could not be recreated since El Capitan has a problem, it seems, with this operability.
Further, the Pro could not be restarted or shut down other than by pressing the power button.
A re-install of El Capitan failed to cure any of these issues.
Fortunately, I was able able to restore the previous Yosemite installation having taken the precaution of cloning the drive before upgrade.
The inability to restart or shut down persisted after the restore, but verifying and repairing permissions in Yosemite Disk Utility (not a feature available in El Capitan Disk Utility) cured that.
