Still work to do, then, on El Capitan judging by this experience and hence only three stars at this stage.
..... Waaaayyyyy much faster than Yosemite, and I quite enjoyed that operating system.
I have a 2011 Mac Mini i5, so I wasn't expecting much, but just having installed El Capitan today I've noticed just how much sharper and snappier my Mini's performance is.
I have upgraded my Mini's RAM to 16Gb, and I've installed an SSD a couple of years back, but crikey - this plucky little machine has picked itself up and is legging it.
I've begun to investigate some of the new features.
I'm loving the transit information for London in Apple Maps.
It's accurately taken the open-sourced journey data and overlaid bus routes, tube journeys and so forth.
Some of the national rail routes need a little work, but it surprised me about knowing bus routes in Surrey and Sussex.
Not bad for an operating system from Cupertino.
To be given a free operating system to keep my four-year Mac fresh for another couple of years is outstandingly generous - it's preventing it from being landfill.
I see some people have much older Macs running El Capitan.
If I can keep Macs for much longer than a PC, then the criticisms about Mac costs just don't stand up.
That's why my family has iPhones, iPads and Macs too.
I'm not affiliated with Apple in any way other than being a customer.
Great job Apple - thanks.
The download in Launch pad says its is paused but it won't unpause.
On the download page it says it is waiting.
24 hours later no improvement.
Presumably due to ultra-slow broadband speed in my area it has taken precisely 11 hours and 10 minutes to download this upgrade (no other devices or apps running)!
So forgive me for not doing a proper review.
I'm just thrilled it has finally downloaded at all.
I'm hoping it will be worth the wait.
At first i was very excited about the split screen this was the only thing that I have found i will use.
I thought having to update and setup icloud again very frustrating and when i did none of my contacts came through from icloud, i had to go and set it up again!!
Then when i went to my imessages all the names had not sync'd and i had to add each one to the relevant contact again.. Come on apple this shouldnt be a problem!
Since going to El Capitan everything relating to my mouse (my R. A. T 7 and apple magic mouse) are all having issues.

Issues are with tracking on the screen, when i open my appilcations folder on desktop the icon in the dock magnifies and doesn't dissapear when i click off it, mission control is ruined, when on desktop you cant click any other open fullscreen tabs.
its just bad.
It may or may not just be effecting me but I've reinstalled El Capitan and restarted my mac twice but nothing seems to work, sort it out.
Updated to El Capitan, now everytime I try to run Civilization V the game crashes due to a graphics error; thanks a lot!
I have been delighted with my 2008 MacBook Pro.
Not only does it not slow down over time (my previous non-Apple computer was terrible in this respect) but it actually gets better with time as the software improves.
Yosemite was, however, an exception to that trend and really slowed it down.
After a year with that, it's back to a great speed (even despite its age) and is running beautifully and smoothly with El Capitain.
Seems a super operating system.
Running Very Very Slow & Beach Ball Of Death, Even On Cut & Paste & The HP Scanner Is Not Work At All Now & No Update for Scanner, Sort It Out
I would highly recommend updating to El Capitan.
As many have already said, this is a refreshed and polished update to Yosemite, and it makes the whole OS experience faster, sleeker and more enjoyable.
All of my apps work fine, including Logic Pro X; Logoist 2 and Flame Painter 3 (which was actually very slow under Yosemite and now runs perfectly).
I love the split-screen view, the cursor locator and Spotlight's natural language search - they're all really handy features that I've used several times already in the past 24 hours.

Finally, as a self-confessed font geek, I was quite excited about the new "San Francisco' system font - even though it irritated me slightly that this didn't come with Yosemite, considering it was such a major visual overhaul at the time.
That being said, it was well worth the wait, and is a huge improvement in my view.
Overall, a great update that I'd strongly recommend installing!
Like the new features but I will have to go back to Yosemite due to screen mirroring not working on 2011 imac
anyone using Adobe CS4, since updating to El Capitan my Creative Suite is constantly crashing doing the most simple things.
As I am a Graphic Designer I need this software to work and am currently unable to due to the poor perforce!
You would think Apple would think of a pre-patch or something for Adobe users as I would imagine that this a large percentage of their customers.
Stop working on pointless cursor shaking or split view for 3 apps and patch the pro software!
El Capitan has lots of potential but these overlooked errors need to be addressed.
Macbook Air / iPad Mini / iPhone 5s
The 3 stars is for being a great FREE update but it's wrecked my iTunes library even though I pay for Apple Music.

Purchased my first iMac 12 months ago came pre-loaded with Mavericks, worked a charm, upgraded to Yosemite, again worked like a charm, now upgraded again to El Capitan, and guess what, works like a charm.
Well worth 5 stars.
I say this having used Microsoft products since Windows95 and would never think of going back to them.
I tried to install upgrade to El Capitan yesterday but the install failed.
It kept saying there was a problem and it was rebooting over and over again.
the only way to get it slightly stable was to start up in safe mode and then there were issues.
The wallpaper kept tearing and shearing.
In the end I reverted back using Time Machine, thank god that still worked.
Will look to have another go when the first update comes out.
After the upgrade all my accounts and emails in Apple Mail were missing.
The mboxes were in the library but nothing I did could get a connection between them and Mail.
I have a lot of accounts and importing all those mboxes and recreating accounts from scratch is not an attractive prospect.
This is not an isolated incident as others in various forums have had the same experience.
I successfully reverted to my last Yosemite Time Machine backup and will wait until the next update - which is what I normally do and should have done this time.
Never had an upgrade issue like this before and am mystified as to why it happened.
Not good but others have updated successfully so it's not a universal problem.

row.Title: Seems OK on late 2013 MBP 2.4Ghz 8Gb RAM

row.Sentences: Not much to report really; downloaded it, installed it.
Slight reduction in lag on opening apps and boot times, everything works, but I'm hard pressed to notice any specific enhancements.
Good job it was free really.
That said, given it works I should be grateful really as in the last two years Ive had some woeful Apple experiences.
Can't comment on it, can't download it!
I have a 2014 MacBook Pro and downloading it is like watching the old dial up modem procedure.
It's frustratingly bad.
Can Apple's servers deal with the demand?

row.Title: If you use Outlook 2011 DO NOT UPGRADE

row.Sentences: It doesn't work with Outllok 2011, which is a total pain, as it is next to impossible to roll back to Yosemite without being an expert in IT.

I would have expected the install process to hve analysed the application on my machine and warned me of this before going through the 30 minutes upgrade process only for me not to be able to use the most frequently used application on my machine.
Not usre if this is the fault of Apple or Microsoft, but from both of them I expect better.

row.Title: Seems slower, if anything, to me?

row.Sentences: Not sure what everyone is so pleased about.
Tiny changes really (are we really supposed to be that excited by a new font & spinning ball?)
& the thing I really needed, better performance, hasn't yet materialised on my machine (2012 mac mini).
So, none of the things that annoyed me in Yosemite seem any better in El Capitan.
Though, to be fair, many of those relate to apps (e.g.
iCal automatically completeing addresses, getting them wrong & not letting me put them right).
Still, only lost one app, that won't work (Transmit).
Hey ho.
P. S. Also wish Apple (& others) would stop putting completely meaningless "time left" notices as the software installs.
According to Apple 30 minutes is about 1 hour 15.

Another absolute mess, oh yes very pretty but main stream apps like outlook word etc hang, not enough research or testing done R & D has paid the price for profit again, but yes apple users.....ohhhhh very pretty!
i have been waiting all dfay for mine to work ?
is still 0.6 and is refusing all my password ?
keeps asking for email passwords ?
Does take a long time to boot now compared to the previus version.
I recently updated my imac and i am very happy with it.
I love the split screen because i multitask quite a bit and it is smooth.
The text looks different but better.
I have had no issues with laggy performance.
My specs 21.5-inch, Late 2013, 2.9 GHz Intel Core i5, 8 GB 1600 MHz DDR3, NVIDIA GeForce GT 750M 1024 MB 1TB HDD.
I would recommend installing El Capitan because it feels faster and has new features.
I skipped Yosemite, only installing it on launch and really disliking it, both visually and performance wise.
I decided to upgrade to El Capitan on a whim and I actually really like it (as long as SIP isn't re-enabled with future updates, and later can't be disabled by the user.)
It's smoother, some things look nicer and suit the OS.
This is the Windows 8.1 update for Yosemite (it's true....)
This really is a significant upgrade from Yosemite with all round performance improvements, together with new features.
This really is a completely optimised os x yosemite, which is basically using the beautiful interface and adding lovely new features that fit in really well.
Web browsers open instantly and everything is just that bit more easier to use.
I recommend this to anyone who comes across it in the app store.
But please beware of the very very large file 6.(?)
what happened to the app screen by swiping all the way to the left.
I checked the weather there every day and used the exchange rate app all the time and now its gone!!
Hope someone can say where it is.
Programs still slow to load I found no difference.
Yet another release that has not addressed my wifi randomly disconnecting and requiring several attempts to reconnect.
Ever since i downloaded the first Yosemite, its been a complete pain, to the point I am on the verge of throwing in the towel with Apple.
Even the online support couldnt fix and just tried to blame 3rd apps.
Funny worked fine until i upgraded.
Sorry Apple, but the default font is still a big step down from Mavericks.
My eyes started aching after five minutes!
Uninstalling and going back to the last decent OS (in my opinion).

row.Title: It is the new Mavericks!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Performance, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: Ok, the title sounds weird, but if you read my review, you'll understand why I said that.
Oh yes, OS X El Capitan is so, so, so much better than that abomination of OS X Yosemite.
When When I got my MacBook Air (Mid 2013) back in May 2014, it was shipped with Mavericks.
Mavericks was gorgeous, smooth and responsive.
However when the Yosemite update came out, I was so unsure on whether I would get it or not.
The UI looked meh, a bit ugly in my opinion.
I got it since it was a free update.
When it downloaded and installed, I tried to like it for one whole year but I couldn't appreciate it at all.
It was laggy, ugly and took most of my storage space up.
I was so desparate for the El Capitan update to come out.
(I couldn't reinstall Mavericks because it wasn't "purchased".)
When I downloaded the package and installed it, it was a quick setup and off I go!
The UI is still meh but I can actually appreciate its ugliness.
Quick, glossy and usable.
I like the new font too, it suits OS X very well.
Good work Apple, good work.
Frankly two main things are worth the upgrade: animations are now faster (app to fullscreen, minimising, etc.)
and Spaces now behave more sanely.
Old Yosemite use to switch Spaces with an external monitor if opening a new app, that pain is now gone.

row.Title: Just what the Yosemite Doctor Ordered

row.Sentences: This is the much needed update that Yosemite needed.
I persoanlly didnt have too much trouble with Yosemite however I did notice the speed decrease afrer moving from Mavericks.
All in all, there isn't any reason not to update.
Few litltle easter eggs to be found and some minor visual changes all add up to a great update worth downloading and installing.
Hit the download button, then click the install button, go watch some Breaking Bad and come back to a fresh machine you actually love using again.
Thanks Apple as always, Free OS that works well.
Yet another great FREE update.
Fast and reliable so far.
Great improvements to Safari and the new font looks great.

row.Title: Wasting a whole day trying to get it working

row.Sentences: I downloaded El Capitan, but then when the system was shut down, it wouldn't reboot.
The apple appeared on the screen without any movement from the progress bar.
I left this for an hour without any movement.
I have downloaded the software twice and have been sitting here for a whole day trying to brainstorm the problem.
Wish now that I had waited and stayed with Yosemite instead of rushing like everyone else to get the new thing.
APPLE did good job .... realy good job .....almost perfect system is even better now

row.Title: Nice features but breaks existing software

row.Sentences: I like the new features in El Capitan.
However, I use my iMac for photo editing and it has some serious flaws here:- My Apple Aperture software now loads photos with way too little contrast.
This makes editing them a matter of guesswork, at least for saturation and contrast.
(When exported they show up fine).

Now I know Apple have announced that they have discontinued developing Aperture, but a new OS shouldn't break it and the Photos app has nowehere near the functionality I need.- My plug-ins to Aperture now don't work (I use Topaz Labs).
There two issues make this an unusable platform for me for photo editing.

row.Title: Very fast - otherwise maybe its your internet?

row.Sentences: I have installed El Capitan this morning without any fuss and I must say that it has been the smoothest and fastest installation I have done with OSX.
It took a little time to download and then installed in 20 minutes.
Yes, for security, I appreciate re-entering and setting up passwords with iCloud and some mail, but seriously, El Capitan seems to be so much faster and lighter on my system.

I did a Time Machine backup before installation with the intention of erasing the HDD and installing afresh, but I clicked on the upgrade and it was so clean and smooth, that I don't think I will bother with a fresh installation now.
My software is working fine and it is working perfectly and faster.
Thank you Apple!
Everything else seems to be working fine, however the split view function just will not work.
Im running El Capitan on a Macbook Air 13" 2013 model.
Ive tried the holding down the green button, ive treid full screening an app and then dropping a new app into the window via mission control .
Very unimpressed as this was one f the features that would have made my working day so much more productive.
UPDATE - If you cant get split view to work just go to preferences>Mission Control and check the box that says "screens have seperate spaces'.
The log out and back in and BAM!
Split View works
El Capitan is a huge improvement over Yosemite, everything is much faster and smoother than the previous version.

The updated Notes application is excellent with the ability to add photos, checklists etc, and all the little add ons to Safari, Mail and all the other apps make this the best release of OS X in years.
I hope that Disk Burning comes back to Disk Utility, but that's the only bad thing I have to say about this release.
Some great features, I particularly like the right-click to rename files (finally!
), the split screen apps, the improved spotlight with natural language.
Note: I did encounter one annoying bug which took a couple of hours to work out the issue and resolve it.
AFter installing El Capitan the App Store app, the Maps app and iTunes all had connection problems.
After searching on Google and Apple's Developer forums I discovered this affected other users too - you can fix it by deleting the Verisign certificates from Keychain.
Seamless upgrade and big big performance boost well worth the upgrade..

Downloaded a few hours ago & so far everything certainly appears OK. That's far more than I could say for Yosemite which was absolutely awful & trouble right from the off (I reverted back to Mavericks).
First impressions are great, it's clear with some great new features & is simple to use (still not convinced with Photo though, but perhaps when I get more used to it, that opinion will change).
The install / changeover was also a breeze, so all told I'm pretty happy so far.
(Installed on a roughly 2 year old, 13 inch Macbook pro with solid state memory).
This update has slowed my iMac down so much, all i see now is the new colourful spinning wheel keep appearing!!!!
!knew I shouldn't have upgraded :(
I'll currently downloading, so, when i install i'm gonna say what i am thinking about this new update, but i see the most people like it!
all applications just crash!!

row.Title: Should warn you that you're going to lose information

row.Sentences: I lost everything i had in notes!
Plus the features in this are not out of the ordinary!
it alreadye exists its just a little bit different here thats all.
OS X El Capitan is really snappy at speed.
My MacBook 2015 can load everything faster.
The new features it holds can really be useful.

row.Title: she's just this minute standing unsupported...

row.Sentences: .... having stumbled and grumbled in reaching my yard, only to greet me with verbose wails, some punchy prose about my iMac and late-to-bed house-mate both being at fault, rounding downloading with ID fails, iCloud fails, and two trash crash report retorts (obfuscating the first true view of our newly beloved Kernel In Charms) for my attention and precipitation of course, so i miss the pomp and fireworks.

but so what, nothing can stifle this lads new due derision of Windows, always a pleasure, bar one gnawing great niggling, eliciting giggling, the planet's OS Flagship, USS El Capitan, "jumping the shark', in the dark, one hand on the tiller, the other holding it's own hideous helping of "Ice Cream Sandwich'.
here's hoping next week's 10.11.01 Security Update care dare strap on a pair.
and if not, c'est la vie.
still ain't a PC!
Just like Snow Leopard, a most welcome clean-up.
It's fast, bug-free and fine-tuned.
This update is fantastic!
Everything is running so smoothly!
Fresh install, running like a dream.
Yosemite was unbearable and really sluggish so went back to Mavericks for the last 12 months.
El Capitan is a massive improvement and well worth it.
For me it works as I have 6GB of RAM installed and changed to a SSD if anyone else with an old iMac is considering it, I'd say the hardware upgrades are essential.

row.Title: This is Why I Bought a Mac

row.Sentences: No doubt about it OSX wins over other OS's.
Liked Yosomite but this well, lost for words.
GAME CHANGER
After having troubles with Yosemite installation on both MacbookPro and MacbookAir I have installed El Captain on my Air without any problems.
Although it seems that there is faster battery drain than in the case of Mavericks.
Anyway.... good, stable system.

row.Title: OS X El Capitan With Stunning Features

row.Sentences: OS X El Capitan Consist some stunning features with greater performances such as new Spot Light Searches , Drag and drop features in new Misssion Control & improve notes with New mail features.....
I'm strongly recommonding this OS X El Capitan updates for mac users.... :)
Excellent update to an excellent OS.
And free is always welcome.
Thanks, Apple.
As always another brilliant software from Apple.....
Very good improvements in basic things which we tend to use everyday.
my macbook has become faster !
and can feel the change :)
No major negative changes since Yosemite, and overall a much cleaner interface!
Not bad, not bad at all
New mac OS X is much better than last OS 10.10 Yosemite.iCloud issues with notes is resolved now and safari provides a new experience.
Photo sharing is very easy among all the apple devices.
Mission control can easily shows all the opened windows.
What can I say its better than the last update.
So far it's awesome.
At first look it looks great, easy to use and loads very quickly.
Nothing to complain about so far!
I can feel the extra performace!
Loving the new spotlight and launchpad
Brilliant, love it.
Macbook flies with this now!!

row.Title: So far seems a pretty solid update!

row.Sentences: Ive been using El Capitan for the last few hours and so far ive noticed a much faster performace definatily in Safari!
It seems to open webpages in a instant and ive never seen that before im really happy!!!
I havent noticed much of a speed improvement in anything else yet id say its around the same as Yosemite but its only day 1 haha.
The new San Fransisco Font gives your mac a fresh new look and overall that was a good addition :) So overall i think anyone unsure should update to El Capitan for sure!
Performace seems good and theres plenty of new helpful features added.
Yes you shluld update!
First imprssions after first 10 miniutes of use, its fast.
Noticeably faster than Yosemite.
Trackpad no longer works after installing El Capitan (on a mid 2015 MBPr)
Just downloaded and installed it :0 playing around with the new features and loving it.
Im liking the faster response times on my mac.
The rename feature on documents is so overdue but oh well...
Brilliant work Apple.....

Well, I am still on the public beta, downloading the full release, but this is so much better, it was a great update, with Yosemite I just felt a bit of instability, this update has changed that, I love El Capitan!
OSX feels like OSX now!

row.Title: Great update to Mac OS X

row.Sentences: I've been through a lot of OSX versions, and this one seems like a huge improvement already.
I'm hoping it's the new Snow Leopard 10.6.8 in terms of Stability.
Installed no issue at all runs great getting beter performnace on my 4GB RAM Mac Mini 2014

row.Title: Yosemite refined
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Performance, Safari, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: OS X El Capitan is the polish that Yosemite so dearly needed.

I've been running this since the first Public Beta on both a 2012 MacBook Pro Retina (i7 Quad Core, 16GB RAM, SSD, Intel HD 4000/NVIDIA GT650M) and a 2008 MacBook Pro (Core 2 Duo, 4GB RAM, HDD, NVIDIA GeForce 9400M/9600M GT) .
Both machines run beautifully.
Gone is the UI lag that plagued Yosemite.
Apps run much better and the system as a whole is quick and responsive- even if you're using a hard disk and not a solid state drive.
2012 and newer machines are able to use Metal, a new graphics API from Apple which allows for higher performance graphics, further increasing performance.
Safari 9 has some cool new tricks up its sleeve too, although it's now available as an update for Yosemite making it somewhat a moot point.
The only qualm I have with El Capitan is the new Disk Utility app.
Put simply, it stinks.
Well that isnt totally fair, but I do find it lacking compared to the old version.
It adds a few new features but removes a lot more and is generally buggier and less useful than the "classic' Disk Utility app.
For a power user such as myself who deals with lots of disk images and hard disks this is a sticking point, but for your average user its a non-issue.
This is absolutely an ESSENTIAL upgrade for any Mac user.
Yes, even those of you still hanging onto 10.6 Snow Leopard for dear life.
And you couldn't have picked a better time.
Its ok nothing groundbreaking or exciting by the looks of it.
It would've been awesome if we had Siri on our Macs too or the ability for the iTunes to start off where you left off from a mobile device :/ Grr
This update is better in every singe way!
The new split screen is one reason to update alone let alone all the other features!
If you use your mac for prductivity the duel screen make it so much better/faster/easier.
Also say good bye to loosing your cursier with a quick rasional swipe "BAM' it right there!
WOULD 100 PERCENT RECOMEND THIS UPDATE!
Well done apple, amazing job.#FirstReview
Fast, stable and gorgeuous !
Where do we find the "distort extension" in Photos ?
Split screen is just what I need!
The ability now to hide the dock and menu bar to allow me to use the full screen without having to adjust windows etc.
Great upgrade
El Capitan does for Yosemite what Snow Leapard did for Leapard.

row.Title: A peak within the Yosemite range...

row.Sentences: The clue is in the name - El Capitan being a peak within Yosemite.
This is not a radical new direction for MacOS, but rather a honing and sharpening of many of the features we already love, although yes there are a few new ones.

All the improvements are in the right direction though, and on my first machine upgraded.... a MacBook Pro that has seen a little action shall we say.... they are all in the right direction and all appreciated, perhaps even a new lease on life.
Overall, and so far, impressive.
I didnt think you could perfect perfection, but that is just what apple have done!
The new OS X Is SO much better!
The simple things do the most!
My mac is running like a new laptop!
Fast, fluid and furious.
A great update.
Finally a well refined OS, I think it's great all around, Safari just officially kicked my Chrome out, kudos.
This is by far the best thing in my life, my 5 bed semi in chelsea, the aston, the private beaches in the bahamas are pale in comparison to the greatest operating system in the world, I love apple
Thanks for making this upgrade free & available for most of OLD MACs .
Performance wise it has gave a minor boost.
Un-noticeable, but it has made my Mac more powerful!
easy install
Im first to review this os.it is ok
the best apple software to date
I really like it

row.Title: Amazingly fast on an 8 year old iMac!

row.Sentences: Running on iMac 24" mid 2007 - machine is now faster than when new, no problems with installation or existing apps

row.Title: Great but magic mouse still disconnects!

row.Sentences: Love the update but why oh why does my mouse still disconnect randomly.
Still not fixed since the start of yosemite!
on my retina iMac.
OS X returns with a fast and slick update.
There's not much else to say really.
It's the OS X you know and love refined, and it's free.
El Capitan is a very good update, but the most interesting thing about it isn't the features, it's the philosophy behind them.
Take Split View, which extends the existing full-screen feature and lets you have two apps side by side, thus allowing more diversity among taks.
This makes for a more refined mac experience.
El Capitan builds upon the flowering relationship that makes the user and the Mac more personal and cooperative.
Its all about that experience which makes Apple lead the pack in user interaction, and best of all it's free.
So update and climb upon El Capitan.
It mountains above the rest...
It's not a revolution but a very needed evolution!

It's snappier, more convenient to use in forms of handoff, free of the annyoying Yosemite WiFi bug (which I couldn't eliminate until today) and some important imporvements to Notes that have been my primary note-taking app over the years.
Performance is much better in this update, and the new features such as shaking the mouse to see where the cursor is are great aditions!
Great software update.
Nothing major fromm OS X Yosemite, hence the name El Capitan.
But a good update nonetheless with some essentials added.
Particularly the split view
Quite simply the best O. S.system to date.
Clever tweaks have now made it a pure pleasure to use and as we all know a mac is reliable and powerful, but this takes it to another level.
SIMPLY AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!
Brilliant new os
It's amazing, it changed my life and made me a better person.
Stable, powerful and great fun to use - love it.
Been waiting for the El Capitan features for some time now; since iOS 9 came out and spoiled us with the split screen on iPad.
Great job Apple!
Had an opportunity to look at it already....
It truly is an exceptional system.
I love the revamped notes - finally!
Some nice improvements to speed and productivity.
Already looking forward to next year's OS X update.
Siri is erratic and hard to get working.
I spend more time getting tech back up then working sometimes.
I'm thinking I may revert to PC.
My Lenovo at the office works just fine-sure it has clunky features, but at least it functions without constant hours spent with tech.
I have been having trouble with my ibooks application lately.
Every single time I try to open it, it crashes or it just gives me the swirly curser.
I have my Apple computer and ibooks so I can utilize them, but unfortunately I am unable to because of the glitches that Apple has not fixed.
I am seriously dissappointed and beyond frustrated.
I am thinking about switching to a different platform because Apple is not living up to itself.
Hopefully they can try to fix the issues....
I'm not sure that Apple is worth it at this point.
I was nervous about upgrading because of all of the hate that this software has been getting, but honestly, I should have upgraded sooner.
El Capitan is amazing.
Apps open much faster and I don't get the spinning wheel as much as I did on Yosemite.
Having two programs open in one window is especially useful.
My computer logs in much faster.
I haven't had any issues with El Capitan, and I have been using it for a few days.
If you're considering upgrading, but are nervous about it because of the rating this program has been getting, I would recommend using Time Machine to back your computer up.

row.Title: Installer hanging on brand new Macbook Pro

row.Sentences: Spending my Sunday trying to install from a clean disk.
Not what I had planned for today.
It's pretty unbelievable the OS doesn't install on a current generation machine.
I have the latest iMac, and it is now unbearable to use.
I have to wait 5 seconds after every click I make.

row.Title: works well but features are nothing special

row.Sentences: Before downloading El Capitan, I upgraded the memory on my 2009 macbook pro from 4gb to 8gb.
Some applications seem more zippy, in fact.
As for the new features, none are particularly useful to me, especially since I don't have other Apple devices (ipads, iphones).
"Notes" - a gimmick; "Maps" - good; "Spotlight still strikes me as a useless search engine with features that are poorly defined.
For example, what does Spotlight consider to be a "document"?
(Does a comma delimited text file count as one?)
Apple assumes that nobody would ever ask.
Spotlight's ability to understand natural language is poorly defined and unreliable.
I would much prefer a dialog laying out Spotlight's capabilities and allowing me to precisely specify what I want to locate.
As with so many things Apple does the goal always seems to be to get you to do everything the Apple way with Apple products and not think much for yourself.
The Apple effort to make things simple and intuitive has the opposite effect.
It is a false simplicity creating a situation where you never really know precisely what is going on.

row.Title: Been using MacOS since 1985- this is making me reconsider Windows

row.Sentences: Wow, what a buggy piece of junk for virtually no gain.
For decades, one of the main strengths of MacOS was its stability.
I could go weeks without a system hang or crash and would restart my computer only when I felt like too many background processes were stacking up and slowing down the works.

Now, with El Capitan (running on a 27 in late 2013, 3.2 GHz i5 with 8 GB memory and 1 TB HD), the system hangs at least daily, almost never wakes up from screen sleep without crashing and requiring a restart (via the power button- seriously?
), and is generally slow to respond.
Apple, this is a disaster.

row.Title: Don't do it if you don't have too.

row.Sentences: I am a HUGE apple fan and have NEVER had issues with anything.
This update has been a PITA......
I still have issues 6 weeks later that Nobody can seem to figure out.
For instance, I now have to restart my computer one or two times per day as my safari starts acting up and I can't type or anything to get anywhere.
I have also had issues with webpages loading and timing out that seem to go away if I restart.
Before this update my 1 year old imac only needed restarting once a month!
Their are other small issues too.
But, I don't see anything in the update that made it my computer any better for the most part.
I wish I would not of upgraded at this point.
I have spent HOURS on the phone and had to do reboots, re-installs etc.....
Sorry Apple.
I thought I had waited long enough for Apple to get the kinks out before upgrading, but I regret the upgrade.
My 6 month old MacAir was running wonderfully before the upgrade.
Apps would open immediately and respond quickly once opened.
Now, the "infamous" beach ball spins and it can take up to 2 minutes for Safari to open.
I could care less about the "features" if the apps are not opening efficiently.
I'm not sure how long one should wait to upgrade, but hopefully Apple is working to remedy these issues, especially during the busy holiday time.

row.Title: Just updated from Mav... it went just fine. Great OS

row.Sentences: Not sure why the ratings have been poor, but I am extremely pleased with El Capitan and the process to download/install.
Just backup, take precautions and get it done.
Simple, straightforward and way better in my opinion.

row.Title: Leaves MUCH to be desired!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Feature, N/A, Office, Performance, Safari, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: El Capitan has really slowed my machine down!
It does not filter tracking cookies no matter how you set your preferences.
The color pin wheel shows up constantly while working MS Office - even during simple cut-and-paste operations!
I also get it when trying to do something simple - like logging on to the App Store, or opening Safari!
The OS fills the waste basket with folder after folder of "Recovered Files."
As I said earlier, it has slowed my computer to a crawl at times!
It can take over 1/2 minute just to shut down!
I do not run intensive games on my machine, and am running McAfee to keep it secure from viruses.
Wish I could go back to Yosemite!
UPDATE: El Capitan is making my computer slower as time goes on, while acting a a "magnet" for tracking cookies!
It has now crashed 3 times in as many days while trying to use Adobe Photoshop Elements - as well as creating havoc among my Epson drivers!
When will the upgrade come out so we once again have an OS that is truly worthy of the Apple name?UPDATE 2: El Capitan has become one slow nightmare!
Although I clean tracking cookies after each use, Safari has begun crashing daily!
Yes, I send reports to Apple each time it happens - but nothing has changed so far!
Now I even get the spinning beachball and "hiccups" just scrolling through Facebook!
It feels like I have gone back to using a Microsoft product!
Please, Apple - where are the patches if no update is soon forthcoming?
Works wonderfully and just as I expected.
I have a problem with running final cut pro 10.2.2 on this version on os x.if its the final versin so what can i do?

row.Title: Upgrade file is huge. Wifi is fast, but download takes HOURS!

row.Sentences: Okay, I live in the sticks....
Rural is putting is lightly.
So, I don't have Internet access unless I use a Satellite wifi connection which has limited data usage.
So, I drive into town to use a high speed broadband connection so I can download El Capitan.... (meanwhile, the theme from Jeopardy looms in background- for 3 hours).
I hope this upgrade is worth the time I've spent just to download it!
I'll install, use and report back - that is, after I trek back home to where the bear, deer, fox and jack rabbits roam.... to be continued.

row.Title: Really? Why all the hate? Are you Serious?

row.Sentences: Because when you DEPEND on your computer for for livelyhood and you endup wasting time and losing MONEY - you will HATE THIS UPDATE!
Also, when you have 2302 ratings - 3 stars and higher vs. 3494 ratings - 2 stars or less - THERE IS AN ISSUE!
When you have to spend (waste) time trying getting the OS to work so you can do your jobIT IS NOT FREE = I have lost HOURS of my time trying to get this poorly implemented OS to work.
And there also the joy of finding something else wrong.
Who do I send the bill to for my lost time and money?
I was doubting on if i should get it, there are many bad reviews, but i downloaded this anyways.
I haven't installed the newest version yet but the one i currently have works really well.
It does make my screen brighter and more HD, so it is a bit hard adjusting, but my Mac doesn't look the way macs did back in 2012, it looks alot different and I really like it!
The update is very slow, but it was worth it, but my mail is a bit strange, won't show me my mail or receive any.
But I still recomend it, I did install an older version, not the 10.11.1, as it is still new and i know new things usually have slight problems, so thats why i waited to add this version I use.
I always try to wait for the 10.x.5 release before I upgrade.
I thought that since this one had so few changes that I could jump in earlier.
Computer has crashed several times in two weeks.
Apps crash as well.

row.Title: An immense improvement over Yosemite - but still too flat.

row.Sentences: I hated Yosemite and found it completely unusable.

El Capitan is considerably better, but nowhere near as intuitive or attractive as older iterations of OS X. I'd rate it well below Mountain Lion or Mavericks in most respects, but if you have a contemporary Mac, this is the OS you want, not Yosemite.

I don't know if I'd upgrade on a Mac that could still run Mavericks - probably only if you need to run software that requires the later OS - but on any Mac bought in the last year or so this is a no-brainer.
El Capitan worked well at first, maybe a few minor pauses while using Youtube, but nothing too bad.
Then the pauses got worse and worse and now I have to restart my computer on the daily if not more.
It's like the screen gets stuck and can't process anything after the initial hiccup, causing it to either freeze on the current screen until it's manually restarted or it crashes on it's own.
Altogether I am thoroughly unimpressed, I feel like this OS is the Beta or even Alpha version of what El Capitan was supposed to be.
It needs hard core debugging.
I wrote a very long, detailed negative review and somehow I don't see it here.... Apple, stop focusing on new "innovation" if none of it is going to work.
I didn't pay close to $2000 for a laptop that trips over itself doing basic tasks.
I've been using Apple products for a decade and I don't think I will be anymore.
I wish I had my old white 13" macbook from 2006.
But the Genius bar refused to service it after a few years, they considered it a "vintage model" and I was basically forced to buy a new one.
Well, i took a chance and installed this and wish i hadn't.
My iMac is definately slower and i don't really see any improvements.
The only bad thing that's happened so far is that my clock and other parts of my menu bar are frozen.
Not a huge problem but not the buggy behavior one would expect from Apple at this point.
Personally I don't see that much different from this and Yosemite.
One thing I'm annoyed about however is the disk utility app being altered drastically and the verify/repair permissions being completely gone from that application.
Very annoying that you have to type the commands out into Terminal, you know, where you're like 400% more likely to screw up your computer by typing something wrong accidentally.
I think my mac got slower now too, it shouldn't be giving me the pinwheel every time I try to open an application.

row.Title: Open Letter to Apple (or the monkeys who programmed this)

row.Sentences: Your system crashes Microsoft Word v.15.16, causing me to lose my progress.
This hasn't happened once, twice, or even three times-no-it has occured on at least five seperate occassions.

Law school final exams are stressful enough, but when I make small, yet crucial, changes to my 50-page document only to see your "pinwheel of death" and then Word crashes (before I can save or be saved by autosave), it is an added stress that I do not need.
Sloppy work.

row.Title: Preview can't zoom PDFs as far

row.Sentences: Can't zoom in as far in preview when opening PDF files.
If you keep zooming in the screen goes blank.
As a person who needs PDFs constantly this is incredibly annoying.
Feels like im back on a PC

row.Title: No Problems, little improvement
row.Topic: Airdrop, Download, El_Capitan, Feature, Mail, N/A, Office, Performance, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I run a mid-2011 MAC, nothing special, with MS Office installed.
I was running Mavericks and skipped the Yosemite update, due to all the bad press.
The update on a Saturday, took about three hours to download and process.
It also required three updates to be installed shortly after the operating system came up.
I didn't have to restore Office.
Photos all ended up in the same albums in "Photos" instead of "iPhoto".
I needed to revalidate the POP server in "Mail" inorder to send mail, but this was no issue.
The installer seemed to remember all my "settings" down to the wallpaper image.
The speed of the MAC is fairly unchanged.
At first I thought it ran slower, but the applications seem to have returned to normal.
I don't see much difference from Mavericks, given the basic use.
The GUI boxes are very plain now and boring, but I suppose that's just fashion and not performance.
Disappointed that my dinosaur MAC can't use Airdrop with iPhone, as that would have been useful.
There is probably stuff under the hood that makes El Capitan better, I guess.
At any rate, the update worked perfectly, and the performance did not degrade.
In my book, that counts for a great deal.

row.Title: Worst in the internet connectivity!
row.Topic: Airdrop, Feature, Installation, N/A, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I am apple customer since iOS 5.1.1!
and Always loved apple products!
but after upgrading to this OS, I changed my mind.
first, it was easy to install (as it was!)
but after installing, I faced some issues in wifi!
my laptop (MBP late 2013) couldn't establish a network connection and get ip address from my router, I searched about this on internet and tried everything I could, but without any success!
even assigning static ip address didn't worked.
also I had problems with air-drop and handoff!
so I decided to downgrade to Yosemite.
I have notice that there is still small here and there bugs.
For example going to the top dock i notice that it takes awhile for it to load up, or to be entailed when i point the pointer to file it has to load.
In hinsight it isnt loading along with everything in the OS X, or is it like the issue with windows 10, where the start menu isnt really intergrated rather its a layer within the OS?
If there is a way to fix that, also fix the boot up.
(the loading bar is so old and its so boring to watch) it would be a solid 5 in my book.
Nice job.

row.Title: Updated from Lion OS with success

row.Sentences: After being so many versions behind and having skipped Mountain Lion, Mavericks and Yosemite, I took the plunge and updated my last 2009 iMac to El Capitan.
Suffice to say, the update was flawless.
My machine runs smoothly and as fast as it has ever run.
I just had to update my dated VMWare Fusion and Carbon Copy Cloner apps and I am now totally functional again.
I was really excited for El Captian.
However, I wish i never updated to it.
It slowed down my Macbook Pro significantly.
Opening apps takes minutes to open, microsoft office is specifically slow as well, and my macbook runs hotter than it ever has.
I'm very disappointed, this update truly questions whether or not my next computer purchase will be an Apple again.

row.Title: Excellent OS -> Late 2014 Brand New MacBook

row.Sentences: Bought my Laptop Late 2014, came with Yosemite.
I installed El Capitain with no bad experience at all.
The OS is better, with faster loads, great overall user experience, little UI differences, the split view is a plus.
Upgrade highly recomendable.
No major issues on Mid 2010 iMac, some apps were dragging just a bit after install, added an additional 8 GB memory, everything seems smooth now.
Based on the negative reviews, I was pretty intimidated to download El Capitian to my late 2013 Desk Top and my mid 2012 Mac Book Pro, but it went fine!
In fact, I don't see a gigantic difference.
The graphics are great, I like that I can swipe left to delete mail, but I stil like gmail better and wish that apple would sort incoming mail as gmail does.
I am trying to like safari better than chrome, but so far chrome still wins.
I like the new look in notes, but lost my outlook express calendar sync from work.
I am sure I can figure it out.
There have been a few other small issues but it's all about the learning curve.
Nothing huge as some people wrote for me, thank goodness.
Not slower but about the same as Moutain Lion was.

row.Title: Apps not working since the Update

row.Sentences: I have several apps that I have purchased in the app store that no longer work along with a few apps like Suitecase fusion 3.
I am not sure if it was because of this update or not.
I was using OS X Yosemite before and everything was fine until I updated to OS X El Capitan.
My Macbook Pro is the 2013 version, but once I updated for couple of days, it began to freeze frequently.
I had to visit Apple local store but they did not know how to fix it neither.
So they had to send my Mac out to get it fix, which I was okay with that.
The problem is once I got it back, my Mac started to slow down.
I am not sure anymore if I can trust the update or the crew ever again.
I started to download this update, and then began to read the reviews.... yikes.
There are more one-star reviews here than any other update - and the reviews consist of ruined computers / data/ etc.... Needless to say, I stopped the download immediately.
However, I desperately need to update my system in order to run some programs - so now I'm impatiently waiting Apple to release ANY news about their obviously flawed update.
How can a company this huge not release ANY statement whatsoever about this update?
Are you guys just sitting over there pretending everything is fine?
Maybe in some one-in-a-million chance one of your people will see this and realize you should probably do something about this.... Release a statement.
Release a new version with fixes.
Or the least you could do is make the Yosemite download available again?
Do you need me to work on your PR team - what's going on over there you guys?
Things that "just worked" don't!
SMS message sharing between my iPhone and iMac"broken!
Disk icons???
Random freezes, locked outs, forced restarts.
Internal CD no longer recognized!
Support forums are useless.
Can no longer recommend Apple.
Fix this mess.
Late 2010 iMac, 8GB RAM.
downloading this new update was a pain and now my sound doesn't even work anymore.
i have checked the settings and everything else and i will turn up the volume but nothing will happen!
i can't even hear through headphones!
I did a clean install of El Capitan to make sure that nothing from the beta was left and I still get crashes half the time the computer goes on sleep.
I find the screen black, the case very aluminum case very hot and need to reboot.

Safari has issues streaming videos with aweful framerate so I use Chrome.airdrop never ever work (same on iOS actually and with anybody)iTunes became a nightmare to navigateYou have to drop pictures from Photo app to the desktop to be able to use them anywhere else.gonna stop here..

row.Title: Not too much of a change but still a good one

row.Sentences: I have a 2013 MB Pro.
I updated to this today and I find that my computer is running more quickly.
It starts up quicker than with Yosemite and it has seemingly fixed my issues with Mail.
Some of my issues with iCloud seem resolved as well.
I won't lie, I have become less and less of an Apple fan over the last few years.
It used to be that you could count on new software and hardware to "just work" and be secure.
Now, I wonder what I am going to get with every update on my computer or on my phone.
It feels like a toss-up and one I am not sure I want to continue to make after I am ready for my next big technlogy purchase.
My late 2009 iMac now has so much latency it is unusable for anything except as an external monitor.
I don't know what you guys did to safari but its crashing every 20 minutes!
I've been losing work continuously!
This update has certainly slowed my system down and is not what I've come to typically expect from Apple.

row.Title: What Were You Guys Talking About!!!!

row.Sentences: After all the reviews I looked at before I got the update was a little worried to get it.
I uptaded from OS 10.7 and mine worked perfectly.
This update si everything it told us in the description.
Get this update its a good one.
I have been using El Capitan for over a month and LOVE IT.
Mac OSX gets better with every update.
I am surprised by the negative reviews.
One is more likely to enter a review if they have a negative experience.
The only problem I've had is that a handful of applications would not launch.
I just tossed them in the trash and reinstalled from App Store and that immediately fixed the problem.
The transition from iPhoto to Photos does take some adjustment, but I really like it now and the integration with the accompanying image manipulation apps which are becoming available is really nice.
Overall, this OS is more polished than before.
I watch my system logs frequently and see much less spurious messages.
My experience has been very good with this update.
I am not a geek nor an IT, just a plain user who thought the update to El Capitan would have an improvement overall.
Its appereance is very slick but performance is very very slow compared to my OS X.
Used it for a while and then reverted to OS X.
Needs improvements in terms of speed.
Also with OSX it was easier to import my pictures directly from the camera to an external disk without the need to go into iphotos.
It took me a whole night of frustration to finally learn how to.
Needless to say there was no info in the Internet regarding this procedure.
I would go back to El Capitan after improvements.

row.Title: LOVE IT! Apple did it again!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, Installation, N/A, Performance, Speed, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: I've had to deal with Windows for years, and, although now I use both Windows and Mac, I definitely would take a Mac over any Windows PC.
Yosemite was really nice, not to mention the free update from OS X 10.6 to Yosemite when I got this MacBook from my aunt.
Ant,m I've been using the OS X El Capitan betas since about a month or two before El Cap was released to the public completed.
Worked great!
No crashes, DEFINITELY saw an improvement in battery life, a little speed increase too!
I don't know whats with all the bad reviews, once the install optimizes your system, it works great even on older Mac, especially with upgraded RAM.

El Cap was fast enough when I had 2 GB in my MacBook, though when I had several apps open, even if my Hardware resource monitor still showed available RAM, ot was a bit sluggish switching apps, but when I bought 4 GB of RAM off eBay and installed it, my MacBook's speed increased by about 45 - 65%!
A bit faster boot times, and ALOT better app switching too!!
I'm running the most recent version of the beta available to the beta program as I type this, and I have to say I am loving this Mac!

With the brightness at full (when I sit outside), the volume at about 85%, and browsing the web, I get a good 3 - 4 hours of battery, compared to trying that on any of my Windows laptops, which when doing all that I'd be very lucky to even hit 2 hours.
And to think I'm getting the "Service Battery" alert, and it still does fine!
I can get a max of 8 hours on a charge when rationing battery, which is great and easier with El Capitan's "Under-the-hood" improvements.

Now, there are a few things I'd like to be different, like the battery icon, when it really is near 8%, the red bar in the battery icon should be very skinny, not red and as fat as in 25%....sorry, OCD a bit.
Anyways, overall, loving El Capitan!
It allows my 5-year old MacBook to keep up with anything I need to out there!

System InfoDevice: MacBook7,1 (Mid-2010, 13.3")CPU: Intel Core 2 Duo P8600 @ 2.4 GHz (1067 MHz FSB, 3 MB Cache)Display: 13.3", 1280x800, Organic LED/LCDRAM: 4 GB (2 x 2 GB) DDR3 1067 MHzGPU: NVIDIA GeForce 320M (256 MB VRAM)OS: OS X El Capitan beta (OS X 10.11.2 beta, build 15C48a)So, despite the bad ratings from people that don't give it time to smooth out and/or clogtheirs up (Tip: Don't paste a lot of photos directly to your desktop, on any computer, Windows, Mac, Linux, whatever, can slow it down.
Also, wait a minute or two after logging in on older Macs iff needed, to allow everything to fully load up.
Plus, if you experience bugs, Apple will fix them.
It's called patience, some people who wrote bad reviews tried it for an hour and said "I hate it"), I LOVE El Cap, it's more than worth it!
Plus, If you like it, WRITE A GOOD REVIEW!

People are too scared to update because of all the bad reviews, when, if people have issues, they review about those, but all the people who like it like me don't always think or remember to leave a review saying you like it.
I Love it, it's worth it, trust me, people.
Hopefully for OS X 10.12, it will be even better!
Been a Mac user for years.
Of course, occassionally over the years I would get an entire screen error but now, the Finder just hangs on simple tasks.
Sure, it feels "snappy" but the OS is of no use when doing menial tasks like moving a file or copying.
Did someone in Apple go in and delete half the code in the O/S?
Such strange things happening.

This iMac I'm using is only good for running a virtual machine with Windows in it, a choice I've made recently unfortunately because Yosemite and El Capitan are just plain "not easy(iTunes)", "hanging(Finder)", "unresponsive(Finder)" etc.
Ive had to do more hard reboots in a recent month than over many years altogether.
Thanks Apple, just because I upgraded my wifi/bluetooth with ACTUAL APPLE PARTS that just weren't meant for my Mac, I don't have my bluetooth LE anymore.
In fact I don't have ANY Bluetooth, it worked fine in 10.10!

Please fix this in 10.11.1!update: I learned that my USB 2.0 ports were running slower than 1.1, my isight camera didn't work and after the update to 10.11.1 nothing was fixed and my MacBook ran much hotter.

row.Title: Why the bad reviews?
row.Topic: Compatibility, El_Capitan, N/A, Safari, Update, Yosemite

row.Sentences: El Capitan is the best OS X release yet in my experience, and I've been on Macs since OS 9.
The upgrade made the interface snappier on my 2012 Macbook, and the new split-screen features are excellent for those that use a multitude of virtual desktops.
The reason behind the faster interface is Apple's implementation of Metal, but I'll spare the boring details behind it.
Long story short, system graphics and animations run noticeably better than they did with OpenGL on Yosemite.
It's possible that there are some users who have had a plethora of OS X iterations on their computers over the years, and haven't had a clean install since purchase.
I recommend - if you're concerned because of the negative reviews - that you do a backup of your important files, and then do a clean install of El Capitan.
I did a clean install with Yosemite and had not one issue with the subsequent 10.11 upgrade via the App Store.
The upgrade is worth it for Safari tabs alone, considering how much more power efficient and quicker the native browser runs on laptops compared to Chrome.
"Desktop' users probably won't notice the difference between Chrome and Safari.
Anyway, the Windows-esque features are a very welcomed addition to an already phenomenal operating system.
And as always kids, if gaming on a level beyond Hearthstone and MOBAs are important to you, build a gaming rig and quit your whining - Macs are for designers, post-production, producers, and coders.
P. S. Ensure any vital software is compatible before upgrading.
Seems a lot of reviewers are having issues with 3rd party apps.
I waited for the first update to El Capitan before upgrading to it.
I had plenty of problems with Mavericks when I first upgraded.
It choked on having 5 or 10 tabs open in Safari, and it would barely work.
But as they updated, it got better and better until I didn't notice any problems.
Then Yosemite was a smooth upgrade.
Worked pretty well, even on my 2008 Macbook pro.
But I upgraded to El Capitan now, and I can't seem to stay connected to my home wifi for more than half an hour.
All my other devices stay connected, but not my mac.
I hope apple fixes this soon.
Getting old.
ABSOLUTELY THE WORSE MOVE I EVER MADE.
LOST MY EMAIL FOLDERS, CAN'T GET MY PHOTOS RUNNING.
MY BACKUPS ARE WATED.
APPLE HURT ME BAD THIS TIME.

row.Title: No problems:
row.Topic: El_Capitan, N/A, Office, Performance, Update, Windows

row.Sentences: Purchasd a new laptop.
New Macbooks Pro I7 with 500gb SSD.
Installed quickly, updated quickly and runs great!
No issues with El Capitan.
Using parallels in the background with Microsoft Office install on the virtual machine and on OS X.
Office 2016 opens quickly with no issues.
Love the new update.
I run windows in coherence mode and everything runs like a dream there as well.
It's always fun to see someone's face when I run Microsoft on an apple machine.
Even better is that Microsoft Windows runs better than any other PC machine I own on my Macbook Pro.
So far so GREAT!

row.Title: OSX Windows - The worst!
row.Topic: El_Capitan, N/A, Performance, Spotlight, Update, Windows

row.Sentences: This is the first time in 10 years Apple that I feel like I am using a PC again.
The main reason why I use Apple is because I dont like waiting.
Everything takes AGES to open, load, find.
The spotlight for example takes an average of 10-20 seconds to even show any results, another 15 to open any app.
Windows for saving files, such as in PS, start up black, then turn white and then show contents and information.
I had issues with the computer crashing due the OSX and it took several tries to get it back running without crashing right away after login in.
I dont know what they hink to release this crap.
The only good is that you can update older computers too now.
Basically on my old MacBook it works ok, while my new and fast iMac turned into a good looking PC.
Oh and one more thing.
Who had the idea to give an OS he name El Capitan.
Not that I am racist, I live in Puerto Rico and the language is spanish, but what kind of name is that?
What marketing purpose?
Jobs would turn around in his grave.
